PETITION.TITLE: States Grants Schools Assistance Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act, 1988 includes legislation, Part III-Changes to Non-Government Schools and New Non-Government Schools, designed to inhibit the establishment, growth and development of these schools in Australia by the imposition of restrictive provisions in the areas of funding, enrolments and approval criteria.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

Reconsider the application and implications of this legislation in the light of justice, equity and freedom of choice for parents and have the unfair sections (Section 8 (2), 8 (15) and (11)) repealed.
And you petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from three citizens) and Colston (from 24 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The proposed cuts in funding to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will have serious effects on the viability of many family chemists, leading to increased charges and reduction in services and availability of medicines to the community.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to reject the findings of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal and maintain the level of funding existing prior to the Tribunal's findings.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Romania
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Rumania, whose Human Rights Record had been worse than that of South Africa's even before it embarked on a diabolic village destruction program, deservedly attracts worldwide condemnation. The systematic cultural genocide of the peoples affected must be prevented.
Therefore your petitioners humbly pray that:
1. the Australian Parliament establish whether or not Rumania has satisfied fully her obligations under the Treaty of Trianon (1920) and the Peace Treaty of Paris (1947);
2. if found that Rumania violates these agreements, the signatures representing Australia jointly or singularly be withdrawn from the thus invalidated documents;
3. Australia table her findings at the appropriate forums of the United Nations.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programs for children and particularly those programs promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by Western Australia Independent senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This Act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programs that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes: Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
The humble petition of the Victorian Bush Nursing Association and all its affiliated agencies sheweth that:

As a group of supporters of the Victorian Bush Nursing Association and all of its affiliated bush nursing centres, hospitals, nursing homes, and hostels, we call on the Senate to ensure the continuation of the sixteen bush nursing centres, thirty-six hospitals, seventeen nursing homes, and two hostels throughout Victoria.

Every affiliated agency of the Victorian Bush Nursing Association is an autonomous not-for-profit community based organisation aiming to provide the most appropriate health service to the people of its area. For nearly eighty years these bodies have made a significant contribution to Victoria's health services, particularly in rural areas.
The continued operation of some agencies is now in doubt due to severe financial pressures. We believe no community can afford to lose the services provided by these agencies.
Your petitioners therefore pray that every effort be made by the Senate to ensure that no bush nursing centre, hospital or nursing home is forced to close.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: FEDERAL AIRPORTS CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990CIVIL AVIATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now going to enter the second reading debate stage of the debate on the Federal Airports Corporation Amendment Bill 1990 and the Civil Aviation Authority Amendment Bill 1990. These are largely housekeeping Bills and the Opposition will not be opposing them. There are some general points we would like to make before we start.

SPEECH.PARA: My starting point will be the second reading speech of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) for both Bills because in the first paragraph of both speeches, which are largely identical in content, the Minister said that a central plank in the Government's micro-economic reform agenda for restructuring the public sector is that government business enterprises be as efficient as possible and responsive to consumer needs. The Opposition supports that wholeheartedly, particularly the parts that both organisations be as efficient as possible and responsible to consumer needs.

The tragedy of the situation is that the Government does not have the first idea about how it should go about setting up an efficient Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) or Federal Airports Corporation (FAC). Certainly the matter of being responsive to the consumers' needs is something that neither authority has attained at all. One of the great tragedies of the present time is that in a sector that is as vital for Australia's economic welfare and well-being as the transport industry the Government has seen the aviation industry purely as a milking cow. Seven years of Labor Government has seen a massive rundown in the infrastructure, which has got so bad that the Government is now in a panic drive to move and re-establish the radio-navigational aids and the radar surveillance equipment that the airways need. The services from a hardware point of view are very, very badly run down and, concomitant with this, has been a rundown in the morale and the professional competence of the bodies regulating the airways movements in this country, namely, the CAA.

We do need to regulate air activity. The argument really is about the degree of regulation and the method that is used. This Government broke up the old Department of Aviation and created two new statutory authorities which were allegedly going to be independent: the FAC, to look after government-owned airports and manage them on a private basis; and the Civil Aviation Authority, to regulate the airways and aviation activity in this country. That is fine in theory. In practice what we are dealing with is a statutory authority in each case which largely has monopoly powers.

The Government has not been able to come up with a system which fairly, justly and efficiently provides a system by which these monopolies could operate for the benefit of the community. The Government said to them: `You have to be self-sufficient financially'. That, of course, was one of the reasons why the Government promoted them. It wanted to get the cost of aviation off budget. But in saying to them that they had to pay their own way, the Government failed to recognise that in a monopoly situation there was no pressure in any way at all operating on the authorities to behave in an efficient manner. The consequences of that inefficiency are the very much higher charges which are now borne by people in the aviation industry, users of aviation industry and, of course, ultimately the whole of Australia.

Let me put that in simple terms so that everyone can understand: whereas once we had a single management structure running the Department of Aviation, we now have two parallel, bloated bureaucracies. We have two boards: we have a board for the CAA and a board for the FAC. We have headquarters for them. We have all the supporting staff. We have the great train of administrative baggage that moves with two authorities. The point is that they are not operating in distinctly different fields. To a certain degree, their operations are very complementary, one to another, one supporting the airfields, the other doing the air side of it-what is off the ground. The net result has undeniably been a blow-out in costs that affects the whole of the Australian community-not only those people who wish to use aviation services.

The other great disadvantage of the system is that it has not been accepted by the industry with any favour at all. The aviation industry views with extreme displeasure and disfavour both the FAC and the CAA. The airlines do not care terribly much because they are not affected by it. They are big enough to be a law unto themselves: as the pilots dispute demonstrated last year, whatever the airlines want the airlines get. It was just a phone call to the Minister and the Minister called the Civil Aviation Authority or the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation or the FAC, or whoever it was, and fees were waived, licences were granted or validated, and the airlines had no difficulty at all with the regulatory authority.

But the airlines are not aviation in Australia. The very great bulk of aviation activity takes place in what is described as the general aviation sector. That is a bad description because it includes so many different forms of activity. The big users of aviation service in this country, the people who fly the overwhelming majority of hours, who have the overwhelming number of aircraft, and all the rest of it, are those air work groups-people operating third level and commuter airlines, charter operators, training schools, training organisations, agricultural aviation and the business aviation group. They are the really big users. If one can find anyone in Australia in those groups who thinks that the FAC or the CAA have been an improvement in the management of aviation in Australia, I would be very surprised. As someone who is involved in the industry and who has been for over 20 years, I know that they are viewed with extreme disfavour because of their unresponsiveness to the needs of the industry and the inefficiencies.

I would like to give a few examples of what I was talking about before when I said that the business of regulation of the aviation activities in this country was a matter of degree. We are a very regulated country in most ways. We have a huge number of people involved in government: look at the 800-odd local authorities in this country, the six State governments and the Federal Government. All of those legislative bodies produce legislation. It should not be any surprise that aviation is greatly over-regulated.

One of the easy examples to demonstrate in public is the way the Australian Civil Aviation Authority and its predecessors have demanded, as of right, that any new aircraft introduced into this country has to pass their own certification. It does not matter that certification is something that costs millions and millions of dollars, in the case of a regular public transport passenger aircraft that might involve six months or even a year's testing. It does not matter that this is done with great thoroughness and great sophistication by the American regulatory authorities or the British civil air registration groups or the European groups. All that stands for nought if someone wants to introduce a new aircraft into Australia. The operator of that aircraft has to go to the delay and the trouble and the huge expense of certifying it for Australian use.

Despite many appeals from the industry, the Civil Aviation Authority and the Government have turned a completely blind eye to this until the recent past. There is a glimmer of hope on the horizon that at last we will accept the professional credentials of certifying authorities in overseas countries. I hope we do. But the real question to be asked of the Government and of the Civil Aviation Authority is: Why has this nonsense been allowed to continue all these years since the Wright brothers first flew-at great cost, not to the airlines themselves, but to everyone in Australia? That cost of registration flows through the whole community.

One of the other problems we have with the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation is that this Government has messed around with the administration for so long that the old corporate ethos, which was very strong in the Department of Civil Aviation (DCA), has now disappeared. When I started flying, people were very proud to be members of the old DCA. In those days they had a great pride in their work. They knew that they were part of a regulatory authority whose professional credentials were recognised and respected around the world. They knew that the people at the top-whether it was Sir Richard Williams or Sir Donald Anderson-were practical airmen, great airmen in their own right, and that all the senior personnel in the Department knew what aviation was about. With all the changes that have taken place, starting with the Whitlam Government changing the title and the function of the Department and carried on by the Hawke Labor Government, the whole of the corporate spirit and that ethos-that pride in their being, the knowledge that they were doing an essential task and knowing what that task was-have disappeared from the aviation scene.

I do not mean to be unkind to any of them-most of the senior executives of the CAA are charming people, very honest and hardworking and all the rest of it-but the sad fact is that one has to go down about three or four levels in the management structure before one finds anyone who has any real knowledge of what aviation is about. None of the divisional heads has ever earned a living flying or owning or maintaining aircraft. They are quite remote from it, and we have seen many nonsenses from this.

One of the important things the CAA does in a minor way is to publish a journal on air safety. To my knowledge, that has been going for about 40 years since the early 1950s. The purpose of this magazine, which comes out about six times a year, is to look at accidents and incidents in aviation and to draw lessons from them for the education of people in the industry. One of the attributes of this publication has been its extreme accuracy. Within the last 12 months, one of the articles in that journal was absolutely breathtaking in its ignorance. It talked about how the operator of an aircraft had a problem which was related to electrical supply and it confused the magneto switches, which provide the ignition service to a reciprocating petrol engine, with the master switch providing the electrical services. It may be hard for the Senate to understand the significance of that, but it is equivalent in theological terms to confusing the devil with God. It is absolutely unbelievable that that should happen.

Then a prohibition was issued that affected the Antique Aircraft Association, which is now very strong in Australia. It said that any aircraft engine that had not been subjected to a major overhaul within the last 15 years had to be withdrawn from service on safety grounds. Again, that is absolute nonsense. Most of the aircraft in that category fly only 10 or 15 or probably no more than 30 hours a year. They are very well looked after and they are kept under cover. To subject them to a major engine overhaul for which the expertise may be difficult to obtain in this country, purely because of the expiration of time rather than because of hours flown, which is the basic way of assessing engine life, is absolute nonsense. The important point is that no-one in the Civil Aviation Authority before that air navigation order was promulgated talked to anyone in the industry.

There is hope on the horizon. The new Chairman of the CAA is Mr Dick Smith, who made a great name for himself protesting about the sort of nonsense in the administration of the CAA that has occurred in the immediate past. Indeed, he wrote a book which received a great deal of publicity at the time, called Two Years in the Aviation Hall of Doom. The trouble is that the aviation hall of doom is still in existence. I hope that Mr Dick Smith has the ability to clean up the Augean stables of overregulation in that industry, because they still exist.

Several weeks ago, by courtesy of Senator Robert Ray, I was on the lead aircraft, an Air Force C130, flying into Longreach on flood relief missions. When we flew into Longreach the C130 landed on the sealed runway, which is 5,000 feet long. Because there had been a lot of rain, the aircraft was kept on the runway. It was not taken onto the taxiway and on to the apron. Because an aeroplane was on the runway, the Civil Aviation Authority closed Longreach Airport. While the aircraft was unloaded, which was a lengthy process which took about 2 3/4 to three hours, there were four aircraft in orbit over the field, unable to land. It was bureaucracy gone mad.

Here we were in an emergency, in a flood situation. We were in a remote part of Queensland, and we had a prohibition from a Civil Aviation Authority which was hundreds or thousands of miles away from the scene of the action. Those aircraft could have landed with absolute safety because behind the C130 was 4,900 feet of sealed runway. I know that two of the aircraft were Cessna 172s which probably required no more than 600 feet in order to come to rest. One of the pilots was a very experienced charter operator who I know could quite safely have landed at that airport at the time, without compromising the safety of the C130 in any way. Illustrating the nonsense of the prohibition on civil aircraft landing was the fact that an Air Force Caribou came in and landed on the runway behind the C130. The whole of the airport was paralysed purely because of the inflexibility of an uncaring regulatory body.

One of the other prospects for improvement that is on the horizon, though, is the report by Mr Owen Lawrie, which I have not yet been privileged to read. Mr Lawrie, an experienced engineer, was regional director in Queensland before he retired. The Lawrie report is into the degree of activity and involvement of the Civil Aviation Authority. I hope that Mr Lawrie's report is a cleansing operation with respect to the regulatory functions of this body, because it certainly needs it.

As I said at the outset, that is not to say that there is not a need for regulation. When people are flying for hire and reward they have to meet standards. But there are many people flying for recreation or for personal business reasons who do not need the same regulations that Qantas, Ansett or Australian Airlines need. Those people are grossly overregulated and suffer very great costs and limitations on their activities as a consequence. That is quite unnecessary.

I turn to the Bill itself. The Opposition is not opposed to the Bill and I wish to make only a few points in relation to it. The first part of the Bill deals with a freedom being granted to the Civil Aviation Authority with respect to certain State and Territory laws, which is unexceptionable. There is another section on negligent operation of aircraft, which again is eminently reasonable. The difficulty I have with that section is purely one of definition, because what may appear to be dangerous to someone else, in the eyes of an informed airman or operator may be safe. It is a matter of experience, capability and skill. While the Opposition supports the incorporation in the Act of the requirement to operate aircraft safely without hazarding life or property, we can see difficulties in definition when it is put to the test.

A very large section in the Bill deals with the carriage of dangerous goods and, given the way that aviation or air freight moves so many products, it is absolutely essential that the carrier knows what is in them, because a lot of people who consign goods have no knowledge of the effect of those goods if they leak or if they emit gases in an aircraft, and whether they are packed under pressure in aerosol packs and all sorts of things like that. We support very much a declaration of the contents of the goods and a definition of what is dangerous and not dangerous to carry.

A section of the Bill modifies the granting of air operators' certificates, which is something that we could talk about at great length. The only point I wish to make about that is that last year in the pilots dispute the Civil Aviation Authority could not issue air operators' certificates fast enough at the airline companies' request. Formerly, if one wanted an airline operator's certificate, like Mr Ellis in Tasmania, one had to be prepared to wait many months or years and face the possibility of total rejection, of getting nowhere if one wanted a licence to operate an airline. I hope that the changes that the Civil Aviation Authority adopted on granting certificates to the friends of Sir Peter Abeles and Australian Airlines are carried on efficiently, because if someone wants to get into business, if they meet the requirements of the Department, they should be granted the licence to operate straight off.

Another change deals with the composition of the board, its powers and duties, and the most significant part of that is that it takes the employees of the Civil Aviation Authority out of the Public Service Act. One of the great bones of contention between the CAA and the FAC has been that the FAC employees are allowed to operate under terms and conditions set by the board of the FAC whereas the CAA employees, who are allegedly employees of an independent statutory authority, had to conform to the Public Service Act. In regard to airworthiness surveyors and aircraft engineers, who are in very, very short supply because of the policies of the Government in this country and who can earn far more from overseas airlines or in private enterprise maintenance companies, it was very difficult for the Civil Aviation Authority, for example, to get people to make sure that airworthiness standards were being met with respect to maintenance and engineering. I would hope that, moving out of the Public Service restrictions into a system where the board has the power to set the terms and conditions of its employees, the CAA will be able to meet the market and attract the people that it needs to do the specialised job.

There is a requirement that the CAA revalues its assets every five years, which again is a way of the Government squeezing more and more out of the community, because the revaluation of assets is an artificial way by which the Government can demand that the CAA shows a greater return on its investments, which, by the way, the Australian taxpayer bought and paid for generations ago and which, with a typical Keating sleight of hand, were transferred and actually sold to the new CAA. Also, the tax exemptions that the CAA formerly enjoyed have gone.

The final part of the Bill deals with the imposition of liens. The Opposition is very strongly opposed to the power of the Civil Aviation Authority to impose a lien, in other words, to seize an aircraft when a payment has not been made to the Civil Aviation Authority. We will not oppose this through an amendment but we want to bring public attention to the Department's unfairness here. The problem arises because a lot of the arguments about fees paid by the CAA arise through the accounting incompetence of the Authority itself.

When this system was first introduced there were charges known as air navigation charges. People who owned an aircraft or operated one had to pay a registration fee which ran into hundreds or thousands of dollars. If they did not pay the fee, the old Department argued that it should be allowed to seize the aircraft and sell it for payment of those fees, which could mount up to quite a large amount. Air navigation charges no longer exist and the charges that are made are en route charges for flights made. It is a well-established fact of life that the accounting systems in the CAA are not accurate. People are being billed for accounts that they did not generate and there is great argument among various operators in the industry as to just what the account is about.

The Civil Aviation Authority has taken a high-handed attitude, and if the bill has not been paid six months after presentation, the Authority seizes the aircraft and deprives the operator of his livelihood. Our argument is that there are parallels in all other forms of business with respect to payments of accounts, and those are the parallels of resolution before the courts, which the Civil Aviation Authority should follow.

Let us turn to the Federal Airports Corporation Amendment Bill 1990. Again it starts with the pious hope that the government business enterprises be as efficient as possible and responsible to consumer needs. In relation to the latter part, all of the surveys that have been done in the aviation industry show that the FAC is held in even worse regard than the Civil Aviation Authority. That really is some achievement. It is held in bad regard because it is not in the least responsive to the consumers' needs. It is not interested and does not know anything about the industry.

This Bill provides a number of significant changes. One of the minor points at the start of it that interested me was the deletion of the requirement that the FAC should cooperate to the extent required with the Department of Civil Aviation. It is no secret at all that, whatever relationships might exist at board level between the CAA and the FAC, it is open war on many of the airfields around Australia where they both operate. The CAA treats the FAC with absolute contempt and that is reciprocated by the FAC. For the users of the airfields and people involved in the industry that friction is not at all helpful.

The second part of the Bill removes the anti-hijack limitations on the Federal Airports Corporation. It is essential that, as the operator of the real estate, it is involved in security planning. The record of the FAC has not been too good in this. In my previous responsibility as shadow Minister for Customs, I saw many problems, particularly with Sydney Airport, where the FAC would not cooperate with the Australian Customs Service on the creation of secure areas and the passage of individuals between them. Those problems now have been largely overcome.

The changes that have taken place in the CAA board are largely paralleled in the FAC Bill, with the exception that its employees, of course, are employed under terms and conditions set by their board. The exemption from taxation and sales tax has also been removed and in both cases in both Bills the charges set by the authorities have been subjected to Prices Surveillance Authority oversight.

The final part of the Federal Airports Corporation Bill gives the Corporation an exclusion from the Freedom of Information Act, which we think is quite wrong in view of the fact that it has a monopoly position. Overall, the Opposition supports these Bills. Both authorities will become a little more efficient if the boards of the authorities have the skills to exploit the opportunities that are offered to them by these changes. In the case of the FAC, the Bill will also help to create a climate where it will be easier for us either to remove or privatise the FAC when we get into government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: -Mr Deputy President, I wish to confine my remarks to the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill 1990, referring specifically to clause 4, relating to standards, and clause 47, the regulations. I shall deal particularly with standards and what is the appropriate standard to be applied as a safety factor in updating the position of aircraft. Now, I note with some interest the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure into the organisation and operations of the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority, and particularly the following comments in relation to the CAA, the Minister and the Department with regard to the responsibilities of this Authority:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the context of streamlining the Department of Aviation . . . decided . . . to create the CAA . . . in addition to the setting of safety standards and having day to day regulatory control of aviation, the Authority would have `. . . operational responsibility for air traffic control, flight advisory services, communications, navigation and surveillance systems, and rescue and fire fighting services at airports'.

The legislative functions of the CAA require it to establish and administer an appropriate safety regulatory framework within which relevant civil air operations shall be conducted; and, secondly, to operate an effective and efficient system of air traffic services to maintain a high level of safety for all airspace users. Now, it is this latter function with which I wish to take some issue. In so doing, I refer to an ABC 7.30 Report screened on 25 May 1989, almost a year ago, when attention was drawn to Australia's air traffic control crisis. The 7.30 Report concerned itself with the $2.4m French air traffic control autonomous radar display system, more commonly known as ACARDS. Originally this system was ordered in 1980 but it was not delivered unil 1984. Housing to accommodate the system was not completed until 1986, and then it took a further three years to get it going, a total of nine years, by which time, of course, the system was outmoded.

The whole story is just a saga of botch-up after botch-up, though perhaps the blame should not be laid at the feet of the CAA, since it became operative only on 1 July 1988; or maybe the CAA was formed so that the Government could have a scapegoat, someone else to blame for this gross bungle. If the personnel previously in the Aviation Department involved in the ACARDS mess were transferred to the newly formed CAA, it is no wonder that few, if any, positive comments were made to the Senate Standing Committee with regard to its performance. I think this was certainly some indictment of that report. At the time of reporting, the ABC mentioned the number of near misses which had been recorded and the 2,000 reported mishaps, an average of perhaps five mishaps a day. To replace the whole system would take three years or, if history repeated itself, perhaps nine years.

Over recent weeks I have had cause to travel to Canberra on a number of occasions and each time my flight from Launceston to Melbourne has been put into a holding pattern over Wonthaggi. This holding pattern has been maintained for a minimum of 20 and extending up to perhaps 40 minutes, and consequently my connecting flights to Canberra were missed. My first inclination, naturally, was to blame the airlines for poor timetabling. However, this week I again had cause to fly to Canberra and to have my flight again put into a holding pattern over Wonthaggi. I inquired of the cabin crew as to the reason for this continual holding pattern occurrence. To my absolute horror, they informed me that air traffic control had updated its systems so that a computer printout of a plane's position was now given every four minutes instead of the previous 30 seconds. So much for being updated. Obviously, something must really be wrong, and I seek clarification. There must be some misinformation. If not, I ask the Minister to look into it as a matter of some urgency.

Naturally, I was absolutely horrified at this piece of information. How many variables can occur in what I consider to be an interminable four minutes? How many kilometres do various planes cover in four minutes? How many seconds does it take one plane to get into the flight path of another, thus allowing the potential for two planes to collide? I am sure that anybody hearing of this situation would concur with me that the Civil Aviation Authority is not adequately carrying out its legislative functions, and particularly that which requires it to operate an efficient and effective system of air traffic services, to maintain a high level of safety for all airspace users.

I apologise for taking up some valuable debating time at the start of what could well be a marathon effort for the Senate during this sitting period. However, while this matter is not directly addressed in this amendment Bill, I have referred to the appropriate clauses. I believe it is important and that attention should be drawn to this matter. I ask for clarification from the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of legislation is, as the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) points out in his second reading speech, in the case of the aviation industry the final step in the commercialisation of government business enterprises in that area. The second reading speech of the Minister goes on to say that this commercialisation is `a necessary and fundamental precondition to improvements in efficiency'.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout the range of legislation which has come before this Parliament with regard to the commercialisation of government business enterprises, the turning of government authorities into business enterprises, on all occasions the Australian Democrats have expressed the view that that statement which I just quoted is not necessarily the case, that it does not necessarily follow that commercialisation ipso facto equals improvement in efficiency. As I wander through the commercial sector of the city of Melbourne, of which I am an inhabitant, any lunchtime I see bulging restaurants, in spite of the implementation of the fringe benefits tax, which caused me to question the efficiency of many of the commercial enterprises that operate in that city.

The Federal Airports Corporation Amendment Bill and the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill cause us great concern, and I pick up Senator Watson's point: while claims are made by the Government in the second reading speeches on both of these Bills that consumers will benefit, we are concerned about what those benefits will be, particularly as there is great emphasis in this commercialisation on the need for the Civil Aviation Authority and the Airports Corporation to be profitable and, indeed, the expectation that they will be, which is shown by the removal of tax exemptions. That expectation seems to us to be at least potentially in conflict with any expectation of reduction in costs to consumers and-the point of most concern-potential reductions in the priority given to safety issues. We see a great deal of potential for conflict between the goals of a commercial organisation expected to make a profit and pay taxes and the goals of organisations which have oversight of our air travellers on matters of safety. Senator Watson has expressed some concerns about that, and those are concerns that we share.

As in this whole debate about commercialisation, we have questioned whether this is the way to go. We would also say that, if profit is to be made, then it is not necessarily the case that that could not be ploughed back into these government business enterprises or, indeed, into the authorities as they have previously been constituted.
I point to clause 4 of the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill to demonstrate one of our concerns about the actual wording in the legislation. Paragraph (b) provides:
consistent with the Authority's obligations under section 11
and, even having regard to those obligations under section 11, we are concerned with the following wording-
have regard to any costs that would arise from complying with the standards.

That sort of terminology gives rise to our concern about what is to be the priority in this new business enterprise-safety standards or costs. We would have welcomed wording which gave us more comfort that the standards would remain the highest of priorities.

We note that these Bills really just take the process to its completion, and therefore we will not be going to the wall kicking and screaming and will not call for a division in opposition to it. However, I am expressing our opposition to this whole process of which these Bills are a part. Of course, there other aspects to both these Bills we see as positive, including the ability under the Federal Airports Corporation Amendment Bill for anti-terrorist activity to be undertaken, but one of the areas in both Bills about which we are concerned is the removal of Public Service Act coverage of the employees. We have been consistent across this whole package of government business enterprise Bills in that we do not necessarily believe that the only way to get flexibility and performance out of people who are currently public servants is to remove their Public Service coverage. As I said, we often question whether a businesslike approach is always the most efficient method when we look at the way many private businesses operate, but what we do say here is that we insist that the removal of Public Service Act coverage must not disadvantage workers in this industry. As I say, we reject the assumption that it is not possible for flexibility to be involved while Public Service Act coverage exists. In fact, I believe that must be a goal for all of us with regard to the Public Service, because, no matter how much more of this sort of legislation there is, we will always have a Public Service and we must be able to have flexibility within it.

We certainly agree with the area of the operation of the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA), but I would like to stress some of the aspects of the recommendations contained in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure entitled the Organisation and Operations of the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority. Chapter 5 emphasises and calls for extensive consultation between those authorities and the industry. We strongly support those recommendations and urge the authorities to take note of them as well as the reference to decisions of all kinds, including decisions about costs and charges, which are dealt with in this section of the legislation with regard to the PSA. We hope that those consultations will take place and that they are a major feature of the continuing operations of these organisations.

A number of concerns have been expressed in this whole area. What I think we are really saying is that we are concerned that pressures arising from the commercial objective that has now been set for the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation will cause increases in costs and charges that will find their way through to the consumer. We acknowledge, as the Minister said in his second reading speech on the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill, that the consumer is not just the person flying; this industry produces intermediate inputs into the rest of the economy. We believe that this commercial pressure could be a problem in that area. I quote Mr Peter Petroni, the President of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, writing in the April 1990 edition of that Association's journal:

The CAA's proposed safety regulatory charges for 1990-91 represent the area of greatest concern. Increases of 100 per cent are common for many of the 168 major items. Mr Owen Lawry, former Queensland Regional Director, was engaged as consultant to the CAA to review safety regulatory charges and stated in his draft recommendation that he considered that many of the services provided by the CAA were either unnecessary or could be better provided by industry. Mr Lawry's recommendations must be fully explored before any changes are made to the charging arrangements. Due to the current economic climate, I believe we should have a moratorium of price increases until all other alternatives are investigated.

One of the assumptions behind this kind of legislation coming from the Government, and strongly endorsed by the Opposition, as we have heard from Senator MacGibbon-endorsed, as all legislation in these packages has been, because it does pave the way for future privatisation of these kinds of government enterprises by a future coalition government, which was a point made by Senator MacGibbon at the end of his speech-is that this is the only way to go. That needs to be questioned. I quote the Australian Institute of Navigation, just to make a very important point:

While the CAA does not borrow overseas directly, there is a long delay on much needed capital works. The system needs money, but that money must ultimately come from the air traveller because the Government has decreed that aviation, alone of all the public transport systems, must pay for all of its infrastructure costs. Shipping, rail, trucking and coach transportation are heavily subsidised.

That is an important point that we want to make in speaking to these two Bills. As the Institute of Navigation has pointed out, we really cannot see why the financial base of the air transport industry cannot be seen as a community responsibility in the same way as it is in other areas of transportation, particularly as-and here I go back to part of the remarks of Senator Watson-priority does need to be, and must be, safety, and, if it is, there is clearly a community responsibility.

Given the thrust of this legislation and the future intentions of the Opposition should it find itself in government, clearly the key goal would be profitability and commercial success. That is a matter of enormous concern to the Democrats. However, we note the comments of the new Chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority, Mr Dick Smith, when he stated in Australian Aviation in May this year:
My aim is to improve the level of travelling safety by getting as many people into the air as possible.

Mr Smith's stated goals-which the Democrats share-are safety and access to air travel for as many Australians as possible. We certainly wish the Chairman well in achieving those goals, and we hope that our concerns about the questions of priorities will be considered constantly in the ongoing work of the two Authorities which, as we say, we are concerned are perhaps being set off in directions which may be in conflict with at least, in particular, the goal of guaranteed safety and what has been, until now, an extraordinarily well performing industry in this country in an international sense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their positive contribution to this debate. I want to refer briefly to a number of comments made, in particular, by Senator Watson and Senator Powell, regarding the prime responsibility of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) in respect of safety. In relation to Senator MacGibbon's contribution to the debate, he knows full well that I have general agreement with his approach to regulation. I hope that over the term of this Government, that general agreement with the approach he has to regulation will become more and more obvious in terms of the way in which the CAA operates.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon also spoke about the sections of the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill dealing with carriage of dangerous goods. I know that the operators of both of Australia's major airlines are becoming increasingly concerned about the problems that could be posed for safety by this very matter-that is, the carriage of dangerous goods. I recall only last year-and I point this out to the frequent fliers in this chamber-an incident involving a Boeing 727 aircraft which caused me to sharpen up in respect of the carriage of dangerous goods. We all know, we frequent fliers, that there is a prohibition on the carriage of matches in luggage on board aircraft. Like a lot of other people who spend half their life living in motels, I had a fairly healthy collection of matchbooks from various motels laying around in the bottom of my suitcase because it was a handy way to keep the telephone numbers.

There was an incident last year when a suitcase on board an aircraft containing a box of these matchs ignited and the aircraft was delayed. In fact, I was on board the flight. The aircraft was delayed for some hours at Adelaide airport, because when the hatches on the luggage compartment of the aircraft were opened the sight that greeted the eyes of the ground staff was not very healthy. Smoke was pouring out of the aircraft. Indeed, the entire internal contents of the suitcase had been combusted. Of course, aircraft holds, as Senator MacGibbon knows, are specifically designed to be particularly airtight to contain that kind of problem if it should occur.

I can assure all honourable senators that my suitcase was cleaned out the minute I arrived in Darwin and that I will not make the mistake of throwing matchbooks into my suitcase again. That is just one example of why those sensible regulations do apply to things as simple as books of matches being carried on board aircraft. They can potentially cause air disasters leading to great loss of life. I know that the airlines are increasingly concerned about highlighting to a greater degree what is becoming an increasing problem on aircraft: the quite often innocent carriage of dangerous goods on board aircraft.

Senator MacGibbon also addressed one of the major thrusts of both the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill and the Federal Airports Corporation Amendment Bill: the ability that it will give to both the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) in the recruitment of their staff. I consider that to be an extremely important objective of this legislation which in the future will lead to more efficient operation in both of those organisations.

I confess I do not understand Senator MacGibbon's comment on the sleight of hand, as he referred to it, of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in transferring expensive public assets to the FAC and the CAA, which are of course both government business enterprises, wholly government owned. I am not quite sure whom Senator MacGibbon thinks the Government should give them to. Nevertheless, I thank him for what was a positive contribution to the debate.

Senator Watson's concerns about the air traffic control autonomous radar display system as well founded. I have similar concerns about the efficient operation of that system. I will pursue a detailed technical response to Senator Watson's concerns and relay it to him as soon as I am able to-hopefully, later this week.

The one substantial matter raised by speakers during the debate that I want finally to address myself to is the question about the concerns of commercialisation of the operations of the CAA and any possible impact that might have on safety. I can assure all honourable senators that the primary responsibility of the CAA is, as it always has been, safety. However, having said that, I would like to say that I agree completely with the comments that have been made by a number of people-most notable among them the Chairman of the CAA, Dick Smith. A great myth has been perpetuated in this country that there is no cost consideration that can ever be or has ever been applied to safety. I know Senator MacGibbon will agree with me when I say Dick Smith is perfectly correct in saying that that is a myth. That has never been the case in Australia because there are always finite limits to resources.

As Dick Smith has said quite properly, if safety were the prime consideration without any regard to cost, we would insist that all aircraft were four-engined because that is demonstrably safer than having three engines, which is demonstrably safer than having two, which is certainly demonstrably safer than having one. Instrument landing systems would be installed in every airport in Australia, we would have coast to coast radar, and the sky would be the limit. That has never been the case and never will be the case in the future.

Having said that, I simply wish to reassert that, so far as the CAA, the individual officers who staff the CAA and the Government are concerned, the primary consideration of the organisation is, and will remain, safety. However, consistent with Dick Smith's approach, we sensibly acknowledge that we should be trying to get more passengers safely into the air. Otherwise, as Dick Smith is fond of saying, the only person safe to fly will be Kerry Packer.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: FEDERAL AIRPORTS CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) why the exclusion was granted under schedule 2 of the Freedom of Information Act against the commercial determinations of the Federal Airports Corporation. It would seem to me that the public interest demands here that, in a monopoly situation, it be proper for the public to have access to information as to how the Federal Airports Corporation arrived at the charges. That is very important because the Federal Airports Corporation is a new body and operating in an entirely new field.

SPEECH.PARA: The overall concept is very simple. What the Government said to the Federal Airports Corporation was that there were a number of fields around the country that the FAC had responsibility for and that it could earn what money it could from the assets it had so that it could pay for its administration costs. That was something that had never been done before in the country. The FAC immediately went out and bought new offices, new typewriters, new word processors and new cars. The officers paid themselves very high salaries-several times what they were being paid under the old Department of Transport and Communications-and they generated a whole host of expenses. Then they had to get income from everything that it was possible to find. The first thing these people did was to increase rental on hangars.

That might sound reasonable enough, but there are people who do not think so. I declare a personal interest on this. I would not want to mislead the Parliament or the Senate on it. Something like eight years ago I was part of a group who went into partnership, formed a company and built a hangar so we could hangar our aircraft. There is a very big capital expense involved in building a hangar. Building a hangar is not like building a garage and the old Department of Civil Aviation defined the most extraordinarily stringent structural requirements.

I think in our case we had to cope with wind strengths up to either 140 or 160 miles per hour, velocities which had never been attained on the airfield on which the hangar was built. The result of that was that we had to overbuild the structure at vast cost. We assessed all of this before we went ahead and we decided, on all the information that was available, that we were prepared to undertake the financial charges which included the construction cost, the rental cost and the fact that we had a lease that ran for only 10 or 15 years; I forget what it was.

The point is that a number of people in this country have made financial commitments after exhaustive examination of the best information they could get at the time. Then along came the FAC which said, `That doesn't matter, we are just going to set our own rules here and your rental is going to go up by so much'. We have seen rises of several hundred per cent in a lot of the services that are now provided on airfields.

Not only have we had increased rentals for hangars, we have also had things like the GAIT scheme, the general aviation infrastructure tariff, which is a tax placed on aircraft using FAC fields. We have seen people who are on airfields being subjected to increased charges. I have instanced the case in the Senate before of an electronics maintenance engineer who got billed for $500 or a thousand dollars or something to have a licence to enter the airfield. He used no facilities on the airfield at all. He used to drive on in a van which held all his electronic test equipment. Most of the items of electronic equipment, radio navaids in aircraft and things like that, are easily demountable. They are in black boxes, easily removed. This man did most of the work at home, but because he provided a service and that service involved his being on the airfield for a few hours a day the Federal Airports Corporation field charged him for a licence to operate on the field.

There was the famous case in Adelaide where the FAC tried to hang a very heavy tax on taxi drivers picking up passengers at Adelaide Airport. The FAC has turned its mind to every avenue, whether practical or impractical, to raise money from the airports over which it has control. The fact that there is no precedent here-there is no established pattern of 15, 20 or 40 years of these charges being in place-reinforces the case that I am trying to make: there is a very real need in the public interest for the FAC to be able to show to the public how it arrived at those charges, that it is not standing up like a latter day bushranging operation on a stand and deliver basis.

I would have thought that, in view of all the Government's statements about accountability and the rest of it, the provision in this Bill that the decisions relating to charges be excluded from freedom of information is something that really needs some explaining.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon knows full well as an experienced senator that these organisations are not able to behave like bushrangers and not stand up to intense public and parliamentary scrutiny of their financial operations. It is a nonsense to even suggest that they can.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) will be taking a commercial approach to its charges. In a general sense and with some exceptions I think the approach that the people who use the system and get the benefit of it should pay a fair cost for that system is not an unreasonable one. Because it will operate on a commercial basis, the CAA is going to have to enter into its charging regime in a commercial way. It will also have to have access to highly sensitive commercially confidential information from its customers. For that very sensible reason it is not appropriate that that information be made readily available.

Having said that and supporting, of course, the necessity to exempt the CAA from that provision, I point out that it is not correct to suggest that these organisations as a result of this exemption are not subject to very intensive scrutiny. I know that through the avenues that are available through this Parliament Senator MacGibbon himself will no doubt give an intense scrutiny to everything both the CAA and the FAC do. Both of these organisations have to produce corporate plans which they have to make available to me. As a result of that they are then open to full parliamentary scrutiny.

The organisations are also subject to the intense scrutiny-and I must say from my own experience often very effective scrutiny-of Senate Estimates committees. Their operations will also be exposed to the full examination of the Prices Surveillance Authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has raised several points there. First, as to the scrutiny in a Senate Estimates committee, I am not aware that the FAC or the CAA now appear. Unless there is an entry in the accounts that gives them money in some way or other, we simply cannot get them before us. I would be delighted to have the opportunity to question them on their financial operations before Senate Estimates committees and I hope that they do appear. It is not beyond the bounds of possibility that if they do not appear at Senate committees I will move a motion that certain statutory authorities be required to appear before the Parliament. I am not thinking only of those two bodies. A number of statutory authorities should properly be subjected to parliamentary surveillance, but have not been. But that is a bit of a side issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to get into a debate on the user pays concept because my views on that are well known. Senator Powell has gone now, of course; if she were in the chamber a bit more and had been here a bit longer she would have realised that the user pays concept is something I have spoken at very great length on in the past. I believe that the community derives a great deal of benefit from aviation. Senator Powell picked up what I have said on numerous occasions in the chamber: the aviation industry is the only industry that is required to fund itself entirely, whereas all other forms of transport-and indeed other services like medicine, health services, and education-are very heavily subsidised. The community does derive a benefit from aviation but I will put that aside for another day.

One of the points in relation to the user pays concept is that there is no consultation between the FAC and the clients. At Archerfield airport recently there were a number of incidents which related to security. Some property was stolen. I do not know the exact details of it, but as a partner in this company that owns a hangar on the airport, I do know we were presented out of the blue with a requirement that we pay $400 a year for a security surveillance system for the airport. There was no consultation with us, as tenants, in any way at all.

The anomalous thing about it is that we have a hangar, like all the others on the field, that will withstand a 160 mile an hour wind. It is locked and bolted and it is not easy to break into. The thefts and the rest of it that took place took place from aircraft that were tied down on the field. The FAC wanted to charge us-we who had spent our own money in meeting security requirements for another reason-$400 a year each for the maintenance of security, but the people who were outside, who were the ones being subjected to the security risk, were going to pay nothing.

When we asked the FAC why it was not taxing the people on the tiedowns who need the protection it said, `Oh, it's all too hard. It's much easier to get into you because we know who you are'. I do not believe that is a responsible attitude. Maybe it is not bushranging, but it is the first thing to it. I cannot find out officially how the FAC in Brisbane arrived at the decision to charge those of us who own hangars on the place $400 a year each. That is the reason why I am asking the Minister why these organisations have this exclusion under the Freedom of Information Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I do not think there is any point in going round the track a second time. I just point out also to Senator MacGibbon, as I am sure he is well aware, that this exemption in fact applies only to the FAC and not to the CAA.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to briefly bring up a point I mentioned in my speech at the second reading stage. I refer to clause 8, which has the side note: `Negligent etc. operation of aircraft'-now to be section 20a (1) and (2). The meaning of that is very clear, but I would like the Minister to expand on how that is going to be defined in a court of law. It relates to the `reckless or negligent manner so as to endanger life' and `circumstances likely to cause danger to any person or property'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that question, I would have thought, was painfully obvious. It should have been painfully obvious to everybody. It is not a matter for me to try to second-guess whoever this might come before at some future time. The question of how this is going to be interpreted by a court of law will no doubt be a matter for whatever jurist happens to make the first determination under the Act in a court of law.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Collins) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Senator Button:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate turns now to debate the Government's amendment to the export market development grants (EMDG) scheme. This scheme provides financial support to Australia's manufacturing exports. The scheme is due to expire on 30 June 1990, only a few weeks away. This scheme has been subject to considerable review-it was reviewed in 1978 and again in 1982-by the Industries Assistance Commission; in 1985 by a committee known as the Ferris committee; in 1988 by both Price Waterhouse and the Bureau of Industry Economics; and, finally, it was reviewed by a committee chaired by Professor Helen Hughes, a review which was announced by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on 11 December 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: The so-called Hughes report is an excellent document. It deals superbly with the problems of Australian manufacturers and it identifies the urgent need for reforms to be effected not just to the EMDG scheme but to the Australian economy. That is the main purpose of the Hughes report. The problem with Australian exporters, or manufacturing exporters, is the Australian economy. I will come to that in the course of my speech. On 28 August 1989 Senator Button announced that he had received the Hughes report. I want to turn to the Minister's press release of 28 August 1989 when he said he had received the report, because he said something else which I think was very significant. Remember the date: 28 August last year. The Minister said:
The Government will consider the Committee's recommendations so as to finalise the details of the new scheme well before financial year 1990-91.
In other words, well before 30 June 1990. He went on to say:
This will give exporters ample time to plan their export market development activities for the first full year of the new scheme.
And where is the new scheme? We have not got it. There is no new scheme. What the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill does is extend the existing scheme for another six months.

Then, Madam Acting President, we had a Federal election. During the course of that Federal election Senator Button and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) called a joint press conference at which they announced the details of the new scheme. Those who can remember it can recall that it was an absolute shemozzle because the Minister got it wrong. Senator Button started to talk about the additional funds which would be provided to exporters. One of the journalists there knew a little about export market development grants schemes and asked a few questions about facts, not about the rhetoric, and Senator Button could not get the answers right.

The result was articles like this headline in the Age: `Embarrassment for PM over slip by Button'. That article was in fact written by Michelle Grattan and I understand that it was Michelle Grattan's calculator which was ultimately used to try to work out what were the additional funds, if any. Articles appeared like one in the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 March 1990:

The Prime Minister was forced to sit stony-faced as Senator Button conceded under pressure from journalists that what was originally touted as a spending initiative would actually save the Government money over the next three years.
Senator Button then offered varying estimates as to what the saving would be: $200m over five years, $90m over three years and $35m over three years.
The author of this article goes on to say:

The unedifying spectacle of the Industry Minister surrounded by television cameramen struggling desperately to come up with the correct figures took much of the gloss out of what was planned to be a key campaign initiative for the Government.

What is this grand initiative? Here we are debating the Bill-the Bill is before the chamber-and I may say, Madam Acting Deputy President, that this grand initiative is a puff of wind. In fact, some people in the chamber-not you, Madam Acting Deputy President-may be able to think of a four-letter word synonymous with a puff of wind, because that is what this Bill is.

What the Government is now saying is, `We want more time. Give us another six months'. In fact, what it originally asked for was five years; the draft Bill, which was distributed by the Minister's office, in fact extended the existing scheme for five years.

Then the Government learned that the Opposition was not going to put up with an extension for five years without further detail; we said that the most we would agree to was 12 months. I understand that the Democrats went along with that suggestion, and so the Government, because it could see that it was going to be rolled on this, said it would extend the scheme for just six months. It would look as if there was an understanding that it would bring down something in due course. Well, the Opposition looks forward to seeing that in due course. It is another promise by this Government, which has been making these miserable promises for three years, about what it will do. Throughout the election campaign Government members bamboozled the people of Australia by telling them that the Government was going to do all sorts of things. Here is the Government's first opportunity, and what was promised is not being done.

I ask the Senate: what about this promise by Senator Button and the Prime Minister during the election campaign? What about this promise to the people as the Prime Minister and Senator Button tried to big-note themselves on what they would do? Let me quote from the Minister's press release of 28 February, headed `The Export Market Development Grants Scheme extended and augmented with a new $55m discretionary scheme'. We know that they got the figures wrong, but let us see what Senator Button said. He said that the new scheme would support established exporters, and so on, and he referred to `that new scheme'. He went on:
It will encourage. It will also support. The new discretionary scheme builds on the experience of . . .

The people of Australia were in effect being told: `There is a new scheme; the Government has a new scheme. The Opposition has said that it will extend the existing scheme while it considers the report of Professor Hughes, but we of the Labor Party have a new scheme. We keep talking about it-the new discretionary scheme'. Where it it? The Minister comes in here with this Bill and says in his second reading speech, `Look, during the election campaign we came to realise that there were some problems, so give us another six months to consider these problems before we come down with the new scheme'.

Now, as I have said, that was our policy and that was what we were telling the people of Australia. We were being honest with them, while the Australian Labor Party was being dishonest. This press release referring to a new scheme is all lies. Members of the Labor Party were out there winning votes, talking about a new export market development grants scheme which did not exist. Of course, this Government has never worried about lies, never worried about misleading the people of Australia. I might say that its supporters in the press gallery have never worried about trying to drag it back where it is misleading the people of Australia.

I now turn away from political questions to the really tough question of why Australian exporting manufacturers need financial support from the taxpayers of Australia. Let me say to the Senate that it is not just the manufacturing exporters who need financial support from the taxpayers of Australia to continue to survive. Such support is needed by every Australian manufacturer in every industry which has managed to survive in this country. The Government conceded that last year when it granted Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd $36m. Senator Button came into the Parliament and told us that Kodak's industry was the only manufacturing industry left in Australia that was not getting a taxpayers' subsidy and that is why the Government was granting it $36m. Just think about that. No manufacturing industry in Australia can survive without a subsidy from the taxpayers.

In the words of the late Professor Sumner Miller, why is it so? Why is it that all Australian manufacturers need to be subsidised? We know what will happen if they do not receive a subsidy. They will fold, as so many of them have folded in recent years, and continue to fold. I was talking last night to a fellow who left this Parliament in 1983 because he lost his seat at an election and then put all of his savings into an industry. He has not only lost all of his savings; he has lost further moneys as well. He is now desperately trying to pay off the massive debts that he owes. Why is it so? Why can we not get up and running? In this country we produce great produce; we produce massive quantities of wool. But where are the industries in Australia which convert that wool into cloth? There are not any. They are all overseas. Other countries buy our wool and take it away, make it into cloth and send it back to Australia. It is imported as cloth by our few remaining clothing manufacturers. Why do we not have an industry that converts our wool into cloth? It is a very good question. We need to think about it.

Australia has a huge number of cattle. We produce enormous amounts of beef. Every day large numbers of cattle are killed. What happens to the skins? Do we turn them into beautiful leather? No, we leave that for the Italians, who are very good at it. They buy large quantities of our skins and convert them into leather. They then send the leather mostly to Hong Kong, where it is manufactured into clothing, et cetera, and then we buy the clothing and produce from Hong Kong or some other Asian country. Why is it so? Why do we not have an industry which converts all these skins into good quality leather? Why is it that our wharf labourers say that what we in Australia export is empty containers? That is our export industry. Every day they load container ships full of empty containers and send them back where they came from. Why is it so? I ask members on the Government side to address their minds to the question: why? The problem is the Australian economy. Under this Government, the Australian economy is now in a desperate situation. Under this Government the Australian dollar has had to be propped up by high interest rates because of the massive debt we have incurred overseas, and if we allow the Australian dollar to drop the debt will increase enormously. With every drop of one cent in the value of the Australian dollar there is an enormous increase in our overseas debt and in our difficulty in meeting the interest payments on that debt. So this Government continues to prop up the Australian dollar. But, of course, that destroys our exporters, who cannot sell their product on the world market with Australian dollars at this value. So our manufacturing exporters are in diabolical strife because of the Australian economy. Under this Government, where are Mr Keating's plans to do anything about it?

Look at the massive protection we give to car manufacturers. That is why we are all paying twice what we ought to be paying for our cars. Yet the industry still struggles to survive. Look at the problems in the textile industry. The textile, clothing and footwear industries receive massive protection, which is why our shoes and clothes are so expensive. Yet they still struggle to survive. Indeed, there is a Bill on the Notice Paper at present which will provide them with additional assistance to get out of the hole that they are in at present. A few shoe manufacturers have managed to survive. I can think of Rivers in Ballarat, which has only recently got going. I congratulate it. I congratulate the textile industry and the motor vehicle industry on overcoming the problems that they have had to overcome because of the problems in the economy of this country.

Pacific Dunlop Ltd has taken one of our greatest manufacturing industries offshore. I am referring to Ansell rubber goods, the producers of rubber gloves and condoms, which exports those products around the world. Last year it closed its Australian plant and took it offshore. There is nothing wrong with the Australian work force. Certainly, there is room for improvement in our skill training, but fundamentally there is nothing wrong with the Australian work force. They are intelligent, able people. There is nothing wrong with Australian entrepreneurship. Some Australians have been the greatest con men ever, and that is a form of entrepreneurship. Apart from that sort of criminal activity, among the ordinary manufacturers and industry entrepreneurs in this country there are great skills, great ideas and great ambitions, but they are absolutely hamstrung, destroyed and broken down by the penalties which this Government has imposed on them.

I have mentioned the major problem, the so-called macro-economic problems-high interest rates, high inflation, which are being created deliberately. Mr Keating is squeezing demand in the economy. Let me refer to an article by Mr Paddy McGuinness in the Weekend Australian of 5 May, which is last weekend. The headline is, `Wanted urgently: a new job for a tired Treasurer'. The article draws attention to the fact that Mr Keating refuses to face up to the fact that his policies have failed miserably. Because of the compliance of the press gallery he is able to get away with it. Members of the press gallery love him because he makes smart alec remarks and clever, vitriolic speeches. They can write a story about him without having to go into depth as to what he is really saying. They can write a surface story about how he has abused some person. Because of that they love him and they allow him to get away with the things he has been doing in this country for the last three or four years. Paddy McGuiness wrote:
He deserves some recognition-perhaps the embassy in Washington, Tokyo or Paris. But as far as Australian economic policy is concerned he deserves only one message-for God's sake, go!
Senator Walsh, of course, is trying desperately to draw attention to these matters in his Cassandra articles in the Australian Financial Review.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very responsible.

—Very responsible, and he is behaving in the way that parliamentarians ought to behave, except that he ought to be making these speeches in the Parliament rather than writing them in newspaper articles. Nevertheless, he is doing something to try to bring this Government into line with what it ought to be doing.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the Ministers know what the Government ought to be doing. Senator Button has repeatedly made speeches in this chamber in which he has drawn attention to the problems being created by his own Government. I get angry with him. I keep saying that he is number three in the Government. He cannot get any higher than that while he remains a senator, yet he is not able to bring the Prime Minister and Mr Keating into line.

This country has other problems for manufacturers. We want to maintain high living standards and higher wages for our work force, decent holidays and a good environment. But as well as those things-and we ought to accept that they are part of what we want for the Australian work force and the Australian nation-we impose other burdens on our manufacturers. We are not satisfied with asking them to provide these things which are worth while. We impose additional taxes, such as the fringe benefits tax. We impose high company tax rates. In addition we also have a complicated tax regime. A lot of manufacturers, instead of employing people to manufacture products, frequently have to employ one or two accountants a year just to maintain the records that are needed for tax purposes and other government requirements, both State and Federal. There is complicated regulation of industry, complicated company laws and complicated and heavy taxes.

On top of that, we have the infamous accord which in many ways prevents them from trying to negotiate productivity increases with their work force. It is very interesting that within the last week Mr Keating has described the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) as a fool. Mr Langmore claims to be the originator of the idea of an accord. He was pushing it when he worked for the then shadow Treasurer, Mr Willis, when the Labor Party was in opposition. I wish Mr Keating had recognised earlier that John Langmore was a fool and had decided that the idea was foolish, because we have been telling the Government ever since 1983 that the accord is absolutely crazy. It is holding down the salaries of people who ought to be getting more, while paying more to people who ought to be getting less. There is not the slightest doubt that it is creating problems in increasing productivity in manufacturing industries in Australia.

Finally, let me turn to the Hughes report. As I said earlier, this report sets out what are the problems of this country. I will quote some parts of it. I know that it is a bit of a bore for people to listen to this sort of stuff. Quite frankly, I would like to incorporate the whole report in Hansard, but I will not do so. The report states:
Incentives--
and this Bill that we are talking about is an incentive-
which assist exporters to overcome the initial difficulties of entering foreign markets can play only a limited role in stimulating export growth. The economic policy environment swamps their effect.

What is being said is that these incentives are all right, but the overall economic policy environment swamps their effect. That is what I have been saying. One can give companies this subsidy, but until one gets the economic environment right, the subsidy will just manage to keep them alive. The report goes on to say.

However, because it will take time to improve economic policies even if new policy changes are initiated and ongoing reforms are accelerated, incentives to exporters can be used in the interim to increase the involvement of small and medium sized business in exports.
