That explains why the report says, `Look, we'll have to keep this scheme going in some regard'. The report recommends some variations to the scheme, but the explanation for the recommendation that there be a scheme-and we on our side of politics have accepted that there has to be a scheme-is the economic policy environment in which manufacturers find themselves in Australia today. The report goes on:
It is less well understood that our lagging economic performance is closely linked to our poor export growth.
Despite recent growth of tourism, service exports lag even further behind other industrial countries.

Of course, this report was written before the pilots strike, which the Prime Minister pushed so hard and which in effect has destroyed our tourist industry. I go on and quote from another part of the report:
Past reviews of Australian export incentives concluded . . . that the effect of macro and microeconomic policies far outweigh the influence of specific subsidies and incentives to export.
That is exactly what I have been saying to the Senate. The report continues:

Macroeconomic policies are by far the most important determinants of exports. The rate of exchange dominates the profitability of exports but, except in the short run, the rate of exchange is largely the outcome of all of a country's principal policies-fiscal, monetary, trade and income-and how they mesh together.

That is what I have been saying. This Government has not got it right and has not had it right for four years. Senator Walsh is saying that. Sensible economic writers-not this press gallery that we have got up here-like Paddy McGuinness have been drawing attention to it. Until we get it right, the environmentalists will not be able to achieve what they want. Until we get it right, living standards of all Australians will fall and continue to fall. I will not make a prediction about what will happen to the Australian dollar because I am worried about these sorts of predictions by politicians becoming what in effect happens as a result of what they have said. It is certainly very worrying.

The Opposition will support the extension of this scheme, but we say to this Government, `You lied to the people of Australia, you did not have a new scheme, and we wait to see what scheme you will produce to this Parliament before 31 December of this year'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill is a one-clause Bill. Having listened to Senator Lewis for the last half hour, I think he is trying to load an enormous amount in a very light vehicle indeed, and I suggest to him that it collapses under the weight. One rather interesting thing he did say was that the Italians were going to buy his skin. Might I, with some good humour, suggest the sooner the better, and particularly if the Italians then sell it on to the people in Hong Kong to be turned into clothing. It might be more useful than what we have just been listening to.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that this Bill is really a temporary extension of provisions already in place and is simply required to extend the provisions of the export market development grants scheme until the substantive Bill is brought in during the Budget session. We will be addressing our substantive remarks in relation to that scheme at that time. It is for that reason that we will be supporting the Bill and not supporting the amendments. The amendment that has been proposed by Senator Harradine is, indeed, an inappropriate place-leaving aside any merit that that amendment might have-in which to place a constraint in the operation of this Bill.

Indeed, addressing the substance of the scheme itself, we have a large number of objections to a whole range of assumptions and processes which are built into the operation of this scheme. For instance, implicit in the scheme itself is the notion that trade is an end in itself and is desirable for its own sake. The Australian Democrats would clearly take the view that trade is something in which one engages to provide those goods and services which one cannot manufacture oneself, and it should be a small part of overall economic activity in a sustainable economy which tends increasingly towards self-sufficiency rather than locking us into more and more precarious relationships with other nations.

Indeed, one need only look at the recent occurrences in relation to Australia's trade to observe the necessary failure-the failure which is implicit-in coming to depend more and more on trade relationships. We have been exporting live sheep to the Middle East for quite some time, and for a whole range of reasons, many of them completely spurious, sheep have arrived in the Middle East and have been unable to be unloaded. They have been kept in quite unsuitable conditions which have been, quite rightly, objected to by many of the animal rights lobbyists while arguments went on as to whether they did or did not have scabby mouth, were or were not old animals and so on and so forth. It seems to me fairly obvious that if one builds an economy which is increasingly dependent on exports for its health, then of course one lays oneself open to the arbitrary operation of other countries and the vicissitudes and changes which occur in the economies of those other countries.

One can point also to the recent failure of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to honour the payment of $100m for wool exports. Again, to the extent that we lock ourselves necessarily into trade, we make ourselves more precariously dependent on those trade conditions and circumstances and render our economy far more precarious and less manageable. Indeed, if I were to make a prediction, I would point to the fact that Egypt is one of our major importers of wheat, yet Egypt is also one of the most heavily indebted countries in the world. It can only continue to pay for Australian wheat as long as the international banking organisations, the International Monetary Fund and so on are prepared to support Egypt's adverse balance of payments. I predict that it will not be many years down the track before Egypt will not be able to buy or pay for Australian wheat, and to the extent to which we have built an Australian economy dependent upon that export, we will have made our economy more unstable, more precarious and certainly less manageable by the elected government of this country.

Implicit in the program of self-sufficiency which I have suggested is that, rather than export enhancement, we should be going more for import replacement. I recognise that the Government has also been pursuing that goal. We would strongly support that goal, and to that end we would support some of the remarks of Senator Lewis in relation to much of Australia's primary product which is currently exported unprocessed, processed overseas and then imported back into this country. It is clear to us that a great deal of value adding should be occurring and that that would lead in many cases to import substitution.

I also make the point that really it is only the value added which occurs when one processes resources of a non-renewable kind, such as our mineral resources. It is only as we value-add to those resources that we really get any wealth at all. I have made the point in this place before that, if we kept proper national capital accounts, the value of those resources in situ would appear in a national capital account. When we exploit those things and export them unprocessed we observe that there is no increase in the wealth of the country whatsoever and that the increase in the wealth of the country occurs only as we value-add, in other words, as we process those resources into finished products. To that extent the value adding part of any overall economic management program should place emphasis on import substitution and value adding.

Of course, one fears that this is not the way the Government is going, and the extension of this export market development grants scheme until the Budget time is presaged on a number of other reports which the Government has. We have not yet in this place discussed the Garnaut report, Australia and the Northeast Asian Ascendancy, a report which looks at supposed very optimistic developments in north-east Asia and which suggests that Australia will successfully be able to lock into those growing markets with exports to the benefit of Australia.

I observe in passing that the Garnaut report was some 330 pages long but contained only 6 3/4 lines which dealt with the environment, and those only to the extent of saying that the Australian environment was a very pleasant one in which to be and asking how we could exploit that environment for the purposes of tourism. Garnaut recognised not a single environmental constraint to the growth and development of the north Asian markets in the future. There were no considerations of the problems of greenhouse, stratospheric ozone depletion, resource depletion or acid rain. They were not recognised as constraints in that economic model.

The Democrats are extremely worried about the way in which the Government is basing its economic policy, of which this is simply a part. The Opposition is proceeding essentially along the same path. We believe this economic model is out of date, dangerous and simply will not succeed.

Indeed, a moment ago we heard Senator Lewis indicate that he was quite ignorant of the fundamental fact that growth in the economy and environmental protection are inconsistent. He reiterated what others in this chamber have said, that one needs a growing economy in order to pay for environmental protection. He does not seem to recognise the fundamental economic reality that what is spent on environmental protection goes down as an addition to the gross national product and therefore what we spend on environmental protection is itself a direct cause of economic growth as currently measured.

He also went on to indicate that he thought that Mr Keating's economic policies had failed. I would observe, as an extension of what I have just said, that had the Opposition been in Government it would essentially have been pursuing the same economic model and, to the extent that it would have been possibly even less efficient in pursuing that model, would have brought us to the same position of failure even more quickly.

One other thing is important to pick up, for the reason that it was an issue very much in the Murray Valley and other parts of Australia during this recent election. Senator Lewis said that it was appropriate that we put into place in Australia proper environmental and worker health controls. Of course, we would agree absolutely with that statement. But then he seems to support the Government in progressively deregulating and removing tariffs and various other protective measures, which essentially means that we import from other countries products which are manufactured under conditions which do not provide the same standards of environmental and occupational health protection.

For a long time it has seemed to me and to other Australian Democrats that it is totally unfair on the Australian environment and Australian workers to expect workers to lose their jobs because we have quite rightly imposed proper standards of protection here when we then allow imports from countries where the same standards are not applied. It would therefore follow that we would support the application of tariffs which were not arbitrarily applied but were modelled on the real costs of the imposition of those environmental and occupational health protection measures. We believe that under such a system Australian industry is well able to compete and produce quality products.

As I indicated at the beginning, this is a very brief Bill. There is really only one clause. We do not believe it is an appropriate vehicle to cause to carry any amendments whatsoever, and for that reason when the substantive Bill comes back in August we will comment further on the sorts of amendments we would like to see.

We have considerable concern over a number of exports. We have expressed concern in the past over the export of uranium and of arms. Government policy appears to be at least partly dependent upon the build-up of sales of arms overseas. We object to those things and consider them far more significant than the sorts of amendments that Senator Harradine has suggested. But we think it more appropriate to debate those sorts of issues in relation to the export market development grants scheme when we have the substantive Bill before us, and not at this stage. Therefore, we will be supporting this Bill without amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating what was supposed to be the introduction of a new, exciting and wonderful scheme to enhance exports, the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1990. That is what the Government told us during the election campaign. Yet here we have a Bill which says, `Please give us more time. We need a temporary respite'. The temporary respite, according to the draft of the original explanatory memorandum, was not to ask for the six months that this Bill is asking for but to ask for five years. The original intention was to extend the operation of the existing Export Market Development Grants Act from 30 June 1990 to 30 June 1995. The explanatory memorandum says:

SPEECH.PARA: This is an interim measure to preserve the continuity of the Act pending the enactment of the Government's amendments to that Act jointly announced by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, on 28 February 1990.

That refers to the farcical press conference that we all remember. Normally we would have been expecting to read about it on page 1 of the newspapers but, funny thing, it got buried down there on pages 5 and 7. The whole attitude to this question is indicative of the failure of the Government to formulate policies which will insist that industry be more productive and be able to export, and will enable Australia to trade its way out of the huge debt which has been accumulated under this Government.

The record of the Government concerning export incentives is indeed a record of inaction and uncertainty. Let us have a look at the last five years. In five years we have had five reviews. In 1985 we had the report of the national export marketing strategy panel and in 1987 the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which dealt with the submissions from Austrade following an audit report. In 1988 there was the Bureau of Industry Economics report, then a Price Waterhouse report commissioned by Austrade, and finally the report of the Committee for Review of Export Market Development Assistance, the Hughes Committee report. The Government has had the Hughes Committee report for nine months but the amendments are still not drafted and ready to be presented.

The Government is providing for institutionalised uncertainty because the amendments, when they are finally to be introduced, are to be retrospective to July, being the date announced at that press conference on 28 February. Industry requires, most of all, consistency and predictability in Government policy. Without a clear knowledge of what assistance they can expect, firms are unable to take up the full advantage of assistance which is available in developing export strategies. Professor Hughes noted that continual change to the export market developments grants scheme has caused confusion and indecision, and frequent changes have created an advisory industry which appropriates a share of the EMDG benefits.

To look further at the history of the Government in this area, prior to the 1987 federal election the Government led industry to believe that there would be no tampering with the scheme. In June 1987, the then Minister for Trade, John Dawkins, said:

I have written to all recipients of EMDGs-that is, the export market development grant scheme- assuring them that the Hawke Government regards the scheme as an integral of Australia's export effort . . . I have also assured them that we will not undermine that effort by chipping away at the spearhead of Australia's export drive, Austrade.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) also gave an assurance during the 1987 election that Austrade funding and the EMDG scheme would remain intact. In the following May statement of 1988 changes were announced to the scheme. In the EMDG Amendment Bill of 1988 exports to New Zealand were excluded, an increase was made to the eligible expenditure threshold from 5,000 to 10,000 a year, the maximum grant payable was reduced to $150,000 and to $100,000 for those in receipt of their tenth or subsequent grants and it was decided to treat the affiliated companies as one unit in the assessment of grants.

In Estimates committee hearings we found that little research had been carried out on the likely effect to exporters from the changes that were made. No answers could be provided to the question of what percentage of grantees would be likely to be first year applicants nor to the fundamental question of how many applicants would be exporters without the existence of the scheme. The Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) criticises the scheme and says it has failed to bring about the establishment of new products and the continued penetration into new markets. The report said:

Encouragement of new products is not achieved very well by the scheme. The data suggests that the development of new products appears, on average, to be minimal after claimants have been in the scheme longer than one year.

New markets were generally entered by firms in the early years of the scheme but from the second year to the eighth year only one new market per year per claimant was developed while beyond the eighth year new market development declined markedly. The BIE concluded that assistance was being provided to established exporters who were not developing new markets and to exporters not adequately committed to success in exporting.

Professor Hughes, in the same vein, said that the stalling of export development after eight years in the scheme was apparent. Over 60 per cent of all firms that have claimed more than seven times did not enter a new market in 1987-88 and beyond the second year only 12 per cent of claimants promoted a new product in 1987-88, according to the Committee's findings. Professor Hughes further said that after the tenth year the average export earnings of claimants actually fell and that the ratio of exports to claims also declined beyond the eighth year in the scheme and also beyond the eighth year firms' proportion of turnover exported declines. Clearly inducement should be provided to initiate new exports and markets rather than rewarding those already established.

The same report said that there was little correlation between market development expenditure and the level of export earnings. For instance, the more isolated markets of Africa, the Middle East and Latin America showed the highest ratios of export income to promotional expenditure while those markets accounting for the majority of promotional expenditure, such as North America, Europe and members of the Association of South East Asian Nations, had among the lowest ratios.

Could it be said that the real reason is the poor administration of the scheme, with cost overruns which result in people being not paid in due time? In March 1988 the Government found eligible grants had been underestimated by $64m. For weeks payments to genuine exporters were suspended. The cost of the scheme tends to increase every year due to the open access nature of the scheme. Funds budgeted by Austrade have been considerably below estimates of the next years costs which have resulted in delays of the payments to some firms and supplementary payments have had to be sought to match the funding of the amount for the eligible claims.

The cost of the scheme to be administered seems high. The cost of servicing each grantee has been approximated at $500. There are high levels of unprocessed claims at the end of the financial year and the carry over value of claims of $38m at 1 July 1989 was up from $20m from the 1 July 1988 date. Professor Hughes' conclusion was that there was no rigorous causal impact of EMDG payments on export growth. Most of the firms would have been successful without the scheme.

The recommendations from the Hughes report were that exporters should only be eligible for a maximum of eight incentive payments, that the minimum expenditure threshold should be increased from $10,000 to $50,000, that the maximum rate should be increased to $250,000 and the cut rate should rise to $25m, and that the rate should be reduced from 70 per cent to 50 per cent of eligible expenditure.

What has been the Government's response to those recommendations that have been made? The Government's immediate response is to come here and ask for a six months extension of the existing Bill, having originally intended, according to the draft of their original memorandum, to ask for five years, and leave a system of uncertainty with industry not knowing exactly what might be brought in in six months time. The spectacle of Minister Button during the campaign, huddled with a group of journalists and television cameras, struggling to do his figures on the back of an envelope, only added to the uncertainty. The position that was finally brought to us by way of the media was altered no less than four times. No wonder the Government is on the nose with industry.

A survey of exporters' perceptions of the Labor Party before the election found that 80 per cent of respondents rated the Governments policies as either poor or average. The Government's overall policies have resulted in high inflation, which has undermined exporters' capacity to plan and produce for the export market. Tight monetary policy has driven up interest rates in an attempt to slow domestic demand and, of course, has impacted on exporters. Further reductions in protection, including tariff and non-tariff barriers, would make substantial contributions to the competitiveness of the Australian exporters. High costs of coastal shipping, on the wharves and railways, and the high costs of power and other utilities were supposed to be dealt with in the last term of the Labor Government. At the beginning of its 1987 period it said that that was to be the term of micro-economic reform, and it simply did not happen.

So what we have before us today is a plea from the Government saying, `We told you, the electorate, before the election that we had a brand new policy which would be introduced and which would assist manufacturers and exporters generally in reducing Australia's accumulated debt.'. What we get is a one page mea culpa saying, `Please, we are not ready. We have read it down and ask for six months' time to give us breathing space because we knew that the community would not wear five years'.

As Senator Lewis has already said, we will be supporting the Bill but we point out to the Australian electorate that they were fooled during that election period. We are not seeing this new `you beaut' scheme; what we are simply seeing is a plea, `Please give us more time to try to get it right and present you with something which will not be an affront.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to speak to the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1990. Speaking about the export market development grants situation is no new experience. I have spoken about it many times. Each time we seem to have an inquiry or each time we seem to want to fiddle about with it, around the edges, we have one of these debates. I want to speak about it because of the great concern over the appalling lack of understanding and the mishandling that has long been part of the export encouragement program of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought that the Hughes report, the report of the Committee for Review of Export Market Development Assistance, was a very valuable document. It was valuable inasmuch as it raised all the issues. I was disappointed that in the end it came back and reflected the Government position. It certainly did not reflect the position of the exporters and the potential exporters.

It has already been said-and I do need to say it as well-that we are tinkering with the figures and tinkering with the fringes instead of getting the main game right. The economy of Australia is in one terrible mess. There should be no need for a scheme of any sort. If we had the main game right we would not need tariffs, we would not need bounties and we would not need these inducement schemes. They are all expensive to run; they are all expensive to claim. The whole thing is so much out of kilter at present and we are trying to patch it up by these stop-gap methods.

We have this ridiculous dollar value which is an enormous handicap on business generally. We have a level of interest rates higher than that of any of the people that we deal with competitively around the world. We have an inflation rate that is driving people crazy here and damaging business enormously compared with the other countries that we deal with as competitors. None of those things is being attended to. The great whiz-kid of the Government on these matters just says, `I have lovely figures'. Well, if they are lovely figures I do not know what they would be if they were terrible. But none of these are being attended to and this scheme, whatever it turns out to be, will not fix them either. We can wreck Australia's exporters if we really go about it this way. We only have to look at recent headlines in the paper. The Age of 4 May, which I have here, has the headline, `Imports boom, economy busts'. The article states:
A disappointing slump in manufacturing exports, which have ended their promising surge of late 1989 and retreated to their lowest quarterly level for a year.

The results shocked the market. And so on. So it ought to shock the market, but it does not shock the Government. The Government just goes on and ignores that. Then we have the sort of problems that the exporters have. I picked up an article from the Daily Commercial News of 8 May which was headed `Give exporters Fair Go, Govt Told'. It went on to tell of the ridiculous applications that are being made of various aspects of the Tax Act.

We have to make up our mind about what sort of a country we are trying to develop. Do we want to be a banana republic? I think the answer is `yes' at the moment, but I do not think that the people out there see it that way. Do we want to be a manufacturing or a producing country? Do we want to be self-supporting? Do we want to see ourselves just build up huge debt-debt on debt on debt-so that we cannot even pay the interest on it? Do we want to be like my colleague from the Australian Democrats who says, `We do not want to be a trading country'. Is that the way we want this country to head? What are we going to do?

I think Austrade under Lindsay MacAlister has done everything it possibly can. I think it deserves great credit for having struggled and struggled to try to encourage people to go into the exporting business, to try to get Australia off the hook a bit, to try to reduce our overseas deficit to some extent; but every time it finds a new customer, every time it finds a new potential dealer, the Government changes something and out they go. People I have come across in industry and in business have said to me, `Look, we tried it; it was all too difficult. By the time we filled in all the forms and saw all the people and put in all the returns it cost us more than we were likely to get back'.

We are an insular nation, one that clearly should be amongst the world's great maritime countries. But are we? No, we are a joke. I find that sea and air transport is much the same as well. This reminds me that a few weeks ago I saw headlines in my local paper at home that was congratulating a lady who had secured a market for selling proteas in Tokyo. For a small grower, that was a great achievement. I thought the next day that I would ring her up and congratulate her, and I did. After I had spoken for about half a minute, I suppose, she said, `There is something I should tell you'. I said, `What is that?'. She said, `The proteas never got there; they lost them between Burnie and Melbourne'. Not only did she lose the proteas; she also lost the customer.

How can we hope to be a trading nation when we cannot even start the things off right on our own doorstep? Where are we going to deal? People expect us to behave ourselves and behave in a reasonably professional way. Look at the effects of the airline problems on the Tasmanian exporters. I think it is worth reading a small piece about a gentleman who is well-known to the Minister. This article states:
The Minister for Roads and Transport, Mr Wriedt, yesterday accused the Hawke Government of hypocrisy and of inflicting unnecessary hardship on Tasmania by prolonging the national pilots' dispute.
Mr Wriedt said in a scathing attack on the Government that he would neither forget nor forgive it for the role it played in depriving Tasmania of millions of dollars in tourist revenue last year.
`I believe it was a shameful exercise' . . .

And so on. That is the sort of thing that is going on all the time. Why the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Federal Government had to take the sides they did, why they strung it out as long as they did to the total detriment of the people that they are supposed to be serving, I will never understand, and neither will all these others. All those delays totally ruined many producers and exporters, and even the interstate ones as well. If one is trying to run a business that is involved in things like fresh cheeses, broccoli, cut flowers, crayfish and oysters, one just has to have regular, reliable and dependable service, and this is what Ken Wriedt was talking about in the Tasmanian Parliament.

Reference has been made already to the Government's attitude and understanding. The people out there have absolutely no confidence left as to what the Government might do about export markets development. How could one try and plan a business with the record that this Government has on this very subject? The classic blunders that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) made during the recent election campaign shows the level of importance that he places on exporting and how well he sees and understands what it is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not as many as you made. We are still here.

—The fact that after months and months since the tabling of the Hughes report the Government clearly still has no idea of what it is doing is now apparent to everybody. The fact that it wanted another five years of interim time to work on it I think is another matter to shatter anybody's confidence in what it intends to do.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Minister; I just happen to have a document which shows that you applied, on an interim basis, for an extension of this Act from 1990 to 1995. That is five years.
—The scheme will be extended for five years. That is quite clear.
—When?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am enjoying the conversation with the Minister but I would rather that he have his say at the end, if that is all right with him. Now that the Minister has raised the matter, I would like him to explain, as an interim measure, why five years was the date that was placed originally. Also, is that an extension of the scheme? Or is it the brand new whiz-bang scheme that was talked about two or three months ago? Is it an interim scheme, or is it a new scheme? Was it for five years, or was it not for five years?

SPEECH.PARA: Everybody apparently is going back to the drawing board. What concerns me, and what concerns a lot of people out there, is that if they do not look out they are going to find that there is going to be yet another inquiry while we put it off a bit longer. How can manufacturers and producers plan anything out of this total confusion that the Minister has just demonstrated that he is still in?

One thing is clear, however, and that is that a scheme is essential. It must be simple. It must encourage triers and appropriately reward them for their efforts and it cannot just be a sop for the big people. It must give potential exporters a feeling that getting into the big league could help them and could be in the national interest. At present everything in Australia is being run for the importers. Every time we wipe out another industry we import the value of those goods, and every time we import them we stick it on the slate and the cost just gets bigger and bigger and bigger.

As a result of government policy we have lost dozens of whole industries and we have severely damaged and weakened many of the other smaller ones as well, and they are still getting less. Up goes our foreign debt. Is this what we want? What are we doing about it? How long does this Government think that we can allow things to go on getting worse and worse and still do nothing about it? If we are to be competitive we must compete in a manner similar to those of the other countries with which we are dealing. It is as simple as that. I have a list of various countries and schemes here about which I have spoken to the Whip. I want to incorporate them. They list the main items that go with these sorts of schemes in other places.

Do we want to compete on the world markets, or do we not? If we are going to have a scheme it must be good enough to give confidence to our exporters so that they can start to wind back this appalling international debt that the Government has endowed on our children and grandchildren. Although this is only a one-line Bill that the Government may have thought could be just nodded through, I think it is important that I speak on it. The Government has no idea of what it is going to do so at least it might listen to us and then pick up something that it can use.

It all starts off with the fact that our currency value, still pumped up, is miles out of line with what it is truly worth. We have only to look at this trade-weighted index to see how far out of line we are with our current actual money value. Our interest rates, to pump up this dollar, are murdering our primary and secondary industries-absolutely murdering them. The social costs of the things that have already been referred to are borne by the productive sector. The benefits go to everybody else but they are paid for by the productive sector, particularly the exporters. It puts them totally out of kilter with the other countries of the world with which they are competing. Our inflation makes us unreliable in the marketplace. Our industrial relations and transport reputation around the world is woeful.

The Treasurer, Mr Keating, talks about his lovely figures. I think it is time we looked at a few more of these lovely figures to make some true comparisons. On the hourly cost for production workers, with Australia in an index of 100 as at 1988, it is worth remembering that amongst the countries of this area and around the world that we compete with the figure for New Zealand was 65, Taiwan 24, Singapore 24, Korea 23 and Hong Kong 22. And then we talk about inflation rates. Australia is currently running at 8.6 per cent, Japan 1.1, West Germany 1.2, USA 3.5, United Kingdom 4.7. Then we talk about labour productivity. Of the more industrialised countries, Australia produces $24,100 per employee per annum against the USA which produces $35,500, Belgium $27,400, and Japan $25,200. As for the real growth of labour productivity, the figure for Australia between 1967 and 1986 rose 2.6 per cent. The figure for Japan was 5.9 per cent; Canada was 4.4 per cent; and Germany 3.6 per cent.

Are these lovely figures? I think they are absolutely disgraceful. We have been told all about restructuring and all sorts of things like that, and where has it got us? This restructuring still has not lifted us out of the ruck and got us to where we can be a profitable and meaningful country in the trading world. Think of the bankruptcies, this huge splurge of bankruptcies. Both large and small people are going to the wall as a result of not being able to compete. Think of this huge influx of consumer goods. Senator Walsh has put a lie to the old story about this all being great new manufacturing plant. It is not, it is consumer goods: it is food, it is clothing, it is furniture, it is electrical goods. It is all these sort of things. These things are coming in here and wiping out our industries and blowing up our debt. We just have to face this.

Not only are we going up in debt, not only are we not competing on an international scale; there are tens of thousands of people who are going to lose their jobs. Does that worry anybody? Is the Treasurer concerned? I have seen the Treasurer a bit lately and I have not seen him looking as if he is terribly worried about other people's predicaments. What is going to be the result of all this?

Mr Acting Deputy President, I have two tables that I have shown to the Whip, as well, which I would also like to incorporate in Hansard along with the one on the selected schemes. I seek leave to incorporate those now.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows:
KEY FEATURES OF SELECTED OVERSEAS SCHEMES
New Zealand
New Zealand's current scheme is the Export Market Development Taxation Incentive (EMDTI), which
provides for rebate/refund against tax, as a percentage of qualifying expenditure (53-64%).

qualifying expenditure includes: travel, salaries and wages, payments to agents, expenses incurred overseas, and expenses incurred in New Zealand to bring in overseas buyers, preparation of tenders or quotations, sales promotions, exhibition costs, etc.
EMDTI is to be phased out by 31 March 1990. It will be replaced by the Individual Exporters' Programme (IEP).
IEP provides funds of $NZ10 million.
funding is for two years and covers export survey costs, costs of hiring an export manager and promotion costs.
Canada

Canada provides a Programme for Export Market Development (PEMD). It is a shared-cost Programme designed to cover up to 50 per cent of approved expenses incurred on an export project. Repayment of PEMD contributions are required if a sale results from the marketing effort. It covers the following specific areas:
specific project bidding
market identification
participation in trade fairs
export consortia
establishment of permanent sales offices abroad
PEMD-FOOD: export markets for agriculture, fisheries and food products.
General Guidelines for the Programme are:
any business operating in Canada is eligible for assistance
products or services promoted under the scheme must have significant Canadian content
PEMD assistance is usually limited to $500,000 per year per company or group of related companies.
Japan
The only direct incentives available to Japanese exports are the `trade insurance' facilities (equivalent of EPC) administered through MITI.
Italy

Italian export incentives take the form of special purpose grants, rather than concessions of the EMDGS type. Financial assistance Programme is drawn up each year by the Italian Ministry of Foreign Trade. The Programme is drawn up in line with the following objectives:
Priority to specialisation in medium to high technology products with high `value added' content
maintenance of support to exports of `traditional' products
Priority to promotional investments with the highest profitability in the short to medium term
Co-ordination of specific promotional drives in order to avoid activities not forming part of specific priorities.

Some examples of assistance provided are: International Fairs Office in Paris; specific grants to trade-oriented bodies; contribution to Chambers of Commerce abroad; contributions to fairs and exhibitions abroad; grants to exporting consortia.
Singapore
Singapore operates the Market Development Assistance Scheme (MDAS), which is a cash grant scheme aimed at defraying initial costs of companies' export development activities.
the scheme is discretionary in that grants will not be given unless the company has sound managerial and financial capabilities with positive net worth and working capital.
grants are given in respect of: setting up overseas offices; improving product/services; and developing new markets.
assistance is given on a project basis, via a cost-sharing arrangement, and for one or two years only.
maximum assistance per project is $250,000.
large firms setting up overseas offices and applying for MDAS are expected to involve small companies as a means of helping these small companies.
Singapore also operates Export Expansion Schemes, which include:
double tax deductions for trade fairs/missions, overseas trade offices, overseas market development and promotional publications.
companies seek approval prior to obtaining the tax benefit.
International trading Company Scheme.
There are a number of other tax-based incentives that Singapore provides which are based on profits earned from exporting activity (e.g. the Export of Services Incentives)
Hong Kong
Hong Kong does not operate any market entry or development scheme.
however the Hong Kong Trade Development Council operates overseas trade shows and exhibitions.
United States
The United States operates the following major export assistance schemes:
the Export-Import Bank, which provides credits and guarantees insurance to US exporters. These are frequently subsidised.
the Export Enhancement Programme (General) which provides $1.5 billion for subsidies to US agricultural exports.
a variety of smaller agricultural export assistance programmes, such as the Dairy Export Incentive Programme.
Korea
The Republic of Korea operates the Export Financing Programme:
the Programme provides credit to promote exports of goods and services.

the Programmer is operated by the individual commercial banks at their own discretion, and has no direct connection with the Government's budget although the scheme is authorised and promulgated under the direction of the Bank of Korea.

the Export Financing Programme provides three types of financial facilities: loans for general export and import; loans for export of construction and services; and loans for preparing exports of agricultural and marine products.
India
The Government of India does not maintain any export assistance Programme which is inconsistent with the main GATT provisions. The main Programmes which are operated are:
Cash Compensatory Support (CCS), which is designed basically to reimburse unrefunded indirect taxes on imports used in export production.

the Government of India allows various deductions in the computation of taxable profits including the deduction of 4 per cent of net foreign exchange realisation and up to 50 per cent of export profits

Market Development Assistance (MDA) which is a multi grant rate scheme to cover inter alia sponsoring/inviting trade delegations to India from abroad, market studies, publicity, the setting up of warehouses/showrooms, research and development and quality control-MDA is mainly directed towards group promotions through trade associations, but also covers individual promotions.
Brazil
Brazil operates the following main export inventive schemes:
Working Capital Financing for Exports, which is a discretionary grant somewhat like EMDGS, giving a loan based on an adjusted fob value of exports or estimated exports
Financing for Trading Companies, in which the Government guarantees payment of financial fees up to 15% per annum
Financing for Storing of Goods, providing for the storage of goods for export under concessional conditions in special bonded warehouses
tax rebates are also available on profits earnt from exporting.
Finland
The Finnish Ministry of Trade and Industry promotes export activity by granting support for export marketing activities, particularly for small and medium sized enterprises.
grants and loans are paid to exporters. Grants are a maximum 50% and loans 75% of total expenditure
grants are provided for marketing of export products, for participation in foreign trade fairs and exhibitions and for export campaigns
guarantees are provided for small and medium size firms

export credits are financed by the Finnish Export Credit Ltd. which is jointly owned by the Finnish Government, major banks and some industrial companies. FEC provides finance for medium- and long-term export credits and pre-delivery costs.
Sweden
The Swedish Government operates a range of subsidies, mainly through the semi-State-owned Swedish Trade Council, whose services are available only to subscribing companies. The main subsidies are:
general subsidisation of the operations of the Swedish Trade Council which provides consulting services and grants of up to 40% of costs of market research, trade fairs and market information
medium and long-term export credits for capital goods can be refinanced by the Swedish Export Corporation, which is jointly owned by the Government and the Banks
Norway
Norway provides a direct subsidy for export promotion
details are not available.
Yugoslavia
Yugoslavia supports exports with the following measures:
drawback of a portion of freight charges for exports
a special incentive for agricultural exports
drawback of customs and other import charges
the Yugoslav Bank may grant export credits to successful exporters of a variety of goods and services.
Turkey
Turkey employs the following measures:
Export rediscount credits, granted to exporters achieving at least $5 million in exports in the previous three years.
a price support and stabilisation fund, consisting of payments designed to improve the competitiveness of selected goods
a tax rebate for successful exporters
a corporate tax exemption on certain products (20% of export earnings non-taxable)
Belgium
There are two types of assistance provided to exporters:
Fonds de Commerce Exterieur relates to new market exploration and development
Comprex is an interest bonus/credit system relating to certain types of equipment sales.
Fonds du Commerce Exterieur only provides assistance for new markets, which are defined as markets where sales do not exceed 6% of total exports.
aid offered is 50% of cost of eligible activity or 25% of cost if Belgian share of product/services is less than 50%
eligible expenditure includes EMDG type expenditure (plus accommodation costs)
excluded in export promotion to EEC countries.
Philippines
The Philippines' previous export incentives Programme was phased out on 1 January 1987. The Philippines no longer maintains an export incentive Programme.
France

France has two export market development schemes: ``Assurance Prospection'' or Market Development Insurance; and ``Assurance Foire'', or Exhibition Insurance, both operated by the Government owned Compagnie Francaise d'Assurance pour le Commerce Exterieur (COFACE).

the two schemes are insurance Programmes in which exporters pay a premium to insure against the risk that export returns from their market development activities or trade-show participation will not cover their expenses.
if export returns are less than expenses, compensation is received; if returns are greater than expenses, the exporter must pay back compensation already received.

claims can only be made in respect of activities undertaken after a contract has been concluded with COFACE. Two types of contracts are available-for small to medium sized companies without previous experience in exporting, and for companies which already have export experience.
to apply for support, firms must provide a business plan of their export activity. A list of countries in which they propose to promote sales and financial statements of the company.
Republic of Ireland
The Market Entry and Development Scheme (MEDS) is designed to help medium sized indigenous companies break into overseas markets or expand existing markets.
assistance is provided by way of a loan up to a maximum of UK pound 400,000.
The eligible costs are similar to those under the EMDG Scheme and must be incurred solely and directly in relation to a proposed venture and a defined market.
the onus is on the firm to justify the proposal and demonstrate that the loan will be repaid based on a levy on sales.
The Company must be indigenous and must satisfy either:
minimum of 50 employees;
fixed assets of at least 500,000 Pounds; or
annual sales of at least 2 million Pounds
and must be under such financial constraints as would prevent it from undertaking the venture without MEDS funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage of the game we have been offered this puny patch-up Bill and we are obviously still going to plough on down the main lane, ignoring the real problems and just waiting to see what happens when we hit the gurgler hole. What is going to happen? I do not know. I do not think that anybody out there in the real world has any confidence that the Government knows even what our policy is on export. Do we want it or do we not? Will we support it or will we not? If we could just spend a little bit of time here, concentrating on the main game instead of being tossed this one line Bill at a time like this, we would all be much better off.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COURT CASE: COMMENTS BY MINISTER FOR JUSTICE AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Is it a fact that the Minister was briefed by a member of his staff prior to his press conference on Wednesday, 2 May, concerning the arrest of Mr Yooyen in Bangkok on drug charges? Will the Minister inform the Senate of his exact recollection of the details of the briefing he received from his member of staff and, either directly or indirectly, from the Australian Federal Police on this matter?

—I was first informed of this arrest about 8.30 on Wednesday morning by a member of my staff and, indeed, during the course of the morning I received various indications as to the state of that particular matter. The sequence of events is set out as comprehensively as possible in the letter from the Attorney-General to the Prime Minister. I believe that there the honourable senator will find a clear indication of the various recollections of conversations which did take place, and I refer him to those paragraphs.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Whilst that might be the recollection of the Attorney-General in his letter, I asked the Minister to tell the Senate what in his recollection were the terms of the briefings he received from his staff member-and now we know there were two such briefings; and secondly, the briefings from any officer of the Australian Federal Police.

—I have indicated that the Attorney-General's letter to the Prime Minister covers the recollection of events as conveyed by me to the Attorney-General. There is nothing further to be added to that recollection conveyed to the Attorney-General.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CITIZENSHIP: DELAYS IN PROCESSING APPLICATIONS IN QUEENSLAND

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. In November last year I asked the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, whether there were any lengthy delays in the processing of applications for Australian citizenship. The Minister replied that Queensland had the longest delay period of any State. I therefore ask whether the Minister can indicate what the delay period now is in Queensland and whether any action has been taken to reduce the delay.

—I am able to advise Senator Colston that processing times for citizenship applications in Australia, and in particular in Queensland, have improved quite significantly after delays that were operating last year-last year, of course, being a record-breaking year in terms of the level of citizenship applications-as well as the impact of the recent changes to the Migration Act. The Minister informs me that his Department is now processing applications nationally within its two-month target standard of service applying from the date of receipt to approval. Conferrals, of course, take longer and are generally outside departmental control. The rate of processing in Queensland was less than one month in March, although the Minister expects that such a quick turnaround may not be sustainable. However, the point of the answer is that processing in Queensland now is down to one month's delay.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COURT CASE: COMMENTS BY MINISTER FOR JUSTICE AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question follows from the answer, or non-answer, I just received from the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I ask him a further question, and I take this from the letter from the Minister as it seems we are not going to get any information direct from the Minister, apparently: how does he account for the differences in the detail of the briefing that is said to have been given by his staff member, particularly relating to the names of parties, in order to clarify whether the Minister had knowledge of the names of parties who are being currently prosecuted in Sydney?

—In this particular situation, on the morning of last Wednesday, I suppose pressure of time led to hurried conversations that may have meant that, whilst a person can honestly recollect a particular conversation, in fact it may not have occurred in the way that he recollects, or be heard by another party in the way that the first party may have intended; in other words, these recollections of conversations--
—So, did the staff member mention the name or not?

—No, not to me. My clear recollection is that no names were mentioned to me. Unfortunately, this communication was not as structured as it ought to have been. In relation to the actual arrest of the person in Thailand, I did receive a written submission from the Australian Federal Police (AFP) relating to the arrest in Thailand, but with regard to these other matters which are the subject of the controversy there was no such submission to me. I believe that the remedy that has been suggested, and insisted upon by the Prime Minister, namely, that trials in progress or trials about to be commenced ought to be notified to the office of the Attorney-General and to my office, is a structured way in which we can avoid and remedy the obvious deficiencies of last Wednesday.

—I ask a supplementary question. The Minister made reference to a written submission that he received from the AFP concerning the arrest in Thailand. Will he table that written submission? Will he further table any other written advice that he received from his staff members, either in relation to the arrest in Thailand or, alternatively, in relation to the trial taking place in Australia?

—I would have to seek advice about the AFP written submission concerning the arrest, because it does contain sensitive information concerning operational matters. In relation to the other parts of Senator Hill's questions, I did not receive any written advice from staff members about these matters. It is a recollection of conversations which is outlined in our letter from the Attorney-General to the Prime Minister.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ASSISTANCE TO VICTIMS OF NATURAL DISASTERS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. What assistance has been made or will be made available to persons affected by the two recent natural disasters, the Newcastle earthquake of 28 December 1989 and the more recent Queensland and New South Wales floods?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fortunately, as soon as the disaster of the recent floods occurred, my department made special efforts to have staff go immediately to those areas. Upon doing so, not only was emergency cash relief distributed but also we managed to double the normal special benefit available in those cases, so that some immediate relief was made available to many thousands of people who were gravely affected by that very serious natural disaster. However, I do not think that our efforts can end there. Clearly, as people are still not living in their normal place of abode and are not expected to move into their normal place of abode for quite some time, it will be necessary for officers of my department to make special efforts to have more officers located in flood areas of both Queensland and New South Wales to ensure the speedy delivery of the social security benefits to victims. That process is being undertaken now. I do not believe that there is a requirement at this stage for many more of those immediate cash payments. I think that immediate need has now been met. Nonetheless, people are-and I do not use the phrase in any critical way-drifting back now, and it is irregular; it is difficult for us to know how many people will go back and at what time.

ANSWER.PARA: Consequently, we will have to keep this under constant review. That is being done. I believe that at the present time the efforts of the Department of Social Security are more than adequate to meet the need. I should congratulate officers of the Department. Some of them were wading through the waters themselves to deliver benefits at a very early point after the disasters had occurred. Those people I congratulate. My Parliamentary Secretary, Con Sciacca, also visited the areas almost immediately after the disasters occurred in Queensland. I think we have been more than on top of those problems.

In Newcastle the situation was much the same. We had officers on the spot immediately to help people with their problems. When one looks at it, while the Newcastle earthquake was obviously extremely serious, there were many more affected by the floods, and I think we have met the problems there more than adequately.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, concerns the multifunction polis (MFP). What does the Minister mean by the term `multifunction polis'? What advantages to Australia, either intellectual or material, does the Minister expect from the multifunction polis which could not be achieved by the reinstatement or the enhancement of funding to existing universities and research institutions? If the multifunction polis is to be directed toward that research and its application which will be profitable in the short run, what assurance will the Minister give that the social and environmental consequences of these applications will be researched and addressed simultaneously? Will the Government initiate and encourage public input to the processes leading to the decision whether or not to proceed with a MFP? If so, what will be the vehicle for this public input?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question is one which Senator Coulter gave me some brief notice of and it really in some way should be put on notice because it has a number of parts which are fairly complex. Let me say first of all that the multifunction polis is a future city concept that could assist Australia in meeting the environmental lifestyle and technological challenges of the next century.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me explain the expression `multifunction polis' which is not of my making or the making of anybody else here. It is a view of town planners and industrialists that work patterns in the next century will be very much less dictated than they have been in this century by places where people live. That is to say, people will live, work and have their leisure-or tend to-in the same situations as they used to in the Middle Ages. Following the Industrial Revolution there was a breakdown of relationships between workplaces and living places and we now have enormous problems in big cities with people commuting across cities to go to work and to return to their places of leisure and living. It requires a fair conceptual leap to say that, with computers and technology in the next century, these sorts of things will be possible again.

May I illustrate the point. Major international companies are devoting their next century's strategy to what they call resort offices, which is to say that people will live in the environment which they happen to like and do their work in that environment. It may be the Caribbean or Adelaide or wherever one likes. They will be connected to their corporate headquarters by sophisticated communications systems, and so on. That is likely to happen, and that is in a sense the origin of the expression `multifunction polis'.

The honourable senator's question has a number of parts, but I just want to say that the MFP would focus on research and development and scientific and new industry development. It would focus on developing skills in core MFP activities. The private sector committees which have been looking at the MFP proposal-thinktanks as they have called them-have identified a number of areas where value can be added to Australian resources, particularly, whether it be in agriculture or transport resources or in the types of services which Australia might appropriately network into South East Asia in the next century-telecommunications services, health services, education services and so on. They are the priority areas which have been considered by the so-called thinktanks which have been composed of academics and members of the 80 Australia companies which have been involved in this project.

Its purpose would be to foster key growth areas like telecommunications, education and health services, entertainment and environmental management. They would be the core activities of an MFP. I must say that the Government is fully committed to an examination of this concept, its implications for Australia and its overall feasibility in the Australian context. This country is always accused of being a country which is not prepared to look ahead. Indeed I do not mind saying we would not have some of the problems we have today or those we have had in the last few decades if governments, businesses and institutions in the past had been prepared to look a little further ahead than they did. But unless the Government is satisfied that the concept is economically sound, that it can be financed and, most importantly, that it is socially acceptable to the Australian community, it will not go ahead. Those decisions will have to be made in the latter part of this year.

The honourable senator asked me a number of other questions. I think his core question was why resources are not channelled into the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and universities in Australia instead of being devoted to a concept like this. The Government has made it quite clear from the beginning that the private sector essentially has the economic carriage of this project. That is to say, Government resources will not be poured into it. If, for example, at the central site of the multifunction polis there were a university or a research institute, of course the Commonwealth would make a contribution to that sort of thing as it would to any other activity of that kind, but it would be available to Australians just as much as any other resource currently funded by government at present.

In so far as Senator Coulter seeks assurances about community consultation, environmental concerns and so on, I just say in the interests of abbreviating this answer that those questions are at the forefront of the Government's mind and they will be addressed. I believe answers which are appropriate will be provided. As Senator Coulter is particularly interested in the concept, I will seek to address those questions with him privately if he wishes, but I do not want to delay the Senate further at this moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I was particularly interested in the development of the Minister's reply, his opening remarks in relation to his resume of the history of industrial development and communication. As the Parliament of Australia is one that lends itself to those means of communication, I ask him therefore whether we might use those means of communication more profitably in the operation of parliament?
—I do not regard that as a question.
—I think it was a statement.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen reports about a ruling of the Federal Court against the use of union resources to promote the yes case in union ballots concerning amalgamation? Did this ruling apply particularly to the ballot over a proposal to amalgamate the Electrical Trades Union of Australia (ETU) and the Australasian Society of Engineers (ASE)? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the ruling places impediments in the way of the campaign for trade union amalgamation which is supported by the Government, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and employer organisations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen a decision handed down by Mr Justice Gray of the Federal Court on 6 April concerning the proposed amalgamation of the Electrical Trades Union and the Australasian Society of Engineers. I think it should be said that the judge in his decision recognised that Parliament intended to facilitate amalgamation in its amendments to the Industrial Relations Act but ordered that the unions' resources and funds should not be used to promote a Yes case for amalgamation except in an extraordinarily limited way.

ANSWER.PARA: The judge's decision, for me at least, is disappointing in that it is clear, I think, from the amendments we put through in the Act in 1988 that Parliament intended to help the merger process by the provisions of the Act, that amalgamation is indeed a strong policy of this Government and of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and that amalgamation of unions is one of the elements critical to succeeding across the wide range of micro-economic reforms that this Government has in view.

The decision may frustrate the attempt by these two unions, which have demonstrated before the Industrial Relations Commission a clear community of interest. That has been recognised by the Commission, as the Commission has indeed recognised that their successful merger would in fact further the objectives of the Industrial Relations Act. And, might I say to Senator Devereux, it is likely that those two unions would have been eligible for a government grant to promote a Yes case had this action not been taken.

Since that decision I have received some strong representations from within the trade union movement and from other organisations as well, I might say, to seek ways of overcoming the problem identified by the judge. Quite clearly, the best way to proceed is to amend the Industrial Relations Act. I have announced that I intend to review the Industrial Relations Act and bring amendments to the Budget session this year in order to focus particularly on union amalgamations-but not exclusively. If there are other matters, we can bring those too.

In the meanwhile, there is this particular case, and there are a number of other cases moving through the pipeline for amalgamation. What I am currently considering is whether or not it would be appropriate for me to make a grant to interested individuals who support an amalgamation where the Industrial Relations Commission has identified a community of interest and where it is said that that amalgamation is consistent with its policy. I recognise some of the inherent dangers in such a course and that is why I am giving it considerable consideration.

In this particular case, the ASE and the ETU amalgamation case, it must also be observed, I think, Mr President, that certainly those opposed to the amalgamation, some of whom seem not necessarily to be members of the union, seem to have a plentiful supply of funds to finance the No case. In a situation where there is a clear Federal view of this organisation, it seems inappropriate not to examine ways in which the situation can be rescued.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COURT CASE: MINISTER FOR JUSTICE AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate. I ask him: When he was told by a member of his staff that nothing should be said about any Australian links with Mr Yooyen, the dealer in Thailand, did he not inquire about the nature of the links or whether any such persons in Australia may have been arrested, charged or on trial? As he admits that he was aware of an Australian connection, did he have any reason to believe that a trial would not take place in Australia at some time related to the person described as the Australian connection?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, there was never a reference to the Australian connection in a way which led me to identify any person or particular operation. I have explained-and once again it is in the letter. It is very clear on the bottom of page 2 of the letter of the Attorney to the Prime Minister:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . Senator Tate has informed me that he interpreted the advice not to refer to Australian links as meaning that he should not refer to particular, current police operations in Australia.
Certainly there was nothing to point to or identify any particular person or operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I was not questioning whether the Minister was told about any particular person or operation; I was questioning why, when the Minister knew there were Australian links, he did not inquire what they might be and who they might be?
—I have already made clear what was conveyed to my mind by that expression. It is outlined in the letter. I have nothing further to add.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Recent reports in the media point to a significant expansion in arms sales in the Asia-Pacific region. East-Asian nations spent approximately $US75 billion on defence in the last calendar year. Since January this year the United States (US) alone has issued 11,000 licences for arms sales-almost 60 per cent more licences than were issued in the equivalent period last year. Will the Minister inform the Senate what implications these purchases may have for the stability of the Asia-Pacific region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me begin by saying that it is important to appreciate that the Asia-Pacific region is probably the most complex strategic environment in the world. It has not been the centre for engagement of the two superpowers in the way that Europe has been, but there are more independent actors of real significance in this region than elsewhere: not only the two superpowers-the US and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics-but China, Japan and India, as major powers in their own right, plus a number of other significant countries such as Indonesia and our South East Asian neighbours generally, plus the two Koreas and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: All countries do have legitimate security interests and concerns and have the right to acquire conventional military capability to ensure their own security. Without this assurance there will be a lack of confidence, leading to regional insecurity. Defence expenditure figures of themselves are not a particularly reliable guide in assessing issues of stability and military power. The more important question is the types of equipment that individual countries purchase and whether this equipment is essentially for defensive reasons or whether, rather, it provides an ability to project and sustain military action against other countries.

Clearly, any dramatic change or increase in offensive and power projection military strength in the Asia-Pacific region could be destabilising. In particular, the introduction or expansion of exotic weaponry-by which we essentially refer to nuclear, chemical or missile weapon capabilities-in the region would be particularly destabilising. For instance, I could imagine no more potentially dangerous and destabilising development than the acquisition by North Korea, the DPRK, of a nuclear weapons capability.

It is for these reasons that Australia is pursuing such an active policy of support for arms control measures, particularly in relation to nuclear, chemical and missile weapon capability. It is also important, of course, to try to resolve issues which might lead to regional conflict or confrontation. Again, our efforts to resolve the Cambodian issue are an example of this.

I can summarise all of that by saying simply that to the extent that arms purchases-whatever their volume-meet legitimate defensive requirements and thereby contribute to the confidence of regional countries, we see such purchases as contributing to regional stability. If, on the other hand, the arms purchases involve the introduction of exotic forms of weaponry in the region or otherwise unbalance the regional security scene, they obviously do not contribute to the stability of the Asia-Pacific region.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COURT CASE: MINISTER FOR JUSTICE AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I ask: was the Minister aware of the arrest in January 1989 of Donald and Victor Tait and Paraphasson Yooyen and the laying of charges of conspiracy to import relating to the Australian Federal Police seizure of 10 kilograms of heroin and a large sum of money?
—Yes, I was informed of that arrest.

—My supplementary question, is two fold. When was the Minister informed of that arrest on the first occasion? Was he aware of the Federal Police action which led to that arrest? Was he aware of the family connection between any of those persons and the person named in the Minister's written press statement of 2 May 1990?

—I believe I was informed early in 1989 about the arrest. Normal practice would be that I would be informed within a matter of days, but I cannot be absolutely sure of exactly when I was informed of the arrest. As to the link that is being suggested, I do not believe I was informed of any such link at that time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COORDINATING COMMITTEE ON MULTILATERAL EXPORT CONTROLS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the political and economic reforms now occurring in several eastern European countries. What is the view of the Australian Government, as one of the 17 members of the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, known as COCOM, about the possible relaxing by Western countries of controls on high technology exports to eastern bloc countries? What, if any, steps have been taken by the Paris based COCOM organisation this year to shorten the list of the many tens of thousands of industrial items which Western countries keep out of the eastern bloc?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The role of COCOM is to coordinate export controls on strategically sensitive goods and technology without interfering unnecessarily with West-East trade. The lists of controlled goods and technology are subject to a continuous process of review. However, a number of participants have felt for some time that the process has been too slow and too conservative in its approach. At a meeting of COCOM's principal policy making body last October, countries reviewed the economic and political reforms taking place in eastern Europe and agreed to review their controls and COCOM processes. A program of work is under way in this respect. Australia has been pressing for a substantial relaxation of the COCOM processes which in our view are unnecessarily impeding legitimate trade on quite a wide range of technology. Most western European COCOM countries have also been pressing for some time for such liberalisation.

ANSWER.PARA: On 2 May, just a few days ago, the United States President launched a major proposal for liberalising COCOM processes with respect to technology that has both industrial and possible military applications. The United States' and other proposals floating around are due to be considered by the key policy body next month. Australia will certainly be taking quite an active role in seeking substantive reform with a view to opening new trade opportunities for Australian exporters of high technology goods and services.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COURT CASE: MINISTER FOR JUSTICE AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. When the Minister formed the view-and I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: There's no doubt that this man has been the number one importer of heroin into Australia during the 1980s; therefore this particular arrest will utterly shatter and, I believe, demoralise the forces of those who are peddling these drugs of death and destruction into our country.
did it not occur to him that one or more of those who are alleged to be peddling drugs into our country may have been on trial or charged with such an offence involving Prasart Yooyen?

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I was making the obvious point that a distribution network would be required in Australia in relation to the peddling of heroin into the streets of Australia, having been trafficked into Australia from the Golden Triangle.

—Can the Minister for Social Security say at what stage are the negotiations with other countries for social security agreements? What is the Government's attitude to negotiating new international social security agreements with Greece and Turkey?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the excellent work of my predecessor Australia set about rationalising agreements with other countries on the payment of our pensions and, indeed, the payment of theirs. We now have agreements signed, or about to be signed, with a range of countries which include Canada, Ireland, Austria, Malta, Italy, Spain and the Netherlands. Obviously we have been very active in the last few years. If one looks at the February economic statement one finds an announcement there of a saving by the Government on the non-payment of wives and widows pensions from 1 July next year for those who had not been in Australia during that 12-month period. That involved a saving across the board of about $30m. In the case of Greece and Turkey it involved a saving of about $14m.

ANSWER.PARA: To enable that saving to be achieved, it would require Australia giving notice to terminate the treaties it signed in 1972 with those two countries. Back in 1972 Australia signed treaties with Greece, Turkey, Italy, and Malta which were to cover the portability of pensions. The following year Australia made a further announcement on portability of pensions which went much further than the terms of the agreement with either Greece or Turkey. So we have in fact done much more than that treaty ever required us to do, and we propose to continue to do so.

In the case of Greece and Turkey, however, neither of those countries has ever abided by those two treaties; so the Australian Government is now looking at giving 12 months notice to terminate.
