But we would not presume to do that without some adequate consultation with the Greek and Turkish communities in Australia to explain not only the decision to terminate those pensions and get the savings but also our determination to get comprehensive, shared responsibility agreements with Greece and Turkey, which, I might say, would mean inevitably, over time, more money being paid into those countries, particularly Greece, because, looking at the model agreements that we have signed with those countries I mentioned earlier on, there would be many people now in Greece who would be entitled to part and full time age pensions who are not receiving them now and are currently ineligible for benefits. So this is not simply a taking away; it will inevitably lead to many more people in Greece who spent considerable amounts of time in Australia being able to receive Australian pensions.

Over the next month or so I will continue the meetings that I had this morning with the Greek community in Melbourne and I will be going to Greek and Turkish communities in Australia to explain that. I hope that the communities understand what we are doing and that Australia can proceed along those lines.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COURT CASE: COMMENTS BY MINISTER FOR JUSTICE AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —On the flight last Wednesday to Melbourne, to which the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs made reference yesterday, did he raise with the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) the question of the impending trial of Mr Yooyen or did the DPP raise this matter with the Minister? What were the details and circumstances of the Minister's conversation with the Director of Public Prosecutions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I got on a plane to Melbourne last Wednesday. I noticed that Mr Weinberg was seated by himself. I think I had mentioned as I entered the plane that if I got a chance I would have a chat with him. In the last 20 minutes, as the flight was descending into Melbourne, I went over and sat with him. We discussed a number of matters. I may have asked him whether he had heard about the arrest in Thailand. He asked whether I had heard about the trial in Sydney. At that stage I was looking for the oxygen mask to descend from the console above my head, because this was one of those emergencies that the flight attendants always only tell you about.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the conversation took a serious turn, and I indicated that I had no knowledge whatsoever, before he had spoken to me, of the trial in Sydney. The Director of Public Prosecutions has accepted that I knew nothing of the trial at the time of my conversation with him. That was the first awareness or instance of any knowledge of that particular trial.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I ask Senator Tate to clarify the position with regard to the arrest. I also refer to my original question in which I asked for the details and circumstances of the Minister's conversation.
—I have nothing further to add to the very full answer I have given.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. In view of the recent Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) decision concerning Adrian Crisp, a deceased Vietnam veteran, which linked his cancer with his exposure to herbicides, pesticides and the antimalarial drug dapsone whilst he was on war service, will the Minister take action to alleviate the suffering of very sick cancer victims who are forced to spend years battling through the appeals system by, first, ensuring that the Department of Veterans' Affairs ceases its obstinate refusal to accept such claims and, secondly, advising all affected veterans or their widows whose claims have been rejected to reapply?

—I have received a brief on this matter from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Humphreys, to the effect that the Australian repatriation system is comprehensive and ensures that each case is decided on its merits in accordance with that legislation. The AAT handed down its decision in Mr Crisp's case last Friday. The decision rejected an appeal by the Repatriation Commission against the decision of the Veterans' Review Board, which had granted Mr Crisp's widow a war widow's pension. The Minister has been advised that the Repatriation Commission is carefully considering its attitude to this case. The Repatriation Commission, not the Minister, has the responsibility for deciding entitlements for individual veterans. Before deciding upon its approach to this case, the Repatriation Commissioner is seeking legal and other relevant advice. The Minister is unable to comment further on the case until that advice has been received.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question: I understand the Minister to be saying that the Minister and the Department are reconsidering their attitude only to this case and not to the range of cases which quite clearly fall within similar circumstances.

—I think I have indicated that it is the Repatriation Commission that has the responsibility for deciding entitlements for individual veterans and not the Department or the Minister. It is an important distinction which is obviously emphasised in the brief in front of me. The Commission itself is taking advice as to the further implications, legal and others, flowing from the decision of last Friday. I imagine that it must extend to considerations of matters other than the particular case in relation to which the AAT made its determination.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COURT CASE: MINISTER FOR JUSTICE AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Tate has advised us that he knew of the arrest of the female Yooyen in Australia on a charge of importation of herion and he received a full Australian Federal Police (AFP) briefing regarding the arrest of the male Yooyen in Thailand on matters relating to the exportation of herion presumably intended to reach Australia, and in view of the comments of Mr Justice Graham in the case, where he said it could be legitimately speculated that there was a relationship between the two, is the Minister seriously asking this Senate to believe that at no time did he draw any relationship between the male Yooyen doing the exporting and the female Yooyen doing the importing?
—Yes.
—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Was there nothing in the AFP brief that indicated any linkage between the two?

—This puts me in a difficult position, only in the sense that I have indicated that I would like to consider how much of the AFP brief that I received on Wednesday might be made available because of operational matters contained in it.
—Why don't you get someone else to make a judgment? That is not for you.
—I can make an assertion but Senator Alston will not accept the assertion. That is my point.
—What is your assertion?
—My assertion is no, no such link was made.

—I refer the Minister for Defence to the Government's decision last year to scrap the Chinook helicopter based at Amberley Air Base in Queensland. Currently, 11 Chinooks are mothballed at the base awaiting sale. I also remind the Minister of the previously proven reliability of the helicopter in providing support during natural disasters such as the extensive flooding and fierce storms off the Queensland coast early last year when the Chinook was used to provide invaluable service to the community as it was the only helicopter capable of withstanding the gale force winds in order to rescue people stranded at sea. Though this is not the primary role of the Chinook helicopter, in view of the recent devastating flooding in western Queensland and New South Wales, when evacuation would have been easier and fewer livestock lost if this type of helicopter had been available, will the Minister reconsider the decision in light of the helicopter's effectiveness in supporting the community during such times?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that Senator Bjelke-Petersen has followed this general issue with a great deal of interest. I do not agree with her presumption that a lot of livestock were lost because of the unavailability of the Chinook helicopter. Indeed, the support given by the armed services in these floods was deemed adequate by the State Emergency Service, and everything asked for in that period was supplied and dealt with.

ANSWER.PARA: One does not make defence decisions on the basis of what civilian use they may have. I have ordered that the decision to mothball the Chinooks be reviewed, but for military reasons, not for civilian reasons. We will be looking at that over the next few months. It may be that the decision to mothball them will remain. It may be that a compromise will be reached where some may be restored to service and others basically sold off or used for spare parts. That will be a military decision, not one based on civilian use. There is no denying that if we were to retain some Chinook helicopters they could be put to civilian use.

There was a lot of publicity and inference in Queensland that in this last unfortunate series of natural disasters somehow the rescue efforts and other contributions were inhibited by the lack of the Chinooks. I deny that. Adequate numbers of planes and helicopters were made available to cover the job. That is attested to by the State emergency services in New South Wales and Queensland. However, the final decision as to whether some, all or no Chinooks are retained will be made in the next few months.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I draw the Minister's attention to recent reports that a lack of quality is jeopardising Australia's wheat industry, which in my home State of South Australia could be worth as much as $1,000m. Overseas buyers of Australian wheat, particularly Russia and the Middle East, are demanding that something be done about falling protein levels in our grain. I ask the Minister what strategies and practices farmers could adopt to combat the problem. Does he think it is serious enough to warrant an education program in rural areas to help wheat growers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a need to improve the quality of the Australian wheat crop since buyers are becoming more discriminating. Over the past decade there has been some decline, I am informed, in the average protein levels of the Australian wheat crop. The problem is being addressed in a number of ways. The need for improvements in the quality of the Australian wheat crop was one of the reasons why this Government deregulated the domestic wheat market and provided greater flexibility to the Australian Wheat Board for its pooling and commercial operations. These changes have provided more scope for growers to receive appropriate returns for quality in their wheat crop.

ANSWER.PARA: The Wheat Board has also been very active in trying to improve the quality of the Australian wheat crop. For the first time, in the 1989-90 season it has introduced a system of load by load testing and payment for protein within the Australian standard white (ASW) grade, which accounts for about 70 per cent of the crop. A major benefit of this program is that growers delivering ASW wheat will be able to monitor the protein performance of particular varieties and paddocks on their properties. An accumulation of this information should prove invaluable in decision-making. Differential payments for protein within the ASW grade will bring new incentives for growers to improve protein levels in the main part of the Australian crop.

I should also emphasise that the Wheat Research Council has had this issue high on its agenda. I am sure Senator Panizza would know that. It has held discussions with the Australian Wheat Board and has organised a number of workshops to better define its research priorities. Quality improvement features widely in the Council's strategies. State departments of agriculture now also have programs for raising wheat quality. Raising protein levels is difficult because there has been a trade-off between protein and yield. In the long term, improvements in protein will depend on the maintenance and improvement of soil fertility. This issue will be addressed in the Government's sustainable development strategy.

To answer the last part of the question-is there a need for an education program?-from the body of my answer Senator Foreman can see that, indeed, a great deal of education is going on. The best way of promoting that education is through the Wheat Research Council, the Wheat Board and the State government authorities.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COURT CASE: MINISTER FOR JUSTICE AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Tate. Given that he indicated that on the plane to Melbourne he was immediately concerned about being notified of a trial such that he wished the oxygen mask would fall down, why did notification of that trial concern him in relation to the remarks he had made, given that he told the Senate he had no reason to connect the two Yooyens?
—I find the question astonishing. The Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions expressed his concern to me. I understood his concern.

—I ask a supplementary question. The question is quite simple. If the Minister had no reason to connect the two people sufficient to caution him in relation to making the remarks he made, why was he then concerned, having been notified that a trial was in progress in relation to the remarks he had already then made?
—Because the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions told me.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Does the Minister agree that the resignations of officers from the Australian Defence Force continue to increase at an alarming rate? What specific measures does the Government intend to implement to retain our experience levels and to avoid wasting funds on unnecessary advertising, recruiting and training?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The separation rate in the Armed Forces has increased over recent years. It is very much the case these days, though, that it will probably never return to the levels of, say, the 1970s. However, it would be very desirable if the separation rate no longer increased but, rather, decreased somewhat. There is a variety of reasons for that and Senator Newman is probably aware of most of those reasons. Some of them are societal-a change in society's attitudes. One of the reasons why it is occurring is simply the fact that the participation rate in the work force is so high and there have been so many opportunities for people to use skills and change jobs. A lot of it is to do with people training for something they may never be required to do. Therefore, to be more successful in future, one has to create within the Armed Forces conditions that are attractive and make people want to remain. There is a variety of options before Government at the moment. I am currently looking at some of those options. My colleague, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Gordon Bilney, is also studying some of those. But I do not think we will ever get back to the separation rates of the mid or early 1970s. However, it is very desirable to reduce the separation rate.

ANSWER.PARA: In her question Senator Newman pointed out the fact that the cost of recruiting and training is remarkably high. The increased rate also highlights one other thing, and that is that not enough training is done in the community as a whole. The Armed Forces are sometimes used just as a recruiting ground by lazy employers who do not want to enter into training themselves; rather, they simply go in and shark out.

I hope that Minister Dawkins's initiative-which will be debated here and I will not anticipate the debate because I would be in breach of Standing Orders-will go a long way in overcoming that problem. It is particularly serious not just in relation to percentages but, rather, in certain areas of the forces where the attrition rate is much higher, and it takes quite a while to attempt to replace those officers. We will have to address specifically those particular issues and look for remedies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I think that I asked a much more specific question than the Minister was prepared to address and I just remind him that I asked him whether he agreed that resignations of officers from the Australian Defence Force are continuing to increase at an alarming rate-the rate of increase is growing-and what specific measures he would put in place to deal with that.
—I am not really that concerned with the question asked. I have given the answer I wanted to give.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Does the Hawke Government intend to continue its role in the elimination of domestic violence when the current education campaign is completed and the Commonwealth-State working party disbands in June of this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Giles at least would know-and other members of the Senate, I hope, would know-that the Prime Minister announced on 2 March this year the establishment of the Commonwealth-State Committee on Violence Against Women and a continuation of community education and research in the area. Senator Giles rightly says that the three-year national domestic violence education program (NDVEP) will conclude next month, but I think it is fair to say that government and most independent commentators have been impressed with the program and its effectiveness, particularly in increasing community awareness of the issue of domestic violence. I think its importance has been that it recognises and highlights the need for a high level committee coordinated approach between the Commonwealth and State governments to tackle issues in this area, particularly issues arising from a lack of uniformity in both legislation and police practices.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government firmly believes that the program has been successful, not only as an educative process but also in terms of raising for government and the community issues that need to be picked up and progressed in this term of government. As I said, the issues do relate to the area of Commonwealth-State relations, and the Prime Minister's announcement on 2 March goes very much to the establishment and continuation of a process to ensure that there is coordination in this extremely important area.

Senator Giles asked specifically about education in this area. As part of the commitment given by the Prime Minister, the Committee will get funding in the vicinity of $1.35m over three years to provide a coordinated national strategy on all forms of violence against women, including of course spousal abuse, elder abuse and rape. It is anticipated that this coordinating role which will be undertaken by the Commonwealth-State Committee on Violence will be one that will continue also the community education undertaken under the previous NDVEP. Of course, it will ensure that the issues related to the Commonwealth-State coordination, the priorities for uniformity, the priorities for education, and the priority for attention given to legislation and police practices will be addressed over the forthcoming three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I remind the Minister that the newly independent state of Lithuania has been asking for practical assistance. I ask the Minister: In the event that the newly independent state of Lithuania, now under economic blockade by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, asks for specific practical assistance-including urgently needed medical assistance-will the Australian Government respond in a practical manner with assistance?

—We would certainly give very sympathetic consideration to any request of that kind that did emerge. I would need to take that question on notice and see what the realities of the situation are, but in principle the answer is yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. What has been the role of Austrade in relation to the rejection of Australian live sheep exports to the Middle East? As Austrade has five posts in the Middle East, why has its market intelligence failed to ascertain the reasons for the rejection of our live sheep?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Austrade has had a very limited role in regard to the export of live sheep to the Middle East. That function has been supervised or assisted by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and involves, of course, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.
—They reckon Austrade is incompetent.

—I do not know about that, but the point is that the Meat and Livestock Corporation has been responsible for those exports. It, of course, is a trading body that was established long before Austrade was established, and by and large it has a good reputation in this area.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the question of rejection of live sheep exports turns very much now on the age of sheep which are being exported. That is something which the exporters in Australia have to examine as a serious issue. But no amount of market intelligence can really add to that as being the essential problem faced by live sheep exporters.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the significance of Prince Sihanouk's decision to step down from the position of leader of the Resistance Coalition? Will it affect the outcome of negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 May just a couple of days ago Prince Sihanouk issued a statement in Beijing saying that he would be taking a long leave of absence from his position as leader of the Resistance Coalition, the national government of Cambodia. He also said that he would not attend a meeting with State of Cambodia Prime Minister Hun Sen, planned for the first week of June in Tokyo. Prince Sihanouk said that he was taking leave because of his age and his wish to leave war and politics and devote himself to the rehabilitation of his people through marshalling international assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: Prince Sihanouk has stepped aside from the leadership of the resistance on several occasions in the past, essentially to gain room for manoeuvre in the settlement process and in relations with his coalition partners. I have to say, however, that his latest announcement came as a great surprise to everyone since he had only very recently agreed to meet Hun Sen in Tokyo. It has not been entirely unknown in the past for Prince Sihanouk to change his mind. That cannot be ruled out. We certainly hope he will reconsider his position on this occasion. He has a very important continuing part to play in the settlement process and if his meeting with Hun Sen in Tokyo does not proceed this will certainly constitute an unfortunate setback to the emerging process of dialogue among the Cambodian parties which is so crucial if a comprehensive settlement is to be achieved.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR JUSTICE AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Hill) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence over all other business to a motion relating to a proposed censure of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs.
Motion (by Senator Hill) agreed to:
That a motion to censure Senator Tate take precedence over all other business until determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censure the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, for failing to meet the required standards in the conduct of his office as a Senior Law Officer of the Crown.

I said in this chamber yesterday that we believed we had a responsibility to ensure that this Government met the high standards that the people of Australia had a right to expect of it. I regret to say so early in this Parliament, this Government, through the conduct of one of its senior Ministers, Senator Tate, has demonstrated that it is not meeting that high standard.

This censure relates to two aspects of the matter that we have been discussing in Question Time. On the first of those I think it is fair to say that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, has already been convicted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) although it might be said that he was being put on a good behaviour bond. That is his interference during the course of a press conference with the conduct of justice as it occurs in Thailand by presuming the guilt of a certain person who had been arrested there for being in possession of a quantity of heroin.

The second aspect of this censure motion refers to a matter of which we might say the Prime Minister acquitted Senator Tate, but which on all evidence indicates that that acquittal was wrong. That is the Minister's recklessness or at least gross negligence in the conduct of his responsibilities which led to a trial in New South Wales being aborted.
This sorry matter commenced with a press release put out by Senator Tate, a press release of 2 May 1990. I refer to but one paragraph of that press release. It said:

The Federal Minister for Justice, Senator Michael Tate, today released details of Australian involvement in the arrest of Prasert Yooyen in Bangkok, and the seizure of approximately 30 kg of high grain heroin.
That press release was the teaser. It was designed to interest the press because at the bottom was a note:
Senator Tate will be available to expand on the details of this release at 12.15 p.m. at the Ministerial Wing entrance.

So Senator Tate expanded, Mr President, and we have a few excerpts of what he said. What he said is, in our opinion, the evidence upon which he should be convicted on the second count I have mentioned. He said, on the first count:

There is no doubt this man has been the number one importer of heroin into Australia during the 1980s. Therefore this particular arrest will utterly shatter and, I believe, demoralise the forces of those who are peddling these drugs of death and destruction into our country.

There he is saying out of his own mouth that there is no doubt that this man has been the No. 1 importer-someone who is not convicted, simply arrested. As I said, Mr President, even the Prime Minister said that that was an intolerable exercise of Senator Tate's duties. What the Prime Minister failed to do, of course, was to take the step that followed, that is, to acknowledge that such standards could not be tolerated of his Ministers, particularly a Minister for Justice, and to dismiss Senator Tate.

The second part of the censure is what the Opposition is really concerned to discuss today, that is, the conduct of the Minister which resulted in the trial being aborted and his recklessness and gross negligence in doing so. The trial, of course, was a trial that was taking place in Sydney of, among others, the sister of the man in Thailand and of whom Senator Tate was talking, a person who had been arrested approximately a year earlier. We learnt today in Question Time that Senator Tate knew of the arrest of this person at the time.

What Senator Tate has denied is that he knew that the trial was taking place. That, in our view, is irrelevant. If the trial was not taking place, the trial was pending. So Senator Tate knew that there was a trail to take place, at least, of the female Yooyen in New South Wales at the same time as he was making not only these allegations but these conclusions about the conduct of the male Yooyen in Bangkok.

The court in New South Wales said that this was intolerable, prejudiced justice, prejudiced a fair trial for the female Yooyen in New South Wales and prejudiced a fair trail for the other defendants as well. The judge, therefore, said that he had no alternative but to dismiss the jury.

The question, therefore, was: Should Senator Tate have known of the connection between the two Yooyens? Was he given any indication of any cause to have made further inquiries than he did? Was he in fact negligent in his duty in running the press conference and therefore prejudicing and determining that the trial in New South Wales be aborted? The answer, Mr President, is clearly yes.
The answer was obvious to the judge himself in New South Wales when he said-and I quote from the judgment of Judge Graham:
It is clear that the person is or may legitimately be speculated to be the brother of one of the accused in the present trial.

Senator Tate knew that they were both of the same name. He told us that he had received a briefing or had been advised of the arrest of the first Yooyen in relation to drug matters. We accept that Senator Tate has taken an interest in this area of the law and has taken an interest in trying to combat drug importations from Thailand. So he knew of that connection one year before this particular matter.

I ask that Senator Tate give consideration to putting before the Senate not only the report of the Australian Federal Police in relation to the arrest of the male Yooyen in Thailand but also the report he received from the AFP in relation to the arrest of the female Yooyen in Sydney a year before. So, he knew the female Yooyen had been arrested a year before. He presumably knew the trial was pending, if he believed it had not already started, although it is interesting to note that the trial had in fact been taking place for some weeks and that there had been press items relating to it. One can only wonder how the Minister can indicate, presuming he has been briefed properly on these matters-if he has not, that is his responsibility and he cannot pass the buck again-that he did not know of the existence of the trial. But even if he did not know the trial had already commenced, he knew it was pending. He knew that there were parties concerned of the same name, in circumstances where certainly a judge of the court in New South Wales concluded that there could be quite reasonable speculation that they were related.

This is different, because Senator Tate gets briefed on these matters. We now learn today that he was briefed by the AFP on the arrest of the male Yooyen in Thailand. This is not any simple drug arrest, I remind you, Mr President. This is an arrest of the person Senator Tate refers to as the No. 1 importer of heroin into Australia during the 1980s. He received a brief from the AFP on that, and we are asked today to accept that that brief makes no connection between this person who has been arrested-this major drug exporter to Australia-and his sister, who is standing trial in New South Wales on drug importation charges, charges relating to heroin being imported from Thailand. I have to say that it is asking a great deal of this Senate to accept that.

But the matter is even worse. Not only do we have to accept this extraordinary set of circumstances, we have to accept a number of others matters as well. We learn of these matters through this exchange of letters between the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and the Prime Minister. One of the things we have to accept is that Senator Tate was not told by his staff of the name of the person standing trial. Interestingly, the staff member-we read from this document-has a different recollection. It is said in the letter from Mr Duffy to the Prime Minister that the staff member briefing Senator Tate before he played out this press conference and the subsequent doorstop briefings to the press `informed me that he recalled in relation to the Australian connection mentioning names to the Minister'.

Senator Tate says, `I do not recall that' and, not surprisingly, Mr Duffy and the Prime Minister decide that the Minister needs protecting and the poor staff member was clearly the one who has the faulty memory. We might say again, `Let us give Senator Tate the benefit of a second doubt'. But there is a third stage to this scenario. Senator Tate recalls that he was told that there was nothing to be said about any Australian links. What are the Australian links? Would not any Minister who was doing half his job properly ask the staff member, `What are the Australian links? What do I need to be careful about?'

Let us put it into context. This is a Minister who accepts that he knew of the arrest of the female Yooyen, who has taken an interest in this whole area, who has been to Bangkok and been briefed on the procedures; he knows what the AFP is doing up there. He now receives a further brief from the AFP about the arrest of the male Yooyen. He goes to the press and says, `This is the major importer of drugs into Australia'. The staff member says to him, in effect, `Beware of the Australian links when you go into this press conference later today'. Senator Tate says, `I really do not draw any conclusion from that at all'.

I would put to you, Mr President, that that is just too much to accept. At the very least, what the Minister should have done was explore the links and ensure not only that he did not detrimentally affect the trial that was to take place in Thailand but also that there was no way in which he was going to interfere with the proper conduct of justice in this country.

At the very least we say that he was grossly negligent in his conduct and the result of his conduct, of course, was that the trial in New South Wales had to be aborted. The Minister told us yesterday that once things have settled down the trial can go ahead again. I think the Prime Minister and Mr Duffy may have said that as well in their letters. We are talking about a notorious family in this matter. This is not the sort of matter that will settle down. By his very conduct the Minister has ensured that it will not settle down because the trial has clearly been aborted in circumstances where there has been a great deal of public interest and public concern-and so there should be public concern.

I will not take up the time of the Senate in recalling previous occasions when Senator Tate has failed to meet the standard of responsibility that can be reasonably expected of a Minister, although some of my colleagues may well do so in the course of this debate. If it were a one-off instance, it may be argued that there was a little more merit in the Prime Minister's bestowal of a good behaviour bond and acquittal on the second count, but I say that that is not so. This matter is serious, and it must be put into the context of a series of occasions when the standard required of this Minister has been found to be lacking.

It is interesting that the Minister himself has previously put publicly what he regards as the standard to be adopted by Ministers and the level of conduct that the public has a right to expect of Ministers in these circumstances. I commend him for doing so. I make reference to one speech that he gave on 3 September 1988 entitled, `The Process of Effective Criminal Law Reform'. In that speech he talked about the Independent Commission Against Corruption legislation in New South Wales. He said:

I do not need to emphasise to an audience such as this that a court always has the inherent power to deal with prejudicial pre-trial publicity in one of four ways; it may order the suppression of future publications; order a change of venue; it may delay the proceedings; or it may grant, in exceptional circumstances, a stay of proceedings. These are, of course, common law powers and capable of expansion or restriction at the instance of members of our judiciary. It is sanguine to recount the words of Justice Wills in the Queen v. Park, and I quote:
It is possible, very effectually, to poison the fountain of justice before it begins to flow.

I regret to say that this Minister in this instance, through recklessness or gross negligence, poisoned the fountain of justice before it began to flow and for that he deserves the censure of this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This Parliament has now met for three days. We have had a Question Time devoted to this issue, which has all the charm and warmth of the tip of an ice-cube, I suspect, in terms of its relative importance. As I said, the whole of Question Time has been devoted to this issue, and we are now debating a censure motion. I must say, as a relatively impartial observer, that I do not think the Opposition made much progress during Question Time, and nor did it during the last Parliament when it prepared series of questions on various issues. After the first two or three questions had been answered, Opposition senators kept asking the questions as if there were some logic about that program of questions. That was not so.

SPEECH.PARA: In this censure motion Senator Hill says that Senator Tate has failed to meet the required standards. He referred to a series of occasions on which Senator Tate is alleged to have done this. He did not identify that series of occasions. The argument turns on two issues. The first is the assumption in Senator Tate's remarks at the doorstop conference of the presumed guilt of a person arrested in Thailand. It is good enough for Senator Hill to come in here today and refer to this family as a notorious family. I do not think Senator Hill suspects that that sort of remark made in the Senate-to refer to these people, brother and sister, as a notorious family-will have much effect on the conduct of a trial in Thailand. I do not think Senator Hill expects that that remark by him will have any influence on a trial in Thailand or any effect on a trial in Sydney.

In saying that, I think Senator Hill is showing a sense of perspective, because for all the rhetoric on the other side of the chamber does anybody seriously believe that Senator Tate's comments made last Wednesday will affect the course of justice in Thailand?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. He is the Minister for Justice.

—If anybody seriously believes that-and Senator Walters has identified herself as one of those-it displays a degree of ignorance, which I find not surprising in the case of Senator Walters. It is quite extraordinary that that sort of allegation is made. If it is good enough for Senator Hill to say it here, why is it not good enough for Senator Tate to say it last Wednesday?
—He is the Minister for Justice in the Government.

—I understand that. Senator Hill is the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. The first point relates to Senator Hill's allegation that Senator Tate's remarks contained a suggestion of presumed guilt of a person arrested in Thailand and that that would prejudice a trial in that country. I cannot take that suggestion seriously--
—The Prime Minister did.

—And I do not believe that Senator Hill does either. Of course, that is a matter for subjective judgment by each individual as to what influence he might have, but I think Senator Hill really gave that point away quite early in his piece and went to his main point, which was the effects on the trial in Australia. That issue made very little progress today in Question Time. In fact, the elaboration of the information contained in the letters of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by Senator Tate today only goes to the question of his discussion with the Director of Public Prosecutions on the aircraft and his first awareness of the trial in Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill says that we are asked to take a few things for granted in the course of this debate. I agree with that. Senator Hill goes through this tortuous attempt to make a connection between an arrest in early 1989 and the trial in Sydney, which has recently taken place, and the arrest of a person in Thailand a week or so ago. Senator Hill can exclude this smokescreen, this sweet-smelling argument that he puts forward like some bug which does it for its own protection, but all that is clear about all this is that Senator Tate did not make that connection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Should he have?
—Somebody interjects to say that he should have. Why should he have made that connection?
—That is because he is paid to make those sorts of connections.

—No, he is not. Senator Tate will make his position quite clear when he speaks in a moment, but he was asked to make an instant connection between an arrest in 1989 and a subsequent arrest in Thailand a year later. Senator Durack, as a former Attorney-General, nods his head. He took five years to make a connection between the documents in his bottom drawer, the bottom of the harbour documents, and what he should do as Attorney-General, and he comes in here saying Senator Tate should make an instant connection about these matters today.
—You told us the AFP had briefed him on the procedures leading up to the arrest. What was he doing?
—Senator Tate said that he was briefed on the proceedings in relation to the arrest in 1989 and he was again briefed last Wednesday, and he made no connection.
—Terrific!
—Senator Puplick might say it is terrific but in terms of what is on the record, what is provable, what is established--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Where those opposite are quite wrong about this is that the AFP report told Senator Tate not to make any reference to the Australian connection last Wednesday.
—He is shaking his head. You have got it wrong.

—He was told not to make any reference to the Australian connection-what Senator Tate understands, and what I understand, is an operational connection between the Thai police, the international police and the Australian police. That is what he is talking about-an operational connection. Senator Hill asked for the tabling of those documents. They cannot be tabled because they reveal operational matters which cannot be tabled in the Senate. I know it is a long time since those opposite have had any experience in government, but one cannot as a responsible Minister table documents which go to the effect of secret or undercover police operations. It is no good Senator Hill interjecting, `Why do you not table all the documents?'. That cannot be done.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two points. First, in relation to a trial, presumably a pending trial, in Thailand, people here in the Senate and elsewhere will make their own judgments about the effects on the process of justice in Thailand of his comments at a doorstop interview. People will reach their own conclusions about the likely effects of those remarks on the process of justice in Thailand. I do not think Senator Hill really sees that point in connection as being very important because he certainly did not advance the argument very far.

The second point relates to the effects on the trial in Sydney. Of course, Senator Tate, the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General have said that the consequences of Senator Tate's remarks have been most unfortunate. Of course, they are unfortunate because, according to the judge, they led to the aborting of a trial. Apart from the fact that the consequences were unfortunate, nothing can be said other than what Senator Tate himself has said about the circumstances leading to those remarks, namely, that he was unaware of the existence of a trial in Sydney and unaware of the relationship between the arrest in early 1989 of the persons who were on trial in Sydney last week and the arrest in Thailand. In terms of his intentions in relation to this matter and the information available to him, the remarks which he made can be described as nothing more than unfortunate in terms of the consequences which followed in the Sydney trial.

Of course, the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General have exchanged correspondence in this matter which has been tabled in the Senate. The circumstances of last Wednesday's events have been fully described in that correspondence and the Prime Minister has exercised his judgment about the matter in view of Senator Tate's intentions and the information available to him, and also because of what I would say is an almost impeccable record in Senator Tate's administration of the justice portfolio, particularly in relation to the restructuring of the Federal Police in Australia, the appointment of an overseas network which was involved in the operations the subject of discussion, the enhancement of capacity for crucial intelligence against drug traffickers and a whole range of issues and procedures which have been enlivened, as it were, and performance improved as a result of the initiatives taken by this Minister.

Senator Tate has been intimately associated with those matters. I do not think there is any suggestion by anybody, even the Opposition, of any dishonesty or lack of integrity on Senator Tate's part. The worst allegation that can be made is the one that has been made here by Senator Hill that the Minister should have known of a particular set of circumstances of which he was not aware. In the Prime Minister's judgment, and in the documents that are tabled in his exchange of correspondence with the Attorney-General, there are a number of suggestions about how there could be improvements in making sure that both the Attorney and the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs are made aware of trials which are taking place and any relevant facts relating to those trials. It is a matter of regret that it was not done prior to this series of events but it will be done in the future, and Senator Tate will remain Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs and be responsible for administering those changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), in defence of his embattled colleague Senator Tate, has made a most extraordinary speech-extraordinary because of the laid-back and don't care attitude he has taken to ministerial responsibility and to the circumstances of the particular charge that is made against Senator Tate. I might say at the outset that Senator Button's defence and his evaluation of the seriousness of this matter are unique to Senator Button. Senator Tate himself, even today in answer to questions, has indicated how seriously he took this matter when he did learn of the trial going on at the time he made these remarks.
—He needed oxygen.

—He needed oxygen. That was a very vivid example of the importance that should be attached to this problem. It is not the Opposition's case at all that Senator Tate ever knew that this trial was proceeding. We accept, of course, his denial of that; everyone has accepted his denial of knowledge that the trial was going on. The case we make against Senator Tate is based on a number of things. One, of course, is that this was no ordinary trial. This was a very serious trial, a very important trial, which was aborted because of some remarks of Senator Tate which were not carefully thought out or carefully prepared. We also have a concern, despite Senator Button's nonchalant attitude about the matter, about the effect that Senator Tate's remarks may well have on the position of the drug dealer Mr Yooyen in Thailand, whose arrest by Thai police was the basis of Senator Tate's statement and the beginning of this matter. So Senator Button's defence is extraordinary because his evaluation of this subject would not be supported even by Senator Tate himself.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what other perhaps more important players in this matter have said about Senator Tate's conduct. In relation to the effect on the position of Mr Yooyen in Thailand, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) in his letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), which was tabled yesterday, says this on page 3:

I have also expressed my dismay to Senator Tate that in the course of his press conference he had presumed the guilt of the person arrested in Thailand. He agrees with me that his comments were unfortunate.

So it is not the Opposition impugning Senator Tate about Mr Yooyen's position in Thailand; it is a very deep concern of the Attorney-General himself and presumably of the Prime Minister. I come to the Prime Minister and his attitude to this matter. Of course, we have read the document that was tabled and the very inadequate, limp, lame reasons the Prime Minister has given for not dismissing Senator Tate or calling for his resignation. In answer to a question yesterday in the House of Representatives from the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peacock, Mr Hawke said:
We-
speaking of himself and the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy-
are appalled at the lapse of judgment.

So we are dealing here with no ordinary error of judgment, no ordinary incompetence or failure or mistake on the part of a Minister. None of us expect Ministers to be perfect, but we are here dealing with a very serious mistake made by a Minister. Although I will deal with the question of his incompetent handling of the matter, which is really the basis of our charge, I think it is fair to say that, where a Minister personally is involved in a matter that has caused serious trouble, that in itself is a basis for his resignation.

This was no ordinary trial; it was a trial of three or four people who had been arrested in January 1989, about 12 months before the trial began. They were arrested and charged with conspiracy to import into Australia about 10 kilograms of heroin with a street value of $10m. Their arrest and their initial appearance in court, as Senator Tate has now admitted today, was known to him roughly, I presume, about that time in the early part of 1989. The trial itself was one that had proceeded, I understand, for some weeks prior to these remarks which led to the judge having to abort the trial.

These prosecutions of people alleged to be importing large quantities of heroin from overseas are very difficult trials indeed. The costs involved in preparation and the length of this trial up to the time it was aborted, of which Senator Tate has given no indication, will be not inconsiderable, taking into account the Crown, defence counsel, witnesses and so on. There is also the problem of witnesses perhaps being brought from overseas for these trials. I do not know whether that is the case here, but these are very difficult and very expensive trials. Certainly this was a most important trial and one which, as I said, was no ordinary trial.

Senator Tate's defence is simply this: he did not know that the trial was taking place. My Leader, Senator Hill, has already gone through a good deal of the detail to show why Senator Tate should have known or understood that a trial was taking place, and he certainly should have made the inquiries at the time before he made these remarks after the press conference. But I think we ought just to recall for a moment what Judge Graham in the District Court of New South Wales said when he gave his reasons for aborting this very serious, complicated and difficult trial. He said:

There is one particular feature of the publicity which is of concern. It is, in particular, the set of statements attributed to the Commonwealth Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, who was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald as saying among other things, ``There is no doubt that this man has been the number one importer of heroin into Australia during the 1980s.''

That was said by Senator Tate not in his statement but because he sought further press publicity and obtained it. He took full measure of the opportunity he had of having the ear of the press and he made these very great claims and allegations against this man who had recently been arrested in Thailand: `There is no doubt that this man has been the number one importer of heroin into Australia during the 1980s.' Judge Graham continued:

The same words were used by Senator Tate and he was seen to be uttering them when interviewed by the media during the course of the news program last night. He went on to refer to a belief that hundreds of kilograms had been trafficked into Australia by Prasert Yooyen [in Thailand] since the early 1980s and further stated, `The distribution of hundreds of kilograms of heroin throughout Australia requires a major network and we have intelligence holdings which I can't reveal to you about the nature of that network.
He further stated:
. . . Senator Tate . . . was confident that the disruption of supply would throw the distribution network into disarray and that that would give leads which would be followed up.

As I understand Senator Tate's answer today, he was only talking about some abstract principle or conception; there was a network. He did not have any names and we accept that he did not receive any names. But a network involves many people, and many people in Australia. There was talk about an Australian connection or Australian links, whatever the phrases were. Senator Tate, as Minister for Justice, has gained a great deal of publicity for himself over the years about his commendable work in this fight against drugs. But he has sought and received a lot of publicity for it. However, it has to be about Australians. The connections are not just some abstract thing as a network; rather, they are people. He knows that there has been trial after trial of these people in Australia. When he is thinking about the fact that there would be a great disruption of the supply which would throw these systems into disarray, he must clearly have had in mind the fact that people-Australians, or people in Australia-were being investigated by the police and who probably had been arrested and charged by the police, and who may well be on trial as a result of their participation in these heinous activities with which he has so rightly been concerned.

That is what I find so extraordinary about the defence that so far Senator Tate has put up. He will have to do a lot better when he speaks in this debate, as I understand he intends to do. He will certainly have to do a lot better than his Leader, Senator Button. But in view of the statements that he has made-they are clearly on the record; they are in the judgment; and they were the reasons which motivated the judge in aborting that trial-he must have had in mind, when talking about an Australian link or Australian connection, that there was talk about people who would be the subject of police inquiries and charges. Once one talks about that, one must then think of the possibility of trials.

It certainly was not that there was no defence that Senator Tate was not in any way warned about these things. When one looks at Mr Duffy's letter to the Prime Minister, one finds that there seems to be some failing in communication from the Prosecutor, through the police, to Senator Tate's staff and to Senator Tate. I find it very disturbing indeed that, on such an important matter, there was such inadequate communication. I think that we would have been better served as a Parliament if the Prime Minister, the Attorney-General and Senator Tate had provided us with some better explanation of those very great failings that appear in that communication to Senator Tate. But, despite that, the following fact is now incorporated in Hansard:
Senator Tate recalls that he was told there was nothing to be said by him about any ``Australian links'' but [he said] at no stage was he informed that a trial was in progress.

The staff member told Mr Duffy that in relation to the Australian connection he recalled mentioning names to the Minister, but the Minister's recollection is that he was told nothing about any particular Australian end of the operation and no mention was made of the names of persons, domestic operations or trials. However, it is clear that the Minister was told about an Australian connection and Australian links when he talks about `a particular' Australian. Perhaps there was no reference to a particular Australian, but it must have been in his mind that Australians would have been involved. With all his past knowledge acquired over the years as Minister for Justice about the activities of people in this trade, he must have been very well aware that there were people involved and it was not just some sort of abstract network that he was talking about. It seems unbelievable that when he was told this, he, with his experience and with the responsibility that he was carrying, would not have checked it. When his staff member told him this, if he had checked with the staff and found the staff person had not perhaps got it straight from the Federal Police and then the Federal policeman had perhaps not done his job as well as he was told to do it by the Prosecutor, this sorry episode would never have occurred.
So there is the responsibility of Senator Tate, and that is why we ask that the Senate pass this motion of censure on him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to begin this contribution to what I take to be a most serious debate, because it involves a possible censure. I repeat what I said yesterday: that I do regard this as a matter of great seriousness and, indeed, yesterday in my public mea maxima culpa I think I indicated that I do believe that I was guilty of a serious lapse in relation to some of the matters that I expressed at the press conference last Wednesday. But I greatly appreciate at least Senator Durack's acceptance, apparently on behalf of the Opposition in the Senate, that I was never aware of the trial being conducted in Sydney. That is a very important matter, and not just to be put to one side, because I believe that that at least upholds the integrity of the statements that I have tried to make to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), which have been the subject of his letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in that I have been scrupulously honest in outlining my state of mind last Wednesday, and I am pleased that the Deputy Opposition Leader in the Senate, Senator Durack, at least has not gone so far as the shadow Attorney-General (Mr Peacock), who in his press release has accused me of perverting the course of justice.

SPEECH.PARA: To say that to pervert the course of justice is a most criminal offence is, of course, an understatement. The shadow Attorney-General has accused me in his press release-not in the Parliament, as I understand it, and not subsequently in his media interviews but in his written press release-of perverting the course of justice, which of course requires a quite intentional and deliberate attempt to defeat the course of a particular trial. It is highly defamatory. I am delighted that the Depputy Leader of the Opposition, I take it on behalf of the Opposition parties in the Senate, has withdrawn from making any such accusation against me. So there is no suggestion, apparently, that I ever intentionally or deliberately set out to cause any disruption, any undermining of the trial in Sydney, because I was unaware of it.

I repeat-because apparently Senator Vanstone did not quite grasp the description of the event: The first I learnt of the trial was indeed when I was seated next to Mr Mark Weinberg, the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, 30,000 feet in the air on a flight from Canberra to Melbourne. At that stage he indicated that he had concern. Naturally I shared that concern, but in the confines of the aircraft there was nothing I could do. That was the first time I became aware of the trial in Sydney.

If one asks with what intention or motive I approached the particular issuing of a press release and the press conference subsequently at the ministerial entrance, it was no more than to enhance the recognition by the Australian public of a major international cooperative, collaborative effort involving law enforcement agencies from Thailand, the United States and Australia which led to a major arrest in Thailand. I was trying to point to the confidence in the ability and integrity of each other's agencies which had allowed that cooperative endeavour to have its fruit in the successful arrest of a particular person. That was the only intention and motive which I had in my mind. Of course, as I say, I am pleased that the Opposition is not saying, as appeared to be the case in the press release of the shadow Attorney-General, that I may have intentionally or deliberately set out to undermine the particular trial in Sydney. Nothing could be further from my endeavours as a Minister concerned to stop the trafficking of drugs into Australia.

Senator Durack has referred quite rightly not only to my expression of deep regret at the course of events and my language which led to the judge concluding that he must take the view that a jury might be affected by those particular words which I uttered. Naturally, a jury in a criminal trial should be influenced only by the evidence which is presented to it. I believe that the Prime Minister has indicated by his very wholehearted rebuke which he delivered publicly in the House of Representatives yesterday that the whole Government shares that particular concern. Indeed, it was a very public rebuke. For a Minister to be rebuked in that way in a proceeding in this Parliament is to be subjected to, I can assure honourable senators, a measure of punishment which-whilst it has been underrated, I believe, by Senator Durack-is a very real one to a Minister concerned. It is one thing to face the anger or wrath of a Prime Minister in the privacy of his own office-and that is bad enough-but I can assure honourable senators that it adds a peculiar dimension to the whole process when that rebuke is delivered in the way it certainly was in the chamber yesterday.

Naturally, I submit to his judgment and his language in relation to the matter. No doubt, in his mind, and in senators' minds too quite rightly, the consequences to me would have been far more fatal had I been aware of the trial in Sydney. I think, now we have clarified that no-one is suggesting that I was so aware.

What occurred, fundamentally, was a confusion in the communication to me of vital information which would have greatly influenced remarks I may have uttered last Wednesday. In fact, I suppose-everyone has the luxury of hindsight-that had I been informed of the matters of which I should have been informed, then I doubt whether I would have uttered any words, certainly not at the ministerial entrance, and probably not issued a press release of any character at all.

It has never been the practice for the office of the Minister for Justice to be informed of trials which are pending or are currently taking place. That particular lack of a procedure-as I say, I have never been informed in a structured way of such matters-led to the confusion which I mentioned in Question Time. So in a pressure situation when information should have reached me in a speedy and adequate way, the lines of communication broke down. That is something for which I accept a responsibility and have, of course, at the direction or the suggestion of the Attorney and the direction of the Prime Minister, ensured that procedures are put in place which will allow for a more structured notification of certainly trials in progress and those which are pending. Of course, there are many trials in progress at any one time in relation to trafficking of drugs in Australia. I guess I will have to look at those as they are brought to my notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is it different if you knew the trial was pending? You knew of the arrest.

—In relation to my knowledge of the arrest, I have conceded that I knew of the arrest of certain persons back in January 1989. I find it difficult to give only a partial indication of what was in the brief about the arrest, but I will tell the Senate that I was informed of the names of the two Australians and was informed that two Thais were also arrested. The names of the Thais were not given to me. In that situation-and I think it may help clarify some of the matters which have been put to me by Senator Durack-what occurred was a deplorable situation, in that I was left in ignorance of very vital information. I believe that that matter is now remedied and I think that, in so far as that action has been taken, the responsibility which I have to ensure, obviously, that that saga of events does not recur has been carried out.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I need to say, and I do admit, that in relation to that particular press conference I was carried away by an enthusiasm for the collaborative and cooperative effort which had issued in the arrest of that person in Thailand. I did so because-and I cannot repeat the assertions I made on that occasion-I did regard it of absolutely fundamental significance in the international fight against drug trafficking.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the death penalty?

—I do not quite know the significance of that interjection. It was interesting that on the 7.30 Report last night, where Paul Lyneham made an attack, it was actually the third item-at least in the Canberra segment of the 7.30 Report, which I think is broadcast out of Sydney. The first item actually dealt with the death of two teenage girls in Sydney from heroin overdose. It took me back to the fact that my interest in this matter began in 1978 when I was in Sydney for a conference. I stayed at Kings Cross, went for a walk along Darlinghurst Road and noticed a fellow and his girlfriend slump on the footpath in front of me into the shelter of a doorway; they were obviously high on heroin. I said, `Can I give you a hand, mate?'. He said `Yes. Can you get me down to one of the squats towards Woolloomooloo?'. I bundled them into the back of a taxi, took them down, put them into one of the squats there and went up to the Wayside Chapel and put them on the blanket and soup run for that night.

SPEECH.PARA: What made me very angry at the time was that whilst I did what anybody would do in a one to one situation with vulnerable young Australians whose veins were filled by these unscrupulous profiteers, no-one was getting at the profiteers, the financiers, the business people, the major organisers of the distribution of heroin out of the Golden Triangle into Australia. Therefore, I suppose, when I got the opportunity that I did three years ago to assume this particular role, I did so with some vigour.

In particular, I have concentrated on setting up an international liaison officer network which by some lateral thinking overcomes the fact that we in Australia, being an island continent, have a 3,500-kilometre coastline between Broome and Cairns every kilometre of which cannot be subject to Coastwatch surveillance 24 hours a day; we have almost 700,000 containers crossing our wharves every year; and we have millions of passengers coming through our airports every year. Rather than wait and have our law enforcement agencies try to deal with the matter domestically when heroin arrives in Australia I have been concerned to put AFP officers overseas into our embassies abroad in order to gather information and intelligence and to cooperate with law enforcement agencies, whether in Bangkok, Manila, Singapore, Hong Kong or Cyprus and more recently, of course, in South America in order to combat the drug barons who are targeting Australia with their cocaine in order to generate once again an international cash flow simply to keep their private armies and mercenaries well armed in order to defeat, in Columbia, for example, the oldest democracy in South America.

It is through that particular program of setting in place the overseas liaison officers and my wrenching the Australian Federal Police away from its old duties to streamline it-with 10-year contracts, for example, an absolutely revolutionary change in the way in which police are employed in this country-and through other measures which ensure that most severe penalties, including loss of superannuation, are felt by those who are tainted by corruption in the service of the Australian Federal Police that I have tried to create a situation where drug trafficking into Australia is either stopped in the source country or certainly the information that comes to us enables arrests to take place, charges to be laid and successful prosecutions to take place here.

In all this, senators will appreciate that I would do nothing, given that sort of background and commitment, to bring about the dismissal of a jury in relation to an importing charge in Sydney. I very much, as I say, regret that in the words that I uttered there were strong references to the person arrested in Thailand in a way which assumed his guilt; that is what the judge and the Prime Minister have asserted, and I naturally adopt that characterisation of my language.

But I believe that I can continue to offer to this nation-and I ask the Senate to indicate that it believes I can-service in the particular battle which is being waged in order to shape the future of Australians, more particularly young Australians. Senator O'Chee gave a superb maiden speech last night when he spoke of the way in which young Australians have so much to contribute to the future of this nation if they are allowed to have their full potential realised by an adult society which is prepared to create the conditions in which their creativity and their contribution can be made manifest to the benefit of us all. He was speaking as a young man of 24 on behalf of that generation of young Australians.

It is certainly my great desire that the future of young Australians not be moulded and shaped by the drug barons and war lords of the Golden Triangle as they peddle their drugs in Australia. In so far as I have begun that battle, I ask the Senate to indicate by its vote that it wishes me to continue in that particular task. I do accept, as I have said, that my remarks were most unfortunate, to adopt the language of the judge in the District Court in Sydney. But in the context of my personal ministerial commitment to the fight against drug trafficking, I ask the Senate to reject the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MACKLIN
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the letter written on 9 May by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) there is a sentence which I think sums up the matter under debate. The Prime Minister states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I agree with you that it is most regrettable that the Minister made remarks to the media which presumed the guilt of the person arrested in Thailand and also caused the Judge to conclude that he must abort the trial in Sydney.

I find only one difficulty with that particular sentence and that is the word `and' because, indeed, it was the presumption of the guilt of the person arrested in Thailand that caused the judge to abort the trial in Sydney. That is clear from a reading of the judge's comments. The connection that is made between someone who is guilty in Thailand with the people on trial in Australia is really the point in issue.

Senator Button in his defence of Senator Tate raised the point-and I must say I agree with him-that the press comment made by Senator Tate about the proceedings here, even carried on our national media, will have no effect whatsoever on the operation of the Thai legal system. That is not the point. The point is that the comments that were made had an effect on the operation of the Australian legal system.

I do not wish to speak over long, but simply point out what the substance of the exercise is. It can be seen from the comments that have been made, the documents produced in the House of Representatives and the answers given today by Senator Tate, that undoubtedly Senator Tate knew, first, that a number of people had been arrested last year, including a number of Thai nationals; secondly, that links were alleged to exist between those people who were arrested and others in Thailand; thirdly, the identity of the person arrested in Thailand; fourthly, the alleged links between that person arrested in Thailand and others in Australia. All of those items have come out in the last few days. All of them are in fact readily believable since any Minister doing his job-I have always had a very high personal regard for Senator Tate and the job that he does; he has always seemed to me to be on top of the detail-would know each of those four elements.
The fact is that Senator Tate did not know when he made those comments that the trial was in existence. However, in terms of Senator Tate's ministerial responsibility he should have known.

Nobody has doubted Senator Tate's integrity or honesty with regard to this. What is impugned is in fact the operation of his ministerial responsibility in this matter. The Prime Minister's statements in answer to questions in the House of Representatives very clearly and very directly also impugned Senator Tate's ministerial responsibility. In terms of the various statements that Senator Tate has just made to the Senate, those of us-and I include in this, I am sure, Senator Hill-who have worked with the Minister have absolutely no doubt as to his contribution to the fight against crime. That is not an issue. He has made a sterling contribution to the fight against crime, and that I readily acknowledge.

But despite my personal regard for him, and in fact my party's regard for him, and because of that distinct failing in ministerial responsibility in that he should have known of the damage that would be caused by the remarks that he made to the press and in that he should have known that those remarks to the press would be carried widely, we can do nothing but join with the Opposition in supporting this censure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with the remarks that Senator Macklin has made in relation to the personal respect that I think all members of the chamber hold for Senator Tate and for the way in which he has sought to discharge his responsibilities and his motivation in that matter. Indeed, he and I have spent time in Sydney looking at issues of drug abuse, AIDS policy and youth homelessness in an attempt to find some way in which these matters might be addressed, in terms of national policy, in a way which would not be combative or partisan or indeed which would fail to address those problems directly. That is not the issue. Senator Tate's intentions, Senator Tate's motivations and Senator Tate's integrity are not at issue in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin has rightly said that the question of proper discharge of his ministerial responsibility is what lies at the heart of this censure motion. Senator Tate remarked at the outset that he had made something of a mea culpa; and it is a combination, in terms of his guilt in that sense, of both sins of omission and sins of commission.

The sins of commission are these: first, as one of the most senior law officers of the Crown he departed from the established principle of accepting the concept of a person, whether they happen to be in Australia or they happen to be in Thailand, being innocent until proven guilty. I am not a lawyer but I think the phrase which is used in the texts about this is that that presumption of innocence constitutes the golden thread which runs through the course of common law. Senator Tate, by his comments-not, I might say, throwaway comments or simply on-the-run comments but comments made as a result of putting out a press release at the bottom of which it says, `Senator Tate will be available to expand on the details of this release at 12.15 p.m. at the Ministerial Wing entrance'-and in deliberately choosing to make a statement to the media, made a statement in which the presumption of innocence, the very cornerstone upon which Ministers are charged with the solemn obligation to see justice done, was put to one side and a person was condemned by the Minister in a way which, as Senator Macklin has said, led to consequences in Australia which are consequences that neither Senator Tate nor anybody who has participated in this debate finds to be anything other than absolutely unfortunate.

Secondly, he has caused, as Senator Macklin has said, trial proceedings to be aborted. They were expensive proceedings. But let us leave aside the question of whether they were expensive or not expensive and simply ask the question: can they ever be put back on the footing where they can be dealt with fairly? Will there ever be a situation where that matter can now be looked at without some juror at some stage having formed a view and that view being of such a nature as to permanently call into question the capacity of that trial to be conducted in the way it should be conducted?

If we look at what His Honour Judge Graham had to say, I think we will see in the details of his judgment that in fact that becomes extremely difficult. If we look at the statements made by Mr Duffy and by Mr Hawke, that they hope at some stage in the future it will be possible to deal with these matters, I think we will realise that there are a large number of people who really believe that the answer to that has to be no.
Thirdly, he says, `Well, there is a failure of communications. My staff, the Federal Police, my advisers, whoever-there is a failure of communications'. They are the sins of commission in that sense.

What are the sins of omission? They are, firstly, the question of whether as the Minister for Justice he kept himself properly informed. He has said to us, both in relation to questions he was asked today and indeed in the comments which he made just a few minutes ago in this debate, that in fact it was brought to his attention that certain Australians had been arrested, that he knew their names, that certain Thai nationals had been arrested, but that he had not been informed of their names.

To be informed of their names, Mr President, all he had to do was read the newspapers. On 3 January 1989 in the Daily Telegraph there was an article in which the two Australians are named and the two Thai nationals are named. One of them, as has become apparent, is the person with the same surname as the individual whom Senator Tate has prejudged and whose name appears in Senator Tate's press release of 2 May. He could perhaps look at the Australian on 4 January, where the headline was, `Former Thai M. P. Charged' and the Australian's name is then given. It is a matter of some speculation and it is a matter of some public record that a person who claimed to have been a member of parliament in Thailand was one of those persons who was arrested in these circumstances.

Frankly, for a Minister for justice to say to us, `I was not informed by the police or by my staff or by the relevant authorities of the names of the Thai nationals' is not good enough when the names of those Thai nationals were a matter of clear public record. All that Senator Tate had to do was read the newspapers.

The second point that I make is that Senator Tate has indicated on a number of occasions that there are international drug rings in Australia and that there are distribution networks.
