At the end of those networks, as my colleague Senator Durack has said, there are people who, we hope, will be investigated, will be prosecuted, will be tried and, if found guilty, will be properly and severely punished.

It must be presumed by any Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs that investigations undertaken by the police, for whom he has responsibility, will at some stage lead to proceedings which lead to trials which can be prejudiced by comments made in a pre-trial situation-not just that those comments have been referred to by His Honour Judge Graham, but, as Senator Hill quoted on an earlier occasion, that they have been referred to by Senator Tate in his own speech of 3 September 1988 entitled `The Process of Effective Criminal Law Reform-Some Considerations'.

Senator Tate is a person who not only has experience as a Minister of the Crown, as the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, but who has experience as Dean of the Faculty of Law. He is not a person unfamiliar with the traditions, the principles and indeed the operation of the law in Australia. He knows those things. He is seized of them and on this occasion they have somehow managed to slip from his consciousness as he proceeds-I think somewhat unfortunately-to attempt to bring about a situation in which, in a desire for publicity and recognition, he has exceeded the bounds that properly should have constrained him.

I make just two comments in terms of the editorial approach that has been taken to these matters. In today's Melbourne Age, in a comment by Michelle Grattan headed `An absence of justice and common sense', she writes:

If ministerial responsibility really counted for much, Senator Tate would be on the back bench today. It is hard to think of a clearer case of a Minister being personally to blame for a serious lapse in ministerial behaviour than that presented by Senator Tate's ill-advised comments about a man arrested in Thailand for drug smuggling, which last week led to a judge aborting a trial involving the man's sister and two others.

She goes on as to what are side issues, but says in relation to those that even if they were put aside he would be gravely culpable on two counts: first, the prejudging of the status of the accused in Thailand; and, second, the defence of ignorance of the trial in Australia, which she describes as irrelevant. She says:

It was not as though Senator Tate made his comments on the run. He released a statement on the arrest and called a `door-stop'. It was his responsibility to find out any relevant information before he did that.

That was the point Senator Macklin was making. It was the point we sought to draw in questions today. When he was advised by his staff, as a result of advice given to them by the Australian Federal Police, to be careful about mentioning the Australian link or the Australian connection, was it enough simply to assume that that meant some operational interaction? That can hardly be sustained because the press statement of 2 May makes much of the fact that the operation was a joint effort by Australian, Thai and United States authorities. In other words, here was the clear indication that the success of this particular matter was a result of the operational interlinking between the United States, the Australian and the Thai authorities. Yet what the Minister failed to do was to say, `What do the police mean when they say, ``Be careful about the Australian link. Be careful about the Australian connection''? What is the Australian link? What is the Australian connection?' It cannot be that there was operational interrelationship, because the substance of what I am saying is part and parcel of the success of the operation of the Australian anti-drug campaign. He failed to ensure that he was aware of precisely what that meant, and he should have done.
The second comment I refer to is in today's Canberra Times, where Tony Wright makes precisely the same point. He says:
The Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, in failing to sack the Minister for Justice, Senator Michael Tate, appears to have refined the concept of ministerial responsibility.
He then poses the question that Senator Macklin has posed: whatever happened to the idea of the presumption of innocence? He goes on later to say:

A responsible Minister might, perhaps, have taken the further step of making inquiries about precisely what the AFP meant by `Australian connections'. Instead, Senator Tate issued a media statement and called reporters to a `door-stop'-a mini press conference-to crow about the arrest in Thailand of a man he said was the top heroin importer to Australia. And it blew up in his face. The Minister for Justice had ill-served the cause of justice.

In opening his defence, Senator Button said that all of this was the tip of an iceberg. It may well be in that sense that today's debate and today's questions were the tip of an iceberg. That may well be, but it is an iceberg which under the water at least has to sink the Tasmanian Titanic on this occasion. Quite simply, Senator Tate has failed to discharge his ministerial responsibility to keep himself properly informed. Secondly, as Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, he has traduced that fundamental principle by making public statements about the presumed guilt of a man, which has not yet been proven, and that has had consequences in Australia that may be consequences in terms of the aborting of a trial-a trial which may never be able to be successfully completed and which may result in precisely the opposite outcome to that which Senator Tate and every honourable senator who has participated in this debate would want to occur.

This is an occasion, I believe, on which it is not the Minister's motives or policy that are in question. It is simply the Minister's administrative competence and the proper discharge of his responsibilities as the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs and as a person who, with every other senator, is seeking to eliminate the drug trade and to punish those who are involved in it. That is the issue and that is the nature of the motion. The Minister has failed to discharge properly the responsibilities incumbent upon him and his high office, and it is because it is so manifestly proven that that is the case that the Senate must carry the censure motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to Senator Puplick's address, it seemed to me that what he was saying was that Senator Tate has been guilty of a lot of offences. The first, as I understand, is that he failed to read the newspapers. I am not being facetious when I say that. I think this is what has been put on the other side-that if he was not aware he should have been because he should have read the newspapers. If we are going to censure a Minister for failing to read newspapers, we are on new territory. From now on, all of us here, who are equally responsible to the electorate, will have to read every newspaper that is published in Australia. That is the first thing that Senator Puplick puts.
—It is in his portfolio.

—Senator Patterson says that it is in his portfolio to read the newspapers. I suppose it is in everybody's portfolio to read the newspapers. It is within our responsibility, I say to Senator Patterson, to read the newspapers.
—She did not say that.

—When Senator Short reads the transcript he will see that that is exactly what she said in response to me. The second thing that Senator Puplick said was that the Minister should be controlling the police. What has been advocated on the other side is that there ought to be direct political interference with the police force. That is what was put on the other side.
—What?

—Senator Hill looks up quizzically. Senator Puplick said Senator Tate should have been aware, he should have controlled the police, and he should have known what they were doing. That is absolutely outrageous. It is an outrageous proposition to put that any Minister of the Crown should be in control of the police. It is an outrageous proposition to say that any Minister should interfere with a prosecution taken by the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP); it is just not to the point to say that the Minister was unaware of the internal operations of the police force, because he ought not to be. There ought always to be a considerable distance between a Minister and the operations of the police force.

SPEECH.PARA: The next point he made was that the Minister's comments led to the discharge of the jury-and so they did. That is most unfortunate, but it would not be the first time that a jury has been discharged in this country. Juries are discharged to enable some time to elapse between the controversy that occurs and the start of a new trial, so that the jury can come to the issue with an unprejudiced mind. Of course, the longer this issue is talked about, the further off the trial date will be put.

There will be a vote along party lines on this issue. I am sure that those on the other side will vote in a certain way because of a sense of outrage that prejudging should go on when anybody is coming to trial. Unfortunately, I have not had much time to prepare this speech. If I had time, I would produce copies of Hansard to show what propositions those on the other side put forward when the late Lionel Murphy was being traduced in this chamber. I would be very interested to read what was said about that. What did those opposite say about the fair trial or otherwise afforded to Lionel Murphy? What did they say when Lindy Chamberlain was being traduced in newspapers around the country? Senator Puplick referred to newspapers as if they were paragons. He said, `Look what the newspapers say about this outrageous action by the Minister'. What did the newspapers say about the Lindy Chamberlain affair? What do they say about trial after trial that comes up? What was said by those opposite last year about the so-called black mafia, about Charlie Perkins? What was said about Jim Curran, the Castlereagh by-election and the cemetery votes? I am sure that when I read Hansard I will see that on all of those issues those opposite were very conscious of the sorts of rights that they now proclaim should have been observed by the Minister.

It is said, `Look, the police warned Senator Tate not to mention the Australian link'. He did not mention the Australian link. There is absolutely no suggestion by the other side that he ever mentioned the Australian link.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Walters laughs at that. Instead of laughing, she might produce some evidence. Those opposite talk about the presumption of innocence, yet nobody on the other side has produced one skerrick of evidence.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Harradine laughs during a most serious debate on a censure motion against a Minister. He laughs when I say that no evidence has been produced. If that is the attitude that is being adopted in this chamber, Senator Tate should not be censured; those opposite should be censured.
—How many censure motions have we had against Senator Tate?

—In order to try to bolster the bona fides on the other side, I am asked how many censure motions have involved Senator Tate. The fact is that there has been nothing upon which those opposite could hang anything on Senator Tate until they put forward this flimsy-I use that word advisedly-case against him.

SPEECH.PARA: If those opposite were so outraged about this matter, why did we hear nothing at all from them last week? This matter became an issue only when the Government took it on and said, `This is a serious matter'. Following the reaction of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the matter, the Opposition filed in and said, `Here are some easy pickings. We'll censure this Minister'. I say that there is absolutely no evidence. Everything that has been put against Senator Tate has been put on the basis of inference. The only way in which the Opposition can even reach that stage is to say that the Minister should have read the newspaper or that he should have taken heed of a warning by the Australian Federal Police not to mention the Australian link. That is exactly what he has done. He has not mentioned the Australian link. The police did not ring him and say, `Don't mention this at all'. It has been accepted that there was no statement by the police linking the two names. There was no statement by the Federal Police that a trial was in progress. There was no statement by the Federal Police that if the Minister mentioned the name of a person in Thailand, that would have ramifications here.

If one looks at what the police said, one sees that it was an invitation to Senator Tate to say the very thing that he said. So the warning by the police should not be taken as evidence that he was warned not to speak about the matter. In fact, it was a statement that led him to do what he has done. The police have encouraged him to go ahead and make a statement. They have said, in effect, `Make a statement, but leave out any mention that there may be a connection between this matter and the Australian situation'. It is a flight of fancy to turn that into an absolute warning to say nothing about the case.

People have become very pious about the presumption of innocence. They say, `There ought to be a presumption of innocence', and so there should be. The great scarlet thread which runs through the English law is that nobody should be taken to be guilty unless it is proved beyond reasonable doubt. Those opposite have had no trouble today, on the basis of very flimsy evidence, in saying that Senator Tate has ignored the sorts of rules that apply-and so they should-to this person in Thailand, and to the people here. Apparently, those rules do not apply in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, certainly not by you-by your recent remarks about my laughter.
—Was Senator Harradine laughing when I was making those remarks?
—Not at you.
—If that is the case, I must humbly withdraw.
—You had a go at me and you did not listen to what I said.
—If Senator Harradine says he was not laughing at me, I withdraw unreservedly.
—So you should; you should be nice to him.
—I am always nice to Senator Patterson.
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—It is interesting that everybody, quite properly, becomes very indignant when they are wrongly accused, as I wrongly accused Senator Harradine and, apparently, Senator Patterson. Everybody becomes very indignant when their reputations are brought into question and traduced. That is as it should be, because people are very conscious of reputations. We are very conscious of our own reputations. We jump up and say, `You have done this and that'. Senator Macklin would have to agree that he has made up his mind before he has heard all the speeches in this debate. Before those opposite hear all the speeches they make up their minds to say, `Senator Tate, you are going to be railroaded; you are going to be found guilty of the worst offence a Minister can commit. We have no problems about that. We won't hear your case, we'll just make up our minds now'. Everybody is terribly conscious of their own reputation and gets very upset when I innocently make the odd attack and mistake with regard to Senator Harradine and, apparently, Senator Patterson. Why should they take that approach in respect of themselves--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Have I misunderstood Senator Macklin, too? I apologise to everybody because I accept what they say. But why will they not accept what Senate Tate says?
—You will have to do better than this.
—What about getting back to the motion?

—Was that Senator Puplick? It is a pity that Senator Puplick cannot continue to be a member of the Senate because I think he has adorned this chamber. I will outline what he put forward. He said that Ministers should be responsible. That is to be accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick said that what Senator Tate did on this occasion was to make a statement in circumstances where he should have known about a trial in Sydney. Senator Puplick said, `I accept what Senator Tate says, that he did not know'. So it is established that Senator Tate did not know about this trial. Senator Puplick goes on to say, `But, nevertheless, he should have known about it and, therefore, he is guilty of negligence as a Minister and should be censured'. But I think it is fair to say that the only two criteria, the only two reasons that he gives as to why Senator Tate should have known about the Sydney trial, are, first, that he should have read the newspapers--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, his staff should have.

—No, Senator Puplick said, `It is all in the newspapers'. He held up the articles. He said, `There is the article in the newspaper'. That is the first thing. The second is that the police gave him a warning, which everybody agrees was not a specific warning but, nevertheless, was such a warning that should have put him on notice. As I understand it, that is the case. Is that right, Senator Puplick?
—Don't ask questions across the chamber.

—They are rhetorical questions. Those are the two bases. So it comes down to, as I said before, firstly, that he is to be censured because he failed to read the newspapers and therefore to put himself on notice; and, secondly, that when he got this tortured warning-everybody must agree-from the police he should have understood that there was a trial in existence. The police did not tell him that the sister of the person accused in Thailand was implicated, but they told him not to mention the Australian connection. That is a clear invitation to Senator Tate to say something about the arrest, which he did. So the two bases of the Opposition's argument fall apart.

SPEECH.PARA: I go to the question of Thailand. Clearly, if the person arrested in Thailand had been standing trial in Australia, it would have been most grievous for Senator Tate to have said what he did. But the person is not on trial in Australia; he is on trial in Thailand. And it is no good, without some sort of evidence, saying that what Senator Tate said here is going to affect the trial in Thailand. No speaker here has attempted at any point in the debate to show that the statement made by Senator Tate will have any effect in Thailand. The United States' Attorney-General is always talking about how people have been arrested in other countries, particularly in South America, and nobody seems to take exception to that. I do not take exception to that, because what is said there does not affect any trial that might take place in the United States.

When one looks at Senator Tate's actions, one must look at them in terms of what the consequences have been-and, indeed, Senator Puplick has quite rightly said that. The first consequence has been an aborted trial in Australia. There are many aborted trials in Australia, and that is to be highly regretted. Secondly, it is said that there have been consequences in Thailand as a result of what the Minister has said. There is just no evidence of that at all. So one really comes down to wondering what this is all about. There has been no suggestion in the debate so far that Senator Tate has been dishonest, that he has been perverse, that he has been anything but honourable. All he is accused of is making a mistake, and when one looks at that there is really no evidence upon which to base the mistake.

I finish by saying that we either take these matters seriously or we do not. We either take this matter of censuring a Minister seriously or we do not. We either go round on a consistent basis or we do not. If honourable senators who debated the Murphy affair are now going to take a different approach to the voting in respect of this censure motion against Senator Tate, are any of the honourable senators who are going to vote against Senator Tate able to point to any unequivocal evidence that shows that he knew, or even ought to have known, about the trial in Sydney, other than that he should have read the newspapers? He did not know and not necessarily ought he to have known. The Opposition's only argument is that he ought to have known.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he did not know. Everyone has accepted that.
—Senator Macklin says that it comes down to the question that he ought to have known. Why should he have known? Because he ought to have read the newspapers?
—He ought to have been on top of his portfolio.
—Why should he know in terms of his own portfolio? Senator Newman raises her head here. This is the point I am trying to make.
—The Prime Minister has accepted that he should have known.
—That is the interpretation of the Prime Minister, which I say is wrong.
—In other words, you disagree with him.
—I do disagree with the Prime Minister, because a Minister for justice and an Attorney-General should be at a distance from the Director of Public Prosecutions.
—And, therefore, not making an announcement at all.

—The office of the Director of Public Prosecutions was established and set up specifically-and Senator Newman ought to know this-to distance prosecutions from the Crown. That is the whole idea of a DPP.
—So he should not be involved in the announcement?

—So the DPP has the duty to run prosecutions in the country, not the Attorney-General and certainly not the Minister for Justice. The DPP should be able to operate at arm's length from any Minister. So, in my submission, it is absolutely wrong and false to make the presumption that because we have a Minister for justice or an Attorney-General, under whose general jurisdiction the DPP and the police operate, they should know the details of what the DPP and the police do; in fact, they should be kept at a distance from the details.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition cannot get away from the fact that voting for the censure motion and against the Minister today would establish the principle that the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice should have a direct input into what the DPP and the police do. If one takes that position, one is throwing aside a whole tradition. The more one thinks about it, the more dangerous the principle that the Opposition is going to proclaim today becomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the presumption of guilt?

—I do not want to go into that. Senator Tate is being censured on a party-political basis. There is no basis on which the Opposition can properly censure him. Senator Tate has acted correctly. He has kept his distance from the prosecution and he has kept his distance from the police, as he should. As soon as there is political interference with the running of the police and the DPP, disaster follows. That is the sort of basis of the states that were established in eastern Europe. Fortunately, they are moving out of that.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the consequences of what Senator Tate said have been unfortunate. I advise Senator Tate not to be so florid in his expressions in the future, but the use of a florid expression should visit upon him not a censure motion but perhaps a warning. Senator Tate has seen how this debate has progressed and how honourable senators have got up and declared the way they would vote without waiting to hear from other speakers, including me.
Opposition senators interjecting

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, am I allowed to say that that laughter was directed to me?
—I do not know about that.
—Right. No doubt about it.
—Order! Senator Cooney, address your remarks through the Chair.

—I am, Mr President. I will finish on this. The coalition has had its party meetings and Senator Macklin has had party meetings and they have decided that this is a day to censure Senator Tate because it is early in the parliamentary triennium. We have a three-year Parliament still and this is a good victory early on for those opposite who hope that they can make their point-and away they go. That is fair enough. That is how politics are played and Senator Tate will just have to accept that, but I would not make much of the censure motion. I love you all over there. You really do not know what you are doing but what you are doing unfortunately-
—What about your side?
—We are the goodies over here. Listen to this, because this is a serious point. I have said it three or four times but I will come back to it. Honourable members opposite are establishing-
—You are trivialising it.
—I am not trivialising it. That is the only argument those opposite have had. They have said I am trivialising. I am not trivialising it.
—You are, very much.
—Simply because I have told the truth? Is that what it is?
—His reputation is under attack and you are trivialising it.
—But his reputation is under attack on a party-political basis.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators-No.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is. I can tell honourable senators opposite this: when the vote is taken nobody from the other side will not come over this side to vote.
—And no-one from your side.

—Nobody from our side will not go over to the other side to support Senator Tate, and nobody from the Australian Democrats will not come over to support the motion. The only person who will be making an independent decision is Senator Harradine. Yet honourable senators opposite say that I am the one trivialising this debate. What is trivialising this debate is the event that is now to take place-the vote.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON HEALTH LEGISLATION AND HEALTH INSURANCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Peter Baume on behalf of Senator Hill) agreed to:

(1) That the committee known as the Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, constituted by a resolution of the Senate on 13 June 1989, be re-constituted under the same terms and with the same functions and powers.

(2) That the committee have power to consider and use for its purposes the minutes of evidence and records of the Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance appointed in the previous Parliament.
(3) That the committee present its final report on or before 29 June 1990.
(4) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.

Message No. 3
The House of Representatives transmits to the Senate the following resolution which was agreed to by the House of Representatives on 9 May 1990 and requests the concurrence of the Senate therein:

That, in accordance with section 54 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984, matters relating to the powers and proceedings of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority shall be as follows:

(a) That the committee consist of 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips or by any independent Member, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(b) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(c) That the committee elect a Government member as its chairman.

(d) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall act as chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting.
(e) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the chairman, or the deputy chairman when acting as chairman, have a casting vote.
(f) That 4 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(g) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any subcommittee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.

(h) That the committee appoint the chairman of each subcommittee who shall have a casting vote only and at any time when the chairman of a subcommittee is not present at a meeting of the subcommittee the members of the subcommittee present shall elect another member of that subcommittee to act as chairman at that meeting.
(i) That the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the members of that subcommittee.

(j) That members of the committee who are not members of a subcommittee may participate in the proceedings of that subcommittee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(k) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(l) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to move from place to place.
(m) That a subcommittee have power to adjourn from time to time and to sit during any adjournment of the Senate and the House of Representatives.
(n) That a subcommittee have power to authorise publication of any evidence given before it and any document presented to it.
(o) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.
(p) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to consider and make use of the evidence and records of the committee appointed during previous Parliaments.

(q) That, in carrying out its duties, the committee or any subcommittee, ensure that the operational methods and results of investigations of law enforcement agencies, as far as possible, be protected from disclosure where that would be against the public interest.
(r) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.

Message No. 7
Mr PRESIDENT,
The House of Representatives transmits to the Senate the following resolution which was agreed to by the House of Representatives on 9 May 1990 and requests the concurrence of the Senate therein:

(1) That a joint standing committee be appointed to inquire into and report on such matters relating to electoral laws and practices and their administration as may be referred to it by either House of the Parliament or a Minister.

(2) That the committee consist of 10 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips or by any independent Member, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 2 Senators to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4) That the members of the committee hold office as a joint standing committee until the House of Representatives is dissolved or expires by effluxion of time.
(5) That the committee elect a Government member as its chairman.

(6) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall act as chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting.
(7) In the event of an equality of voting, the chairman, or the deputy chairman when acting as chairman, shall have a casting vote.
(8) That 4 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(9) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any subcommittee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.

(10) That the committee appoint the chairman of each subcommittee who shall have a casting vote only and at any time when the chairman of a subcommittee is not present at a meeting of the subcommittee the members of the subcommittee present shall elect another member of that subcommittee to act as chairman at that meeting.
(11) That the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the members of that subcommittee.

(12) That members of the committee who are not members of a subcommittee may participate in the proceedings of that subcommittee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(13) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(14) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to move from place to place.
(15) That a subcommittee have power to adjourn from time to time and to sit during any adjournment of the Senate and the House of Representatives.
(16) That a subcommittee have power to authorise publication of any evidence given before it and any document presented to it.
(17) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.
(18) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to consider and make use of:

(a) submissions lodged with the Clerk of the Senate in response to public advertisements placed in accordance with the resolution of the Senate of 26 November 1981 relating to a proposed Joint Select Committee on the Electoral System, and
(b) the evidence and records of the Joint Committees on Electoral Reform and Electoral Matters appointed during previous Parliaments.
(19) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
Leo McLeay
Speaker
House of Representatives,
Canberra, 10 May 1990

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Mr President, I introduce the Bill into this House in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services.

The High Court recently ruled that the Government does not have the power to supplement a determination of the Remuneration Tribunal to provide postage entitlements to honourable members and senators. The Government has been advised that whilst the High Court was not required to rule on the question, its decision placed in doubt the provision of benefits having a pecuniary value unless provided by or under legislation. That advice indicates that if the High Court were asked to decide the issue it would probably find that, on the basis of S. 48 of the Constitution supported by the Separation of Powers Doctrine, only the Parliament can make provision for such benefits.
Many of the entitlements and facilities available to honourable members and senators have been provided by successive governments, in some cases since Federation.

Apart from postage the entitlements which are not covered directly by legislation or indirectly by any Tribunal determination include travel in Australia for official business by Parliamentary office-holders; travel overseas on official business by the Leader and Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the Presiding Officers; the provision of office accommodation, home telephones and equipment for the four opposition office holders and the presiding officers in a capital city; the provision of postage in relation to the official business for Ministers, Opposition office holders, presiding officers, the leaders of minority parties and the whips. For honourable members and senators the entitlements not similarly covered are overseas travel as a member of a parliamentary delegation; travel in Australia for purposes related to parliamentary or electorate business; electorate office accommodation and equipment; postage; personalised letterhead stationery; Australian flags and printed material related to national symbols for presentation to constituents; publications available from the Australian Government Bookshop; and the transfer of bulk papers between Parliament House and the electorate office.

In relation to the provision of a postage entitlement to honourable members and senators, the bill provides an entitlement up to the limits determined by the government for 1989-90 until future postage entitlements are determined by the remuneration tribunal. The tribunal is to be asked to determine the postage entitlements of honourable members and senators for the financial year 1990-91. Other entitlements covered by the bill or new or supplementary entitlements can be varied or approved either by reference to the remuneration tribunal or by regulation.

In view of the doubt expressed by the High Court on the provision to date of benefits having a pecuniary value which are not provided by or under legislation, the bill validates all benefits of a kind described in the bill which have been used by or made available to the parliamentary office holders including the leaders of the opposition and to honourable members and senators at any time prior to its commencement.

The bill also provides a legal basis for honourable members and senators to continue to receive their entitlements for the same periods they receive their parliamentary remuneration. This is relevant to honourable members seeking re-election on the dissolution of this house or to a senator seeking re-election on a double dissolution.

Consequential amendments are also necessary to the remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 to support the provision in the bill that the benefits listed in the schedule to the bill shall be omitted or varied only if referred to the remuneration tribunal for determination or by regulation.

Mr President, the high court's decision has raised serious issues which have cast doubt on many of the entitlements available to honourable members and senators to enable them to fulfil their parliamentary and electorate responsibilities. The government has moved by introducing this bill to rectify serious anomalies which, in some cases, have existed for many years.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum for the bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON ANIMAL WELFARE: REPORT ON SHEEP HUSBANDRY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

It was very interesting to receive this nine-page response to the 155-page report. Nevertheless, I must say that, as a member of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare I am reasonably pleased with the response from the Government, albeit that it was a little delayed. One of the most interesting things that comes out of this report on sheep husbandry is the fact that the Government has commented on the balanced reporting. In other words, the evidence given in this report reflected the views of all those people concerned with animal welfare and with the sheep industry. The Government summed this up and the importance of this Committee in point 4 of its response when it said that sheep husbandry is one of the several animal welfare issues which have assumed national significance. It stated:

International concern over those issues is directed at Australia as a whole, tarnishing both Australia's national image and that of the sheep industry. Such concern has led on occasion to threatened boycotts of wool and other sheep products and even of the Australian tourist industry in a misguided effort to force discontinuation of practices such as mulesing, which are considered by some members of the international community to be unacceptable.

It is pleasing that this matter was aired publicly and the opportunity provided for animal welfare groups and the industry to put their points of view. At the end of the day, the Committee came up with a unanimous report that has been accepted by not only the industry but animal welfare groups as being a reasonable indication of the current situation. The Government has noted that. There are two important matters that come out of the report. One is the matter of mulesing, which is a practice looked upon by many as being barbaric and unjustifiable. On the other hand, the industry regards it as something that is very important in sheep husbandry. I might say that if this practice had been banned, as was suggested by some people who gave evidence to us, the overall effect on the wool industry in Australia would have been catastrophic. It is pleasing to note that those people who were most critical of the mulesing practices have accepted the Committee's view that until further research has been done and other ways of treating flystrike are developed, mulesing should be accepted. That was one of our recommendations and it is one that the Government has accepted.

The other major recommendation the Committee made concerned the huge loss of lambs. This matter was brought to our attention by animal welfare groups. One person giving evidence claimed that up to 11 million lambs a year were lost as a result of weather conditions and so on. Subsequently, I think, those claims proved to be exaggerated but, even taking lower figures, it was a matter on which the Committee felt moved to make recommendations. I must say I am a little disappointed in the Government's response. It did not support our recommendation; it pointed out that lamb losses are multifactorial and that, even though management practices may be adequate, other factors affect mortality. The factor quoted was that a large proportion of maiden ewes when coming out of drought could cause a higher lamb loss. We put forward the view that it was a national responsibility to encourage more shelter belts and planting of trees on farms to effect shelter for ewes that are lambing. I still believe that that is a matter the Government should have supported.

This being our fifth report, I am pleased to see that the Government has realised the importance of this Committee and the fact that it provides an arena where people who want to raise matters on animal welfare can put their views. The Committee endeavours to report in a balanced way, and there is no doubt that reports such as this have taken the heat out of what could be very divisive arguments in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support Senator Calvert's remarks and the recommendations by the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare in its report on sheep husbandry. We well know in Australia the importance of the wool industry, which is still worth around $5 billion. On top of that, we have the Australian sheep meat market and the live sheep export market. That is in trouble at this time but it is worth some $150m to $200m a year. As Senator Calvert has pointed out, the main criticism of the sheep industry relates to mulesing. I believe that the practice of mulesing has been the most forward move in the handling of sheep in the last 20 years. I believe that it compares, roughly, with the advent of pre-emergent sprays in the wheat growing industry in the last seven or eight years. The reductions of flystrike in sheep means a reduction in deaths from blowfly strike caused by the weakened constitution of the sheep.

SPEECH.PARA: It has also caused an immense reduction in the cost of wool production. The other night at dinner I was speaking to a Victorian who had just moved into sheep farming. He asked me how many men would be needed to tend 1,000 sheep for the whole year round. I surprised him by telling him that if everything was done correctly, with the help of shearing contractors, mulesing contractors and whatever other contractors are required for sheep farming, one person should be able to tend a flock of 15,000 sheep for the whole year round. So, that has to be considered.

Another point that the animal welfare lobby raised concerns mulesing. It looks barbaric when one first sees it, but the animals make an immediate recovery from this operation the day after, and further down the line smaller amounts of chemicals are used on them for the rest of their lives. Before the advent of mulesing, the sheep had to be virtually dipped in chemicals to prevent fly strike. Chemicals got into the wool and problems would arise overseas as a result. The animal welfare lobby and welfare groups around Australia tend to want people to use fewer chemicals. I also want to use fewer chemicals, which means lower costs. But one has to undertake a number of practices so that chemicals are not required. If that can be done by mulesing, well and good. I commend the Government and the Committee for making such a recommendation.

The Committee recommended, and the Government accepted, that more research be done into using other methods, and I commend them for that; if they can find a better way, so be it. Furthermore, I am also happy to acknowledge that the Committee and the Government accepted that more money should be spent on harvesting wool by means other than the current shearing methods. The advent of a successful method will be a long way down the track, but I certainly commend the Committee's recommendations on improving mechanical methods, because the Australian shearing industry could run short of manpower if as many keep leaving the industry and are not replaced, as occurs now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to take just a few moments to comment on the Government's response to the report by the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare on sheep husbandry. Before addressing that directly, I would like simply to welcome the reinstatement of this select committee in this Parliament, particularly, as I think, has been mentioned by Senator Calvert, the contribution that is made by this Committee to rational debate in an area which, in many other countries and before the establishment of this Committee in this country, was running the risk of becoming an area fraught with emotionalism on very good grounds on both sides of the argument. The Committee has provided a forum for rational discussion for all the issues to be fully aired and for productive development in the whole area of animal welfare. It is a Committee which was established on the motion of the first Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp. I would also like to pay tribute to the work of my former colleague, Norm Sanders, who was our most recent representative on that Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I, too, as both previous speakers have done, want to talk specifically about the question of mulesing and about how that has been dealt with in the Government response and in the report. Before I do that, I would also like to pick the point Senator Calvert made with regard to lamb lossses. I was brought up on a not particularly big farm, which was a mixed grain and sheep producing property on mallee fringe land in the Victorian Wimmera. I regret to say that, when we sold that farm on the death of my father, the tree shelter belts which he had left as a more traditional farmer of a past era, were immediately bulldozed down. I was back on that farm just a couple of years ago and noticed very distinct signs of land degradation and some evidence of dryland salinity creeping in. I regret that and I believe that one of the major issues in lamb losses has been the reduction of shelter belts in the past couple of decades. That episode that I speak of happened almost 20 years ago, but in the preceding 30 or 40 years that farm's lamb losses were very low.

In that area, too, and moving now into the requirements for mulesing, which the industry has found necessary in recent years, I think it is important to say that, to me and from my personal experience, animal husbandry means that the animals are husbanded by, if you like, a human being who cares about them and who has the opportunity to care for them on a regular basis. Senator Panizza mentioned that one person can look after 1,000 sheep and that possibly some of these techniques are necessary in that situation. My view is that we need more trees, but I think also that those people responsible for animals who are concerned about many of these practices, whether they are animal producers or animal lovers, would all agree that if we could have more human content in animal husbandry, we would treat our animals better. I welcome the Government's response to the recommendations in the Committee report that continued research into all means of preventing blowfly strike be a priority so that the need for mulesing is removed.

It is clear that the economic difficulties faced by all our primary producers has been an imperative towards some of these practices that have not been widely accepted in the community, and I think we do have to look at, for instance, funding of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in particular in the excellent work it is doing in this area. The Democrats have been critical of reductions in that area, which have very heavily impinged in a whole range of areas on the needs of rural industry. So, that and the other recommendations with regard to mulesing that support the work that is being done are strongly supported by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with other honourable senators in supporting this motion. In its comments on many of these recommendations, the Government has stated that they lie outside its sphere of responsibility. It notes that sheep husbandry was one of several animal welfare issues that had assumed national significance. The work of this Committee, which has achieved a great deal since it was set up, is a Federal issue. Although it is a Federal Committee, in the stricter sense many of the matters lie outside areas of Federal Government responsibility. But it is the only opportunity, at the Federal level and, generally speaking, dispassionate level, to examine such issues as mulesing, which Senator Panizza, Senator Calvert and others have talked about. I am pleased to note that the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare on sheep husbandry have been accepted by the Government. That is the only sensible course of action. Anyone who sees flyblown sheep will understand the reasons for the use of the mulesing method. Even some of the most radical people in the animal welfare areas are now realising that. The choice is either that method or the use of chemicals-or looking after stock much more closely, which is not possible in the wide areas of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me suggest, though, that in places like Nyngan there is no possibility at this stage, with all the flood problems, of people taking a close look at their stock.

The Government supports our calls for an increased commitment to research efforts. But, having supported us, the Government is not prepared to put up any of the additional money which is needed for research to help in a lot of the areas mentioned in the Committee's recommendations. I am disappointed in that because I believe the Government is rather cynical in this regard. It supports the recommendations but is not prepared to assist with any funding. I think the Government should put its money where its mouth is. Some of its responses I cannot agree with. For example, it says ultrasound testing is too expensive. I do not believe that is the case. I think that if we are to save a lot of the more expensive stud animals the Government should take up that recommendation.

Another recommendation that the Government did not take up, in what I think is a bit of a cop-out as well, is the recommendation that the State and Territory governments increase the number of Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (RSPCA) inspectors authorised under the relevant State prevention of cruelty to animals legislation and provide additional funding to support them. The Government says it does not support that because it believes that to be a responsibility only for the States. I believe the Government should have come up with some money that would have made animal welfare inspections in the livestock industries a lot better. Generally people in sheep husbandry are very mindful of looking after their livestock in a most humane way because that is how they get the best profits. They are not inhumane in any way and I commend them for that. But some people are not so humane and we would be better off with RSPCA inspectors checking to see that they do toe the line properly.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I would like to speak to the report of the National Science and Technology Centre in a manner that I hope will encourage people to take a much greater interest in it now that it is an accomplished fact and working so well. This report covers the period of 1988-89, which was a nine-month period of operation for the centre. The fact that it is within walking distance of this building is something that I hope people will take into account. I hope that they will take the opportunity in due course to visit the centre.

In the first nine months of operation, 365,000 people went through the centre, of which 60 per cent or thereabouts were adults. I think that is very good. We need a lot more people to go through and we need to spread the good news about the centre to as many people as possible. It is very much a vital operating centre and it has a lot of advantages. The objective, as stated on the first page of the report, is:
To promote a greater awareness and understanding of the present and potential contributions of the application of science and technology so that:
* young Australians are stimulated to pursue education and careers in science and technology, and;
* the community is better informed, and seeks out and uses applications relevant to their particular needs.

The centre's aims and objectives are very reasonable, and I am always very pleased to have discussions with Dr Michael Gore on the operation of the centre from time to time. He did a magnificent job previously with the establishment and operation of the old Questacon unit. The new centre is one of the best centres of its type in the world. More and more people around Australia are being exposed to the centre through the visits that it pays to various places. The sponsorship list is growing and includes some of Australia's major companies as well as international companies-companies such as ICI Australia Ltd, Shell Australia Ltd, IBM Australia Ltd, Telecom Australia, NEC, and Coles Myer Ltd. The dedicated people at the top of the organisation-a very good advisory committee headed by Sir Neil Currie and his deputy, Sir Laurence Muir-have got the Centre established and flourishing.

I know that in due course it is the intention of Dr Gore to invite all members of parliament to look through the centre. This is a bipartisan matter and both sides of the Parliament intend to do everything they can to advance the cause of the centre and of science. The country depends upon so much in the scientific area.

I trust that the people who are able to gain some appreciation of the advantages of science by seeing it in operation will be able to use it more in their daily lives and encourage others to become associated with it. In this way we will become less dependent on overseas assistance in so many ways. We have slipped a lot in the last few years and it is only by getting people to operate in a more scientific way, using the advantages that flow from science and technology, that we will recover.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of my colleague opposite. I think what Senator Archer said-particularly about bipartisan support for the national Science and Technology Centre, about its past and about its future is very important-and I am happy to say I agree with all of those comments. This centre has been running very efficiently and effectively. I certainly want to add my voice in urging people to go along and have a look at it. But most importantly, once one gets to have a look at it, one gets to have a go too. It is a hands-on learning centre and is therefore very different from many other museum-like places where people are asked to look only. In this centre one actually gets to have a go.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we should also note that the centre marks Japan's major contribution to the Australian Bicentenary. In view of some of the nonsense that has been spoken-and indeed anxiety people have expressed-about things like the multifunction polis, perhaps we should acknowledge that, properly managed, international contributions from one country to another can be a matter of celebration and need not be cause for anxiety or fear.

It is interesting to read the report of the National Science and Technology Centre. I think in some ways it portrays a lot of the character of the people involved in the centre. I congratulate Michael Gore and all those involved with him on the board on the way they have set up the centre and continue to run it in the efficient and beautiful way it is being run.

Not often does one get reports that actually have a heading called `Accelerated Evolution'. Particularly in a journal on science one could begin to think, `This definitely needs reading. What is accelerated evolution? What are they doing down there?' Actually, it is not a story about genetic material but about how quickly the idea for the centre was brought to fruition. The language of the report, in fact, does encourage one to read it, but I think it also indicates the sort of imagination and humour with which this centre is being promoted. The heading `Visitor Peaks and Troughs' is also an interesting one. One could imagine all sorts of strange things.

The section of the report headed `Safety and People-Proofing' shows the seriousness with which this centre has guaranteed safety so that when people are experiencing the hands-on displays at the centre neither their safety nor the safety of the centre is jeopardised. It is a matter of considerable importance and, as the report says, considerable cost. The humour that is used to interest people in what science can be and what science means characterises the centre and all those involved with it.

It might be entirely predictable to say that I was delighted to see in the mathematica room the very significant posters around the wall featuring significant mathematicians from history to note that every second poster actually refers to famous women mathematicians. I will not actually ask whether anybody here can name them. I have practised some of their names; I have certainly read about them in other places, but IBM's contribution to that mathematica centre, to those posters, to the book it produces and the way it actually acknowledges extraordinary women mathematicians down history I think is a matter of some considerable excitement. In science and technology centres we do not expect to find an acknowledgment of women's contribution in history, although they have made a huge contribution. Part of our history, part of our science centre has to be to remind people of those women so that they can discover not that women are learning science now, but that they have done so since time immemorial. They have just been forgotten or overlooked. So I am delighted that very famous women mathematicians are there alongside the famous men. I sincerely hope all in the Senate can eventually answer the questions of who they are.

I think too that I like the way the centre challenges people to appreciate the relationship of science to art and the relationship of science to everyday living. It is those experiences-the chemistry and physics in the kitchen, things which are often used to denigrate science-which in fact ought to be used to encourage people to see that science is part of everyday life.

Science and technology ought to be matters of excitement and enthusiasm for everybody in this society and this community. Clearly we need to encourage the number of people who know about science who visit this centre and of course make use of the opportunities, if they cannot get to Canberra, to visit the Questacon travelling science circus too when it goes in and around their area. I understand Senator Teague would like a word if he can get in in time. I pass over to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague, I should warn you that the time for consideration of government papers expires in just over a minute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I will be very brief, but I would have liked to have expanded upon this very welcome first report of the National Science and Technology Centre. It was opened 18 months ago and is in fact a permanent gain for all Australians of the bicentennial year. It cost $20m to establish, half of which was given by the Japanese Government and Japanese business with a $1 billion yen donation. So in this important joint venture between Japan and Australia we have this permanent science and technology acquisition here in the Parliamentary Triangle in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate Dr Michael Gore in particular whose original ideas at the Australian National University where he was researching and teaching physics led to Questacon, a marvellous institution, in a disused secondary school here in Canberra. My own children have visited it many times and as a former graduate in physics and maths I encouraged them to do so. Now, greatly enhanced from those years of experience in Questacon, we have this marvellous centre. I would love to speak much more of it and will even if only when the legislation to give it statutory foundation comes before us later this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Time for consideration of government papers has expired. The Senate will deal now with General Business. In the peculiar circumstance of this session, the General Business is in fact the papers we have not yet dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to continue to refer to a few more matters that are set out in this report. It is a lively, colourful and innovative piece of communication because it gives us, in a refreshing way, a lot of information about the first nine months' operations of the National Science and Technology Centre. I long hope that there will be a continuing sense of innovation not only in what the centre does but also in the way in which its material is presented to the Parliament and to the public, such as in this report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report is a different kind of report also in that the Centre at the moment in legal terms is an extension of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It is only when we have before us legislation to give it statutory authority that we will then receive annual reports in the usual form by which the law establishing and determining all aspects relating to the Centre will no doubt require them to be presented to the Parliament. So when that transition goes to normality I make the plea that the presentation not be normal but continue to be extraordinary and set the pace in giving an up-to-date means of presentation.

I want to say a little more about Questacon, the original proven concept that has been widened and made more permanent by the establishment of the Centre. Questacon is a word that is derived from a combination of the Latin verb `quaerere', to seek, and the medieval word `con' meaning to learn or steer, as in a ship. The genius of Questacon was that the physics and mathematics exhibits were hands-on to those who came to experience the Questacon centre; so too are they now in the National Science and Technology Centre.

Both children and adults coming to the Centre learn not only by looking but also by touching, feeling and manipulating; so they are participants in science and technology to the extent that they move from one exhibit to the next, so it is a very active and not passive introduction to new ideas about science and technology. It has long been stated in this chamber by a number of my colleagues, including Senator Archer and Senator MacGibbon, and by me, that this country will prosper to the extent that we encourage a proper, full understanding of the potential of science and technology.

As a former Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, you, Mr Acting Deputy President, likewise share this commitment to enhancing in Australia a fuller knowledge of all the potential of science and technology. But this centre is not only about science. It is not only about what is true about the world in which we live; it is about translating science into technology, into invention, into those processes that will improve the environment in which we all live, not only in Australia, but also the world.

We want to give that type of insight and enthusiasm to increasing numbers of young and old Australians. I am delighted to see that more than a thousand a day are visiting the Centre and I strongly urge Australians to take up the opportunity of gaining from this national treasure which, as I said earlier, is one of the permanent gifts of the bicentennial year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak briefly on this report. As Senator Teague said, it has been a theme of mine that the application of science and technology to the Australian community and the educational requirements flowing from it have been sadly neglected and downgraded since the early 1950s in this country. We enjoyed a great surge of support in the late forties and fifties for science as a consequence of the applications of science in the Second World War. Somewhere along the road from the mid-fifties onwards and particularly by the mid-sixties, the support for science, particularly in the universities, tapered off. Nationally we are paying a very high price for it today and it will be many years-15 or 20 years-before we can recover the position we should have.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting to be at lunch today with Admiral Watkins, the Cabinet member responsible for the Department of Energy in the United States of America, who talked about the priorities of the Bush Administration in America and how its fundamental task was to re-establish knowledge of science and mathematics in the American community through the educational system. It is an absolute priority with them in order to rebuild the capabilities of the United States, commercially and in all other ways.

I visited the National Science and Technology Centre here some while ago. It was actually one weekend when we were held here while the airline dispute was on. I had been meaning to get there for quite some while after it had opened, because I had the privilege about 20 years ago of visiting the Toronto Science Centre.

Without being discourteous to the board of the Centre here, I was disappointed on two grounds. I was disappointed because a large number of the exhibits, although they had been in place only for some months, were not working. I think that on two of the floors about one-third of the exhibits were not working at the time. I have not been able to go back since then and that may have been a transient, coincidental occurrence, but it is terribly important in the concept of this type of museum that the exhibits work all the time, because what we are trying to do here is demonstrate basically not only to children but to the whole community the application of scientific principles in various ways.

The other disappointment I had about the centre was its scale. The costs in setting that up really are very high and that obviously places a limit on what was done. I hope that the board of the Science Centre has ambitious plans to develop further. What impressed me so much about the Toronto Science Centre 20 years ago when I saw it was that it took discrete areas of activity-communications, for example-and would have a whole centre on everything from early smoke signals through to the early telephones, telephonic communications, the old manual switchboards, electronic switchboards, and radio communications. The Toronto International Airport was actually being broadcast in part of the room, and people could use the equipment there and see the full application of modern communications technology.

Similarly, with other things like lasers, there were little corners of the building where one sat on the floor or on steps on the carpet and used lasers to burn holes in bricks and things like that. Students from the university were talking about the basic principles involved. I think this is enormously important, because science is a living entity and it has to be seen in its relevance to the community. I support very much the concept behind this. I wish it well in the future and I hope the vision of the board is absolutely limitless.

The Australian Safeguards Office (ASO) is the body which has to do with nuclear safeguards, and I really want to restrict my remarks to one particular aspect. While safeguards, of course, have to do with two aspects of protecting radioactive materials, namely, the possibility that those materials maybe used for nefarious purposes unrelated to the civil use of those materials, they also pose a health hazard in relation to the possible escape of radioactive materials from any part of the civil nuclear fuel cycle. That is the part to which I wish to draw attention.

I am referring specifically to page 21 of the report, in which the ASO mentions that one of the problems it is faced with is zero real growth of the agency budget and the increasing size and complexity of the nuclear fuel cycle and the allied problem of information treatment. What I wish to pick up here is that, while the global standards for radiation exposure have been set by the International Commission on Radiological Protection, which was established in the 1920s, those standards have been implemented in each nation by national bodies. In this country, of course, they are implemented through the processes of the National Health and Medical Research Council.

If one looks at what has happened over time, one finds that the allowable levels to which workers in the industry may be exposed have been reduced progressively from the mid-1920s until the present time, when the allowable level for industrial workers is 50 millisieverts in this country, although in several other countries the allowable level has been reduced to 15 millisieverts per year. That, I understand, is the situation which may obtain in this country in the near future.

That recent reduction from 50 down to 15 is based on a reworking of the evidence in relation to the Hiroshima-Nagasaki survivors. The point of my remarks here is to draw attention to some very recent work published in the British Medical Journal on 17 February 1990 which looked at the incidence of leukaemia in the children of men who had worked in the British nuclear industry and were exposed to really quite modest levels of radiation.

They began with the workers in the reprocessing plant at Sellafield and discovered that the leukaemia incidence in the children of workers who were exposed to only 100 millisieverts of radiation in total, which is only two years at the present maximum allowable level, was between six and eight times greater than the leukaemia incidence in those who were not so exposed in the course of their occupation. Indeed, they looked at a number of other nuclear establishments and found that there was a linear dose-response relationship which went right down to much lower exposures at Aldermaston and Dounreay, in the case of Aldermaston 7.8 millisieverts total radiation exposure, and 47 millisieverts at Dounreay. These were both associated with a substantial increase in the leukaemia rate of the children of the men who were so exposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would it be in their children rather than in themselves?

—Unfortunately, in the short time available in speaking to papers I cannot go into the detail of this but I can, if you like, give a detailed genetic explanation as to how this can come about. But it does raise-and this is the point I want to make-the very serious question of whether even the present possible reduction to 15 millisieverts is anywhere near enough. I think what we will see with the ASO and similar bodies is the need to very substantially reduce this allowable level of radiation still further. That is a problem which will be faced by the National Health and Medical Research Council, by the ASO and by a number of other bodies, and it poses a very serious problem for the civil nuclear industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

In the short time I have available to me I would like to say a few words about the Defence Housing Authority, whose annual report for 1988-89 is now before the Senate. As honourable senators would be aware, this is an authority for which I have a great deal of time. Certainly a lot of other government authorities could take some lessons from the efficiency with which this organisation has been set up and gone about its duties in providing good quality housing of a community standard for our defence forces. I have often on other occasions spoken of the detail of the work been done by it and I do not intend to do that this evening.

I want to raise two or three matters relating to the work of the Defence Housing Authority which I believe should be given attention by the Government and by the defence forces. The current arrangement is that the defence services themselves allocate the quarters which are owned and maintained by the Defence Housing Authority. It is my personal belief that that arrangement is not working as well as it might, and I urge those in authority to reconsider the automatic assumption that the defence forces are the best people to allocate particular houses to particular individuals. It makes for complications of a number of kinds and, in my view, it is time to consider changing the arrangement.

Certainly amongst the tenants of the Defence Housing Authority there is real concern that the Government proposes to change the policy governing the level of rentals that they pay. Honourable senators would be aware that servicemen get a certain element of subsidy for their housing, partly because it has been recognised for many years that their housing has been of a very poor standard. More important, perhaps, for the long term future is the fact that they are required to live in places where they would not normally choose to live. They are often places with some social deprivation and iso- lation, and that is recognised in rental subsidies. I would like to see the Government put out a definitive statement-and the new Ministers are in an ideal position to do that-reassuring the defence population that there is no intention of reducing the level of rental subsidy.

The Government should also be looking much more seriously than it has to date at assisting Defence Force personnel to acquire homes of their own. The previous Labor Government made a mess of changes to the defence service home loans scheme and subsequently introduced a new scheme which, under scrutiny, has proved to be not a terribly satisfactory alternative and is certainly no great encouragement to home ownership. These things are examples of fiddling around the edges. I would like to see a fresh look at the whole question of housing Defence Force families, with greater emphasis being given to the benefits that would accrue both to the taxpayer and to the Defence Force families themselves if much more generous assistance were given to them to acquire their own homes. One of the problems being faced at the moment by those who own their own homes is that they are liable for capital gains tax if their service takes them away from their home for more than four years. I urge the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to change that quickly. Those people are not living away from their homes by choice.

Another matter which has bedevilled the housing of Defence Force personnel over many years is the question of scales and standards. The minimum level of housing standards applicable to Defence Force personnel, depending on their rank and their family levels, has become the maximum in many cases. It is a rigid, uncaring system, which I believe, with the advent of the Defence Housing Authority, should now be done away with.

The Defence Housing Authority is involved in joint ventures, which I welcome. However, it is currently involved in a major program at Tindal Royal Australian Air Force base of upgrading brand-new houses. I understand that something like $1m has to come out of the Defence Housing Authority's budget to repair work which was inadequately supervised by Australian Construction Services (ACS) only a year or two ago. That is a serious condemnation not only of the contractors concerned but, much more serious, I believe, of ACS which should be held in contempt for its failure to carry out its professional duties.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
