I have much pleasure in rising to speak on this annual report of the Australian Wheat Board on its 50th anniversary. The Board was born out of the disasters of the 1930s, when thousands of wheat growers and their families were driven off their farms. It was the combined efforts of the farmers of Australia and the Government of the time that got the Australian Wheat Board going exactly 50 years ago. I congratulate the Board on its performance over that time.

The report points out that for the 1988-89 season the Board achieved an average card price of $US175 a tonne. That, of course, gave a return to Australian farmers on the average of between $190 and $200 per tonne, which is a marvellous effort compared with the 1986 season, when we had virtually a record low price. Honourable senators will remember the triggering of the guaranteed minimum price, of which Senator Walsh has reminded the Senate so often. This price rise was helped along by the North American drought, which was unfortunate for farmers there but slightly more fortunate for the Australian wheat farmers because it pushed prices up.

Some innovations have been achieved in the wheat marketing system, as the Senate was told earlier today in a question to Senator Cook, who represents the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. One of those changes has segregated stockfeed wheat, for which the grower can now be paid immediately rather than having to wait for payment over the next couple of years. In answering the question Senator Cook pointed out the importance of the current system of payment based on protein content, where the price rises in accordance with each decimal point of increment in protein content. For instance, taking the average of 10 per cent protein content, the increment above Australian standard white (ASW) price is on average about $15 a tonne.

The Minister explained why the protein content of Australian wheat is declining. Indeed, eight to 10 years ago the average protein content of Australian wheat was 11 per cent; it is now down to less than 10 per cent. One explanation the Minister did not give, and it has a certain degree of credibility, is that the price of fertiliser in Australia has risen at a far greater rate than has the price of wheat, and by reducing the amount of fertiliser used, the protein content of the wheat is reduced. There are certain areas on the south coast of Western Australia-where Senator-elect Crane, who will be here on 11 July, comes from-where by the use of superphosphate on light land he has told me he is producing wheat with a protein content of up to 15 per cent. That is a great achievement.

We have experienced the first season with a deregulated domestic market. Although I have been a strong critic of that deregulation, I think it has been a worthwhile experiment. I suppose the experimentation will continue virtually for the rest of our lives, but I think that with that 17 per cent, and taking into account a few minor downsides in the system, deregulation has worked reasonably well in its initial period. It is now up to the Government to keep its side of the bargain by deregulating the other areas that it promised it would-namely, the waterfront, coastal shipping and the labour market. These are necessary parts of the deregulation package that the Government has told us about, which will go a long way to making Australia more competitive in overseas markets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

I congratulate the Pig Research Council on its annual report and on its efforts to increase commercial returns to members of the pig industry and the community in general. As I read the report I note that last year the Council supported a total of 89 research projects in universities, colleges, State and Commonwealth departments and other institutions and appropriate companies. These projects involved most aspects of the production, processing and marketing of pigs and pigmeats. I also note that $2.5m was distributed in accordance with the Council's research and development plan, with the principal areas of research being in pig health, growth and nutrition, meat processing and breeding.

The Council most definitely should be encouraged in its efforts to maintain study into this vital industry. But we should not fail to remember that while we may be funding research into the industry it is important to not then kill off the industry with short-sighted, sometimes well-meaning, but disastrous policies which can affect this industry. I refer in particular to the importation of Canadian pig meat into Australia, as well as the general economic crisis facing the man on the land.

Conservative estimates have shown that the importation of Canadian pig meat will force 20 per cent of pork producers out of the industry, as well as have disastrous spinoff consequences for the grain industry. It is hard to reconcile this fact with the knowledge that one of the objectives of the Pig Research Council is to increase the commercial returns to members of the industry and the community in general by improving production, processing, storage, transport or marketing. What is the use of improving these areas when there will be no one to operate the pig farms? In fact, I wonder how much consideration the Government gave the matter when it decided to allow the importation of Canadian pig meat, in light of current record unemployment levels in rural areas and the downturn now being experienced in economic conditions in many rural industries. How much consideration was actually given to the devastating effects this decision will have not only on those directly involved in pig farming, but also on such industries as those covered by the Queensland Bacon Employees Union? I think the answer is: very little.

It is not only this short-sighted action which affects the pig industry. Also, many of the policies taken by this Government since it came to power are crippling those involved in primary industries. There is not much point in producing a product if it cannot be sold profitably. Similarly, it is not much use to so rationalise our rural sector that we eventually see the demise of the family farmer-the person who spends unrecognised hours and efforts producing that end product. I have made many trips over the years throughout my State of Queensland and realise the value of primary industry and the tremendous contribution it makes to the economy. With regard to this annual report of the Pig Research Council I am concerned in particular about those people who are so worried about the fact that the cost of running a large piggery these days outweighs the amount that they can expect to get for the pig meat that they produce. I do not see how people in any industry, whether it is farmers in the pig industry or the people we have just heard about in the wheat industry, can keep on going when the costs are just so hard. There are just so many costs. The price of fuel alone to all these rural producers is just so hard. I feel very sorry for them, and I can well understand why, at a meeting of the Burnett task force the other day, the pig producers were saying that it was hardly worth while carrying on because the costs are so excessive.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I bring to the attention of honourable senators the work of Dr Murali Nayudu. He has applied to the Wheat Research Council for funding, but I cannot see his name listed as a recipient. I hope that for his and the industry's sake his work into the problems of the fungus take-all can continue. Take-all is an economically devastating problem for the wheat industry and is estimated to cause a loss in production of $200m annually. This is likely to be a conservative estimate, given that little evaluation is made of crops lost as a result of take-all.

There is a lot of disquiet in the community about getting value for money, and that is what everyone in this Senate is always concerned about. Much of the criticism levelled by farmers against research institutes, such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, concerns the relevance of the research being undertaken for farmers. This particular project is supported by farmers, who have had a direct input into Dr Nayudu's work. He is a molecular geneticist at the Australian National University actually working in the field with farmers. He has been up in the particular area where I live where take-all is quite a serious problem. He is learning at first hand what the problems are and finding workable solutions that are able to be applied in the paddock where the solutions need to work, not just at the laboratory bench. I believe that the Wheat Research Council should take a very close look at his work and seriously consider giving him funding. As I say, I cannot find his name in the Wheat Research Council's annual report. Hopefully, when I stand up here next year we will see it, because it is a very important area.

This sort of commitment to rural industry needs to be supported and nurtured, and it is this sort of project that the Federal Government ought to be talking about when it talks in glowing terms about its new commitment to science. Of course, we have had all these new commitments to science given by the Government during the last election. Let us hope that the Government meets the promises it has made and does not back away from them.

This report is a good report. Research is absolutely essential. With the exception of the person I have mentioned, I would be very happy to endorse the report in its entirety, but obviously the Council will have to think very seriously about where it spends its money. I just repeat that I hope that in the next report I see Dr Murali Nayudu as a recipient of research money for the root disease take-all which ravages the New South Wales wheat crops.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ABORIGINAL DEATHS IN CUSTODY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

What is extremely interesting about this report of the inquiry into the death of Mark Wayne Revell is that in the first section, entitled `Introduction and Synopsis', there are some general statements which are pertinent to each and every one of the reports of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. In fact, under the heading `The task of the Royal Commission' Commissioner J. H. Wootten states that the death of Mark Wayne Revell is in many ways typical of the deaths, concern over which led to the establishment of the Royal Commission.

Wayne Revell is described as a restless, unfulfilled Aboriginal who spent hours drinking, a man who was detained for a reason arising out of his intoxication, who disappeared into police custody where no-one but the police had access to him and within four hours of being put in a cell was found hanged. Some time later his relatives were told that he had hanged himself, and they were told this by someone who appears to have revealed few details about what happened. So, naturally enough, the relatives were distressed, devastated and puzzled. The Commissioner states that there was no independent or thorough investigation at the time. There was a ritualistic gathering of exculpatory statements, and those in their turn were rubber-stamped by an equally perfunctory coronial inquiry in which the relatives were represented in a token way or virtually no way at all.

This is one of the dreadful indictments of the whole system, and it does not apply only to Aboriginal deaths in custody but often applies to all deaths in custody. In fact, one case is currently being heard in the State of Victoria of a young non-Aboriginal woman who died under extremely strange circumstances in Pentridge Gaol. The Commissioner in his report states:

Had there been at the time an open and understanding attempt to meet the concerns of the relatives; a thorough, independent investigation; and a real attempt to confront and deal with the underlying issues which led to the occurrence of the tragedy, no Royal Commission would have been necessary.

Indeed, our coronial system often is simply a rubber stamp of what the custodians of the time have said had been the cause of death. The aims of the Commission are stated very clearly in the first section. The Commissioner asks, `Why do Aboriginals die in custody in such appalling numbers?'. He found:
. . . the much higher death rate is not to be found in discriminatory treatment in custody.

Indeed, if we look at the statistics in my own home State of Western Australia we see that there are approximately equal numbers of deaths in custody for Aboriginal people and non-Aboriginal people, but of course very many Aboriginal people are imprisoned compared with the percentage of Aboriginal people in the population. Commissioner Wooton states:

If white Australians had died in custody at the same rate as Aboriginals between 1980 and 1988, there would have been some 7,000 deaths in custody, or about two per day, and no doubt a Royal Commission would have been established much earlier.

The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody will not complete its work but will close down later this year. The work has been valuable but it has not been valuable enough. The Aboriginal people feel that in certain cases charges should have been laid where death has been caused by neglect or extreme negligence, so there is some cynicism about the whole Commission itself. This is to be regretted, but what is to be commended are the sorts of statements which we now have written and inscribed into reports such as this one.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

The progress report on this program of transferring nursing education from hospitals to tertiary institutions reports on the period 1985 to the present. To all intents and purposes it looks a very satisfactory report, and I welcome it. The program seems very progressive and, as I understand it, the nursing profession itself has welcomed it. One point of importance at the moment is that this year is the first time that Queensland has joined in the program, and it is hoped that by 1993 the transition will be completed throughout Australia.

Currently the program is training 9,500-odd nurses, and it is hoped that by its completion it will be training 18,000 nurses a year, which is considered adequate for Australia's requirements, and I hope it is.

It seems that two streams of nurses are involved in the transition. Some of them are trained in the hospitals at the moment. Of course, they receive their clinical and theoretical training in the hospital and receive payment while they are there. The other stream attends the colleges of advanced education. They are treated the same as other tertiary students and do not receive payment. They have a varying schedule that supplies their clinical training and theoretical training, which can be in the proportion of 60:40. In other words, they would be at the college of advanced education for 60 per cent of the time and then spend 40 per cent of the time in the hospitals, for which they are not paid, but of course they would be treated like all other tertiary students then.
The nursing profession seems happy with the program. I congratulate the people who are running it and look forward to its completion in 1993.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that:
(i) the recent floods in the west of Queensland and NSW have been the worst in a hundred years, and
(ii) many families and individuals have lost their possessions and suffered great hardship and many local businesses cannot be re-established without substantial aid;
(b) recognises that it is now 3 weeks since the onset of the floods and that the task of rebuilding is urgent;

(c) calls on the Federal Government in concert with the state governments, to explain in detail, as a matter of urgency, what help financial and otherwise will come from government sources so that those people affected can plan for the future reconstruction of their lives and communities;

(d) further notes that, for the towns downstream of the floods, appropriate planning was greatly hindered because no accurate predictions could be made of the likely flood levels given the complex geography and the variables involved in the great western river systems as opposed to the eastern coastal rivers; and
(e) calls on the Federal Government to fund an adequate research program as a matter of urgency so that an accurate computer model can be generated and developed to aid planners in future floods.

Major floods have recently afflicted western Queensland and western NSW, the worst floods we have seen for 100 years. I want to raise a matter in the Senate tonight in a bipartisan, apolitical way for the welfare of the people out there in western Queensland and western NSW. There are three topics I would like to cover. The first is the immediate provision of emergency services; the second is the provision of emergency services in the longer term; and the third is prediction services for these regions-prediction services relating to future flood levels and velocity flows of water through the area.

Dealing with the first of those topics, the immediate emergency services that were provided, and having visited those areas in western Queensland on a number of occasions, I think the immediate response was excellent, particularly from the uniformed services. The Royal Australian Air Force and the Australian Army gave excellent service. They provided all the resources that were required at the time. We had a little talk about Chinooks in Question Time today, and I will come back to that in a moment. I would also like to mention the Queensland police because I think that very much maligned sector of the Queensland community performed marvellously in the service of the community, as did the Queensland State Emergency Service, which is recognised as being the best organised and best developed emergency service organisation in the country. We did not seem to have much of a problem, if any at all, in Queensland with law and order, pillaging and things such as that, although there were accounts of such problems in other States.

I reinforce what the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) said this afternoon about the provision of the Chinooks. The equipment provided by the services was perfectly adequate for the task and certainly no lives were lost. Undeniably, had the Chinooks been available they would have been extremely useful but, as the Minister said, the correct decision on that is on their military application. Do we have the military requirement for them? The answer to that is absolutely, unambiguously yes, and the decision of the Government to withdraw the Chinooks from service, which was purely a cost saving measure, was one of the monumental acts of stupidity in recent years in relation to the Services. However, I make the point that the emergency services that were provided at the time were excellent.

The second point in relation to emergency services, the longer term provision of aid, obviously leaves quite a bit to be desired. The floods that afflict western New South Wales and western Queensland are different in nature from the floods that habitually affect the east coast in areas such as the Hunter River in New South Wales, the Mary River Valley in Queensland, the Burdekin, and those other eastern coastal streams. The differences are twofold. First of all, there is a good predictive service with the coastal streams on the eastern coast because people experience these floods relatively frequently, every three or four years. They know from experience that if they get 20 inches of rain in 48 hours in the headwaters, the water will be 10 feet high in the main street of a town or something like that. So there is a good predictive service.

The second thing about it is that help is always at hand because in the coastal cities there are hills as well as valleys. While a flood is quite devastating for those people whose businesses or houses are in the submerged areas, it is possible for them to seek refuge and to have support close at hand. It is entirely different out in the great western inland areas, where there is a very flat landscape, and for people in those towns that become inundated there simply is no refuge. It might be 100 miles for them, if they can travel on roads that are under water, before they get to dry ground and can get accommodation and food. So the scale of what is going on in the west is really quite different because of the flat terrain and the isolation.

While the immediate emergency services were excellent, the difficulty those people face now is knowing precisely what the State Government and the Federal Government are going to do to help them re-establish their lives and their communities. The paper shuffling in the bureaucracy and all the rest of it is going on. It has been three or three and a half weeks since these houses were flooded in some cases and these families do not know what sort of financial support they can get from either the State or the Federal government. I think that is quite wrong. They should be told as soon as possible what help is available because they have to make a decision whether they are going to try to re-establish their lives in those communities, and re-establish the communities themselves, or whether they are going to go to another part of Australia to re-start their lives. I have a view that it is not very onerous for the Commonwealth to give the businessmen and the families in those areas a remission on their personal income tax for the financial year 1989-90 to help them become re-established. Without minimising in any way the complexity of the need for financial support for these people, I believe the matter ought to be hurried up so that they know where they stand and can get on with the job.

The third point is the one I want to spend a little time on tonight and that is the development of predictive services. We really do need to know what is going to happen when we have abnormally high rainfalls in the central part of this country. We simply do not have any predictive services at present. It is a matter of saving life. When these floods occurred there was a total absence of an ability to predict how high the flood would be in various areas. Given the terrain, about which I was speaking before, a very flat landscape and no way of readily being able to move to higher ground, it becomes very important. Being so flat, the roads and rail services go out, and the only way one can move around there is by air, and in some cases the airfields go under. Perhaps there is a creek, as in the case of Cunnamulla's, between the airfield and the town itself. A predictive service is absolutely vital. If the water height can be predicted, in all these cases there is time, probably weeks, from the time the floods are in Longreach to the time they reach right down to the bottom of the Darling River in southern New South Wales. In Queensland it takes a couple of days before the Thomson River at Longreach flows down and ends up in the Warrego River, if indeed they link up. Certainly, in the case I am thinking of, there were probably 48 hours between the flood peaks in Charleville and in Cunnamulla.

In that situation one of the difficulties faced by the Army and the State Emergency Service was the worry as to how high the flood water was going to get in Cunnamulla. As I said before, the road from the township to the airport crosses a creek and was underwater. There are about 1,500 people in the town, and the debate was whether, if levee banks were built, they would be high enough, in which case there was no need to evacuate the town. If the water rose above the levee banks, there would have been 1,500 men, women and children in the township and no way of extricating them. In the end, the decision was taken to leave the people in the township and, fortunately, the levee banks kept the water out.

That led me to think what we could do in similar circumstances, which will undoubtedly occur in the future. Having looked at the matter, I believe it is possible to make a prediction. We need to spend some money on a research program and develop a computer model. The technology exists at present to put on computers a database of the terrain. There are such techniques as digital terrain modelling by which a digital topographic database can be created; in other words, the characteristics, the heights and all the physical features of the countryside can be recorded digitally and inserted into a databank on a computer. From that information, it is then possible for hydrologists, civil engineers and scientists to make predictions taking account of the soil types and vegetation. If they know the amount of rainfall that has occurred in the area, they can estimate where the water will go and make a prediction as to what flooding will occur in these towns.

We are doing that at the present time, albeit slowly. The Army Survey Corps has this in hand for various parts of the country. AUSLIG, the Australian Land Information Group, which is the old national mapping group of the Commonwealth, has this capability, as do, of course, the State mapping agencies. It is certainly a big exercise and it is expensive to put all that information into a database in a computer. But from a national point of view we need it, and there will come a day when the topographic features for the whole of Australia will be recorded in a database in a series of computers.

What I am putting to the Senate tonight is that the Federal Government should direct those agencies which have the power to prepare this database to acquire the data for western Queensland, western New South Wales and any other parts of Australia where it is appropriate, and fund them accordingly. Then, when we are are faced with future floods, the emergency services and relevant authorities can say, `Well, given that amount of water we will have, in the main streets of Cunnanulla and Nyngan, a flood level of eight feet, so we had better evacuate everyone.' It could be a matter of life saving importance.

These situations, rare though they might be, will occur in the future, and I believe it is a very worthwhile exercise for the Government to embark upon. We have been talking about heights of flood water in the western towns. The same technology will enable us to estimate flow rates. Some of the damage I saw in those western towns was caused not only by the houses and buildings being inundated by water but also by the velocity flow through there. I would estimate that some of the flows were as high as 25 to 30 knots, and that is surprising. When one looks at the flatness of the land, one would not think that the water velocity would be that fast. But it is possible to predict the velocities and the heights. I think that the community would benefit from such a move.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter before us this evening is quite a serious matter in relation to the floods which have occurred in Queensland but they are in no sense unique, in that in this country we have an extremely variable climate. I suppose the most noticeable feature of the Australian climate is its variability and the fact that we are subject not only to floods but also to quite horrendous bushfires from time to time consequent upon long periods without rain. For instance, at present in South Australia we have had to reinstitute the fire warnings, which is the first time on record outside the fire season. The Adelaide Hills is an area which is very subject to bushfire and which essentially has had no rain since the weekend of the Grand Prix in Adelaide in October, I think it was.

SPEECH.PARA: So, we have these problems of the intermittent and unpredictable occurrence of extremes of weather and the consequences in terms of flood and bushfire. But I cannot agree with Senator MacGibbon's suggestion in relation to computer modelling for the reason that he is assuming that the weather of the future will be like the weather of the past. I think we need to understand that with the very rapid changes in the composition of the global atmosphere, it is extremely likely that the weather of the future will be very unlike that of the past. To think that we can make predictions in relation to the future based on the past is, I think, to misread what we now understand about global climate changes.

Although the floods in Queensland have been described as the hundred year flood, it may well be that in the next century the flood return times will be once every 10 years, because another feature of the changing climate which is well understood by climatologists is that the changes in the extreme will be much greater than the changes in the mean; in other words, the frequency of occurrences of extreme events such as drought or flood will increase quite dramatically even with quite slight shifts in the mean temperature. Whilst nobody has yet said-and I certainly will not be saying-that a number of events around Australia in recent years are due to greenhouse warming, nonetheless climatologists are saying they are consistent with what one would observe if we were experiencing greenhouse warming. The Queensland floods fall into that category, but so do the four or five extremely heavy rainfall periods that have occurred in and around Sydney.

As I have indicated, the extremely dry weather which we are now experiencing in South Australia is absolutely without precedent and bushfire warnings have had to be given outside the regular bushfire season. I think the idea that we might establish a computer model which in some way will be able to predict either the occurrence of these events or the consequences of the events is rather unlikely. I certainly would support Senator McGauran to the extent that the collection of data on land forms and those sorts of things which, given certain rainfall, would allow one to predict the consequences of the heights of floods might be useful. But being able to predict the frequency of occurrence of these events and to plan where to put houses and how high to put them-the cost-benefit type analysis-is simply not possible, given the changes which are likely to occur.

Looking at many of the houses that went under water, it seems to me that one could make a more sensible suggestion along the lines of, what happened in Darwin, where after the cyclone the building regulations were changed so that all houses had to be able to withstand winds of a certain velocity. We now have in Australia extremely good ferroconcrete techniques which are used for building boats and, rather than put houses on concrete foundations, one could imagine these low-lying houses being built on ferroconcrete foundations which, in the event of flood, would simply allow the houses to rise and float; and, as the flood went down, the houses would settle back more or less where they were, provided they were sufficiently anchored. So one could envisage quite feasible changes in building regulations which would substantially reduce the degree of damage should such an event occur again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wouldn't it be better to put them up three or four feet?

—Senator Boswell has just suggested that it might be better to put them up three or four feet. But as I understand it, the topography of the area in which these floods have occurred is very flat and it would be somewhat difficult to find raised ground to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: There are several other matters to which I would like to draw attention in relation to this matter of so-called natural occurrences which may have relatively minor consequences or, in some instances, very devastating consequences. One relates to the matter of insurance against these events. It is particularly true in the case of a bushfire-the natural disaster which we have suffered from particularly in South Australia-that often the consequences of a particular action bear no consistent relationship to the initiating cause. For instance, as happened in the Ash Wednesday bushfires, wires may clash together and start extensive bushfires. If those wires clash together in mid-winter and sparkes fall to the ground, the consequences may be quite trivial. But if they clash together and fall to the ground in times of very strong north winds and a temperature of perhaps 40 degrees centigrade, the consequences can be quite disastrous. So the initiating cause very often bears little relationship to the final outcome.

This raises the very vexed question of appropriate insurance in the case of these so-called natural disasters. I believe that it would be appropriate to establish a national insurance scheme which would fund the cost of recovery from these sorts of events over and above the amount which it would be reasonable to expect individuals-or indeed anything up to State utilities-to insure themselves against. The effect of that would be that these excessive levels of damage-which occur rarely but may occur more frequently in the future, as I have indicated-would be covered by some sort of a national insurance scheme.

I raise my next point in relation to the recent floods particularly in view of an answer given by Senator Ray to a question at Question Time today. He seemed to be arguing that the military defence forces should not be used for civil purposes. The question was particularly in relation to the use of certain helicopters. The gist of his answer-if I understood him correctly-was that, while he would perhaps consider the retention of these particular helicopters for military purposes, he would not consider their retention for civil purposes. In the opinion of the Australian Democrats, that is the wrong way to look on the whole defence establishment. We would certainly prefer to see a defence establishment which linked both military and civil defence into the one set of organisations.

I turn again for a moment to the question of bushfire. We have been proposing for quite some time that, under military control, there should be a fleet of the Canadian CL215 aircraft, which was developed in Canada for the water bombing of bushfires. These aircraft could also be used to ferry troops, or they could be used for the interception of boats engaged in illegal fishing around the north coast of Australia. They could land beside an illegal fisherman, somebody who was drug running or importing exotic diseases or carrying illegal immigrants-anything like that. These aircraft would be capable of landing right beside vessels, boarding them and making arrests then and there. That would be a far better way of dealing with the situation than the current method of so-called surveillance in the northern parts of Australia.

It is but one example of the way in which we believe there should be an integration of the military services in-and let us hope it will never be necessary-the defence of Australia and in a civil defence program, which of course is necessary and is quite frequently called upon in the event of natural disasters like fire and flood. Moreover, it would give the military a clear role in the event of these civil emergencies. It would, therefore, help to allay much of the ill feeling in the community against the retention of substantial military forces in peacetime, when it is thought that military people simply sit around and do not do very much. If they were integrated into a civil defence program, then they could be seen to be extremely useful.

I think the relationship between the defence forces and the public would be very much improved by such a program. That would mean that the purchasing of military hardware would be done with an eye to its use in the event of such things as the floods in Queensland. A clear role would be defined for the military forces in the event that one of these disasters occurred. We strongly recommend that the shape of Australia's military defence structure be reoriented along those lines.

We see that there is a considerable need to address more adequately the problems which occur in Australia quite frequently but in an unpredictable fashion-the problems of fire and flood. They are a feature of the Australian environment. We are not convinced that the sort of computer modelling which Senator McGauran suggested would be able to make the sorts of predictions precisely, because the weather in the future is going to be, we believe, with substantial evidence, unlike the weather in the past. Nonetheless, we believe that successive governments in the past made inadequate provision for these, in a statistical sense, `predictable' disasters. In that occurrence we should direct attention to adequate national insurance which would cover the costs over and above the reasonably insurable costs by individuals and organisations. There should be an integration of the civil and military defence programs and under such a scheme there would be an easier way of dealing with these events when they inevitably occur in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 191 I seek leave to make an explanation on the grounds that I have been misquoted and misunderstood.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —At no stage did I talk about making predictions on climatological changes. I do not wish to debate that tonight and it was not part of my speech. All I was saying was that as a consequence of high rainfall it is possible to make predictions of the effect of the run-off of the water from that high rainfall. That is quite different from talking about the changes which might or might not occur as a result of the greenhouse effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point-and I really take more exception to this than anything else-is that I was called Senator McGauran!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I draw your attention to the lack of a Minister in the House at present. I request that a Minister be in attendance because I believe it is part of the Westminster system. I would like my contribution tonight to be heard by someone who will be able to take it into Cabinet. I will continue with my remarks while maybe the Government Whip or person in charge can muster one of the Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the motion moved by Senator MacGibbon. I know that Senator MacGibbon went out to western areas soon after the floods. Tonight I want to speak mainly about the Queensland floods. My colleague Senator Brownhill who visited the western areas of New South Wales will take up that particular issue and Senator McGauran will talk about the floods as they affected the Gippsland area of his State, Victoria.

I would say most disasters in Australia are subject to some type of insurance, whether fire, earthquake or storm and tempest, but in the case of the floods that inundated western Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria there was very little, if any, insurance cover. In the areas of Blackall, Jericho and Augathella very few people had insurance cover. Maybe one or two in Blackall had some insurance cover. The cost of insurance is prohibitive so the people affected are completely dependent on the charity of people in Australia who answer calls for donations and government assistance to get them out of financial trouble.

In Queensland, the loss is estimated by the Queensland State Government at over $100m. Three hundred thousand sheep and 11,000 cattle were lost at a cost of about $7.5m; 9,000 kilometres of fencing was swept away at a cost of $15m; the damage to dams and machinery is estimated to cost $7m. They are Department of Primary Industries and Energy figures. That adds up to around $30m for rural losses and that does not count the damage to homesteads and the contents of rural properties.

In Charleville, 159 of the 160 businesses sustained damage. The whole of the business area was under water. I think only one service station in the whole town did not sustain some type of loss. Out of 1,470 houses or dwellings, 1,180 were damaged. Alpha, Jericho, Blackall and Augathella sustained similar losses. The estimates for the houses and business areas are $2m for the clean-up, $4m for personal assistance, $25m for housing, $13m for contents, $6.3m for business and $30m for infrastructure, a massive loss in those areas. Added together, it comes to a total of more than $14m. That has been taken from the ecomomy of western Queensland and has to be replaced if Charleville and those other towns are going to have a viable future.

A lot of help has been given, but it has been self-help and help from people living in adjoining areas. Adjoining shire councils sent men and equipment. Fire brigade equipment and trucks came from as far as the Gold Coast and all the adjoining shires. The grazing community answered the call by putting their firefighting and jetting equipment on the backs of trucks and jet spraying the houses, despite their own considerable problems and losses.

The state emergency services came from all the adjoining shires and towns. They came from as far as Gympie, Crows Nest and Toowoomba. The Army erected a tent city at the airport and fed, quartered and housed 4,000 of the townspeople for nearly a week. Special thanks go to two people there that I think should be mentioned. Cam Russell and Dale Wilson flew their mustering choppers all night until they were just about in conditions that were dangerous to themselves and their machines. They flew the small choppers around the hospital and hovered them over the roofs and evacuated people until the military helicopters could arrive on the scene.

The fact is that the help that has been given to these towns has been magnificent, but now the cleaning up is just about over, massive financial problems are emerging, particularly in the business community. I want to address my remarks to the business community at the moment. The Queensland Government sent in a team of assessors who assessed the preliminary damage to the business area to be around $6.3m.

I have spoken to the business people and to bank managers and managers of other financial institutions out there and they consider that amount to be very much underestimated. I think what has happened is that the loss assessors went into the major streets and assessed the retail businesses but they did not look for the shearing contractor who was operating not from commercial premises but from his home and whose house went under water. Such people would probably have $50,000 worth of shearing handsets and trucks and all the equipment that is needed to sustain a business. They did not assess the losses of kangaroo shooters who lost their rifles; of plumbers, carpenters, and all the other types of businesses run from the home.

Bank managers and other business people have assessed the losses at much more than the $6.3m that the Government has estimated. The position out there is that a number of businesses now are forced into having to restock their premises, having lost just about everything. Not unlike all Australian businesses, they have been only stemming the tide of the high interest rates, and any further losses or any further borrowings would put them out of business.

A couple of businessmen told the Premier and the Deputy Prime Minister when they visited that, even if they were given loans on non-interest terms, they would have to think very seriously about whether they could accept them because, together with the commitments they already have, they did not see that there would be any way that they could repay any additional loans, even if they were non-interest loans. So it is absolutely essential that some types of grants are offered to these people to help them get through their time of need now.

I called on one lady who ran a shoe store out there. I asked this lady whether she would mind me using her name and she said that she would not. Her name was Noreen Hendle. She had been running a shoe store out there since 1949-not a big business but a business that gave her and her family sustainable living. She is now, I think she told me, around retiring age and she had the mortgage on her business secured by a mortgage on her house. She had just purchased her winter stock and, together with her normal lines, which completely went under in the flood, she has lost something like $70,000. She is faced with the prospect now of borrowing a further $70,000 to restock her shop or just walking away and not being able to trade out. Then she wonders what will happen to the mortgage on her home.

She is typical of a number of people in that flood area that are just sitting there at the moment trying to make a decision. These people-there are 130 of them in Charleville-need to know immediately what type of assistance can be offered to the business community. They are uncertain what direction to take and what financial decisions to make. The Premier has promised assistance, but it is now three weeks since the flood and, while there is a promise of assistance, no actual assistance plan has been put down. These people are beginning to become edgy at the moment.

I asked yesterday in the Senate whether the Government could make its assistance plan known to the people, because they have been sitting there for the last three weeks wondering what direction they have to take. If there is no assistance in the form of grants, many of those businesses will have to close. If the businesses close, that will directly affect the viability of the town because one business depends on the next business. If the chain is broken, then the town loses its viability.

It is a matter of extreme importance that the Federal and State governments announce their plans as soon as possible. Senator Button informed me yesterday that, while the Queensland Government had made some application for loans on a personal hardship basis, there had been no plan to assist the small business community out there. I believe that that plan will be coming down in the next 24 to 48 hours, and I fervently hope that the Federal Government can make some urgent provision to let the people know what assistance will be available. While there has been a great spirit of help and self-help out in the Charleville-Augathella area, people are now starting to become worried because they have had to clean out their inundated businesses and then return home to a flood damaged house. This is starting to weight very heavily on their minds.

While disaster funding is basically a matter for State governments, the Federal Government, I believe, can offer some form of assistance. I believe there are initiatives that the Federal Government could take. Senator MacGibbon alluded to a tax holiday. There are a number of people out there who are due to pay provisional tax. That is one area in which the Government could help. The traders certainly will not be paying provisional tax on next year's income and perhaps the Federal Government could refund the provisional tax that became due only in the last two months or so. That would be a massive help.

Sales tax is also something that the Government could look at-sales tax on replacement goods that are going out there. Perhaps the Federal Government could look at a way of not charging sales tax on replacement refrigerators, replacement tools, and replacement food. All that type of thing is an initiative that the Federal Government would be able to implement.

The business community has called for wage assistance. That precedent was established when the Government funded the airline strike so that a number of airlines' employees would not lose their income during an industrial dispute. That has been established. If the Government could for, say, three or four weeks assist the business community with a wage package to keep the workers employed, to create a cash flow among the businesses, then that would be a worthwhile project.

Whatever the Government does, it is absolutely essential that it advises the small business community whether it is going to give grants because grants really are the only way that the community will get back up and running. There may be grants required that will have to be in terms of the percentage of the loss sustained by the business, topped up by disaster funding. There are already in Queensland arrangements whereby small businesses can borrow up to $80,000 at 6 per cent. That maybe the way to go where the proportion of the loss is agreed to in percentage terms, topped up with 6 per cent loans.
In closing, I ask the Minister responsible for disaster relief as a matter of urgency to advise exactly what grants, loans and assistance will be made available.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief apology.
—That would be rather refreshing in this place. Is leave granted? Leave is granted.
—Senator MacGibbon pointed out that I had called him Senator McGauran. I am well aware of the difference. I assure him that it was not a Freudian slip. It was a slip, however, and I apologise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I might make a remark about that. Obviously Senator Coulter was dazzled by Senator McGauran from the National Party being so close. He was obviously very taken by his appearance and by his presence. Obviously he is a very noticeable person in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to this motion tonight, I would like particularly to address my remarks on behalf of the people of New South Wales-the many thousands of those people in my home State-affected by the floods. We can all safely in the dry and protected chambers of this Parliament talk glibly about acts of God, and of course flooding naturally comes under that heading.

I do not suggest for one moment that the floods could have been prevented by another act of God or that we ought to have foreseen them, but it is evident from talking to those involved that more should have been done sooner. More should have been known about the dangers and better damage control methods could have been put in place.

At the last count-and these figures were supplied to me by the office of the New South Wales Minister for Agriculture-a total of 50,000 square kilometres of the north-western area of New South Wales and an area around the Lachlan River has been flood affected. Around Australia-these figures are not from the New South Wales department-the area inundated is the size of Germany, France and Britain. So the floods are widespread and their effects are quite horrific. I know it is very hard for those who have not flown over or been in a flooded area to comprehend the extent of the disaster. Even for those of us who have seen floods before, I do not think it is easy to comprehend how a drought affected area changed overnight into a flood affected area.

I had the opportunity 10 days or more ago to go from Dubbo across through Warren to Bourke and Brewarrina; I came back and spent some time in Nyngan. I saw at first hand what had been happening to the people in that area and it was quite traumatic. I have had a little bit of experience with floods myself. In 1955 I happened to be out at a property called `Haddon Rig' near Warren and I know what it is like to walk all day through waters up to and above your knees, among the centipedes and black and brown snakes, and in the squelching mud. I can just imagine how it would have been for people trying to rescue their sheep in this flood, because the mud quickly becomes very sticky. I can remember quite vividly trying to swim across a small creek running into the Marthaguy on `Haddon Rig' and deciding, when I was halfway across, to hang on to a tree because I was getting a bit tired, only to find it was covered with black and brown snakes. I can assure honourable senators my tiredness quickly diminished and I swam on with renewed vigour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll bet the snakes got a shock.

—No, that is not right; but it is not a nice experience. That is a while ago now, but I can understand that the people affected by the present flooding would have had similar experiences to those that I had on that occasion. One never forgets the experience of walking around all day in water up to and above one's knees, trying to save sheep, and getting back to one's bed at night, only to find it stuck up on bricks to keep it above the water in the house. Then there is the smell of the water, which I might add is not so bad in the first few days of the flood, but after that it really starts to stink because of the dead animals and, as the water begins to fall, the stinking mud. I can remember getting home at night and not having a nice place to lay my head. So I can understand a little of the heartbreak and the trauma and disruption that these people have been through. I would like to put on record my sympathy, and I am sure this chamber would join with me in extending sympathy, to those affected by the floods all over Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I saw the town of Nyngan, where we spent three hours. It was the most eerie experience that I have been through for some time. There were only a few people still in the town. The water marks were half to three-quarters of the way up the walls of some of the houses. I saw the smashed windows of the shops in the main street. I was struck by the stench of rotting food in the town. I saw motor cars jacked up on bricks to keep them out of the floodwaters-unsuccessfully, might I add, because what people thought from experience was going to be the level of the water was exceeded. I saw cars, some them still half full of water, in the streets. There were cars on verandahs where people had driven them, hoping to get them out of the water, some of them with the bonnet or the front end of the car stuck up at an angle in an effort to keep the engine out of the water. I can imagine the trauma that those people must have suffered when the water was going through their town.

Then there were all the household goods and other things that had been ruined. There are something like 100 businesses in Nyngan, employing maybe 500 people. Think of the problems of a place like a motel. The Nyngan Motel had 33 refrigerators, 120 chairs, 33 air-conditioners, 33 television sets and 80 doors-and doors do warp and get ruined very quickly with a flood. Let us not forget the fact that there are no guests in the motel to pay the way of the motel keeper for quite some time. I just mention a motel as a big business in a small town. It employs people and it has its own traumas. While we were in Nyngan we met Rear Admiral Peter Sinclair, who has been appointed by the State Government to deal with that disaster area, and I commend the State Government for having done that. Within about 24 hours the Rear Admiral had the whole thing under control, I would say. He is a very bright, intelligent and well trained man. I commend the State Government and the Rear Admiral for the job that has been done already.

Let us not forget the properties and homesteads in those areas which are completely isolated by water; let us not forget the livestock that have suffered through the floods. We are faced with a geographic, economic, social and financial disaster that is having a more traumatic effect in the small area of Nyngan than it would in a bigger area. That night I visited Wesley Hall in Dubbo, where the evacuees were congregated, and I would like to pay tribute to them. They were magnificent. They were accepting the fact that they could not go back to their houses because there was a concern about the health risks in the town, apart from the fact that there was not any water available for them to wash their houses out if they went back. There was no electricity. Here they were in the evacuees centre, wondering what had happened to their houses, which they had left a night or two before.

Let us look at their problems. Most of us have a house, as they have. Think how we would feel to find the television set under water as well as the refrigerator, the stove and the washing machine. Think of all the stuff in the pantry, the electrical appliances-the toaster and the radiator. Then there are the carpets, furniture, bedding, curtains and the air-conditioners. In a hot area like that the air-conditioners are halfway up the walls of the houses and they were completely covered with water. One would not have expected it, but they were. Then of course there was the clothing in the cupboards and the personal effects that were left in drawers as people left the town in haste. I was told of an elderly person in one house who was standing in water up to his chest when they went to rescue him. Of course, the water came in very quickly when the levees went. Those people will clean up their town. They have the determination to do it.

Another person actually left his farm some years ago because of drought. That person, at the age of 58, decided to set up a carrying business in Nyngan so that he could retire to the coast at a later date. Of course, that person has no carrying business left because there is nothing there to carry at the moment. He and his wife, having worked for their retirement, now have a dismal future. We need help for such people. That is the picture I am trying to paint for the Senate.

We need help from the community. I believe that the way in which the community has gone to bat for people in the flood affected areas has been magnificent. In our area, in the north west of New South Wales near Tamworth, one person who sells fuel at his fuel station said that he would give one cent for every litre of fuel that he sold over the weekend. What a great way to help during a disaster such as this. If every garage in Australia decided to give one cent for every litre sold in order to help fellow Australians during a crisis. The person from the local video shop said that he would give 10c for every video that was hired over that weekend. That was a very commendable effort. If only every video shop in Australia would do the same thing. It would not hurt them to do it. It does not hurt anyone to give a little in order to help our fellow Australians in need. I note that even in this Parliament House the social and sporting club is running a raffle for the flood victims. I think we are all compassionate. We all want to do something for people in the flood affected areas.

There are a few things that do concern me. One is the line of command that is used during a flood crisis. To me, there seems to be too much of a backlog at some stages. The local people may realise that there is going to be a big flood but, just because the monitors located on the main river do not show that this will occur, the State Emergency Services do not really take full account of the effect of local water. I am told that some of the early warning systems for the major rivers are correct, but the minor local waters cause a problem.

There are also problems regarding the way in which the defence forces are used. At this stage I would like to put on record my appreciation of the efforts of the defence forces which, when called in, worked tirelessly. I wish to thank the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) for his quick response to my calls for extra aircraft to assist in fodder drops. There was confusion at that stage over what the requirements would be. People did not know how many sheep were caught, partly because the farmers themselves were hazy about what was happening. Senator Ray responded very quickly, the Hercules aircraft went out, and a lot of sheep were saved.

There are other stories, however, of the defence forces being needed a little earlier. One of the stories I was told is that soldiers were cooling their heels on standby in Sydney while residents were desperately filling sandbags. There are stories of farmers and townspeople not being advised of the impending waters until almost the last minute, when it was too late for them to do more than lock the door and let the dogs out. Let us not forget, as I said earlier, the people who were in those isolated houses with water all around them.

The frequency of bushfires has educated us so that we can better handle bushfire catastrophes. I do not believe that emergencies such as the earthquake in Newcastle have been properly addressed by the Federal Government. There has been a distinct lack of urgency in its response to calls for various relief measures to be put in place for Newcastle. Under the national disaster relief arrangements, there is a complex formula under which the Federal Government provides funds for States on a pro-rata basis, linked with the amounts that the States themselves contribute.

I am concerned that, in the case of the three disasters that have happened in New South Wales in the last few months-the earthquake, the floods and the hailstorms-the funding situation is not as good as it should be because it is spread over two years. I suggest that the Australian Taxation Office should give sympathetic hearings to those affected by the disaster who pay provisional tax. It is good to see that Senator McMullan is present. As Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, perhaps he can take that issue to him. I know that he has given some thought to it. It would be very much appreciated by small businesses and others in the community if they could be given a chance to adjust their provisional tax payments.

Another aspect to be considered in order to get the towns back on the right track is the need to keep people in those towns. I know that one suggestion by some members of the Federal Parliament at the time of the Newcastle disaster was to give people the unemployment benefit. That is not good enough because once people go on the unemployment benefit they are lost to the employer. This affects their comradeship with fellow workers and their long term employment record. We really need to have an unemployment benefit that is in some way locked into the employment situation. A grant should be made available so that the employees remain working for the employer until the crisis is over. Obviously, they would have the right to leave if they wanted to do so. That would help people to clean up the flood damage much quicker and in a much better way. Those are just two areas that I believe should be looked at.

Another point with regard to the tax Act which I hope Senator McMullan will take on board relates to new fencing and the fact that it is deductable only at a depreciable rate. If it is a flood damaged fence I believe there should be total deductability in the year of expenditure because people have to rebuild their fences in order to ensure that their stock remains in the right place.

Those three requests are very minor ones which the Government could take on board in order to show compassion and to help people in the communities. The loans that are given by some State governments are not enough. People with these horrific problems need more than that: they need compassion and grants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by saying that I was rather intrigued by the exchanges between Senator MacGibbon and Senator Coulter-one profusely denying that he was I and another profusely apologising for accusing him of being me. I suppose that when you are dead in politics, you are dead. It is not so bad being Senator Julian McGauran. I would not want to be either of the other two.
—That is understandable.

—I knew that Senator Aulich would understand. I wish to address the Victorian aspect of the floods and relate to the Senate what occurred in the Gippsland area. The aftermath of that flood was best summed up in the Age newspaper in an article by Gerard Ryle. I will read snippets of that article:

SPEECH.PARA: It was a week in which even the trees of East Gippsland were filled with the dead.
On one property 486 sheep did not survive. The article continues:

The worst thing was watching them drown and knowing that you could do nothing about it . . . dead sheep hung from the trees. Twisted cattle carcases, entangled in wire, remained as testament to what locals described as the `worst flood in white-man history'.

Latest statistics show that about 290 cattle and nearly 2000 sheep and goats died, and about 500 kilometres of fencing was damaged. More than 90,000 bales of hay and about 590 hectares of crops were lost.

I read that particularly for the benefit of the Government. It seems that it does not know of the frustrations and trauma suffered by the people of East Gippsland. At Question Time this afternoon, even in answer to a dorothy dix question, the most compassionate Senator Richardson-and I say that tongue-in-cheek-did not name the East Gippsland area as flood prone. He does not understand that these people have suffered like so many others in New South Wales and Queensland. Senator Coulter only addressed the Queensland floods. He did not know that we have had floods in Victoria.

Worst of all, during this whole debate, this very important debate on the worst floods in Australia's history-one of the worst natural disasters in Australia's history, ranking alongside the Ash Wednesday bushfires or the 1982 drought-we have not had a Minister in the House. We have had no-one to take our requests, the people's requests, to Cabinet. Senator Boswell rightly requested early on in this debate that a Minister come into the House and at least listen to what we have to say and what the people from these flood zones have to say. Not one Minister has come into the House. In fact, the Government has not even got a quorum in this House. We are debating one of Australia's natural disasters, and the Australian Labor Party cannot even get one Minister on the front bench. It has got a lightweight over there. It is pretty pathetic and very sad.

I do recognise the widespread devastation caused by the floodwaters in Queensland and New South Wales and the trauma it brings not only to individual people but to the whole community. Anyone who has not been through such an experience, such a suffering, does not truly know or understand the loss. But like all Australians, I feel for their loss as much as one can looking from the outside; and such a loss was felt by the people of east Gippsland.

In political terms, the area is the seat of Gippsland itself, held by the National Party of Australia member Peter McGauran-a fine member-but more importantly it is my home district. As the speakers have outlined this evening, nothing jolts us out of our so-called assumed importance of our daily lives than the force of a natural disaster such as the 1982 drought, the 1983 Ash Wednesday bushfires or the present floods which could be best classified as the east coast floods. The force of nature in these forms really does humble the human pride, yet as always it brings to the fore the most heroic aspects of the human spirit-and that is probably based on the most powerful instinct of survival.

I say to the Government at the outset that the aftermath of these floods will be with us for some time to come and they should not be forgotten because they are now off the six o'clock news or the front page of the newspaper. The clean-up has just started; the costs are just being counted; and the families are now just going home. I believe that the Federal Government is in the process of reviewing its relief measures-and the measures that can be taken are in the areas of taxation primarily and direct grants. We urge the Government to fully comprehend the effects of these floods and, without delay, to face up to meeting the requirements of the people affected by way of direct grants or tax relief. We are asking for no more than what is fair and just and, indeed, that the Government should face up to helping these people immediately. To deny that swift and proper action is really to deny a very long history in Australia of helping people in need, particularly during natural disasters. We who represent those people await the Government response. We signal to the Government our determination to fight for the needs of these victims.

It is then important, in the light of the Government's ignorance and for the record, for me to outline the events as they unfolded in Gippsland so that this chamber can gain some measure of the effect upon the Gippsland region. During Friday 20 April and Saturday 21 April between 14 and 16 inches of rain fell in the Great Dividing Range running east-west-a natural boundary for the Gippsland region. It was a phenomenal rainfall, a record rainfall, the heaviest rainfall ever known to the area, and it would have been doubly worse had we not had a dry period prior to that rainfall. In fact, weirs or dams such as the Glenmaggie weir were only half full and were able to absorb, to some extent, that great rainfall.

The flooding of the Avon resulted in some 30 homes and shops in the township of Boisdale-the best publicised township to be flooded-being completely under water as well as farmhouses and properties within a two-mile radius of Boisdale and the river banks. A number of vegetable and dairy farmers suffered heavy financial losses as well as crops, livestock, fencing, fodder and equipment being lost. The Avon continued to wreak havoc downstream in the Stratford and Airly areas. Here the losses to farmers were immense, with the force of the rain again causing heavy erosion and destruction of livestock, fences and property.

The second river, the Mitchell River, filled up and gushed with the same velocity. The Lindenow Flats, which accommodate the richest vegetable and dairyland in Australia, bore the full brunt of the flooding. It can only be described as a scene of complete disaster and devastation. The losses in that area wiped out 25 per cent of Victoria's vegetable produce. It was a horrific economic loss to the State. More particularly to the vegetable growers and their families, the burden is immense, because the topsoil was completely washed away as well as their pumping stations, houses, sheds and livestock. The Mitchell River also affected the very large township of Bairnsdale, where the houses and shops along the river banks were flooded and knocked off their stumps.

In the time given to me I have attempted to outline for the Senate the dimensions of the suffering caused to Gippslanders. For this reason, I have not dwelt on the extraordinary and heroic rescue efforts undertaken by the emergency services on Saturday 21 and Sunday 22 April. Whilst the Victorian State Government agencies, including the community services of Victoria and the Department of Agricultural and Rural Affairs deserve the highest commendation for their swift and constructive response to the victims of the flood, much remains to be done. My brother Peter McGauran, the honourable member for Gippsland, together with the honourable members for Maranoa, Gwydir, Parkes, Riverina-Darling and Farrer have made representations to the Commonwealth on behalf of their constituents, and it hardly needs to be said that they will be looking towards all members of Parliament, including honourable senators in this Chamber, to support them in obtaining Commonwealth assistance to rebuild the lives and businesses of so many families.

In the minute or two I have left I highlight one particular heroic act that I believe should not go unannounced and should be written into Hansard, but I will be as brief as I can. Mr Barry Marshall from the east Gippsland district-a hay carter and crop contractor; a very well-known identity in the area-though a very modest man, is a hero as a result of this disaster and devastation. By his actions, he saved the lives of one particular family-a mother, father and two daughters. Though I do not do justice by not relating the full story to the Senate, the near tragic incident began when a car with a family aboard was washed off a bridge into the torrent. Fortunately, the family scrambled to the top of the car and clung to the rack. None of the help and efforts were successful in netting the car from the torrent. In fact, the situation became very dangerous and a matter of concern and nightfall was coming. For one moment it seemed a hopeless situation as the onlookers feared for the lives of this particular family.

Barry Marshall, aware of the river's course, went home, fetched his very massive tractor, well known in the district-I believe it is a hay cutter-and drove it to the bend of the river and then into the river, dangerous in itself, thus blocking a proportion of it in the hope, and it was only a hope, that as the car rounded the bend it would collide with the tractor and all could climb aboard and be rescued.

Thank God that this is what happened. It was a chance taken, but a chance successful. It was indeed the last chance for this particular family. It was dangerous for Mr Marshall to try it, as rescue efforts had previously given up on such a dangerous exercise. What was lost was the tractor, but what was saved was a family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I would like to extend my sympathies to the people of Longreach Charleville, Jundah and Alpha. I know all the areas in Queensland that suffered some sort of loss during the flooding. Tonight we are discussing a motion moved by Senator MacGibbon. It shows very clearly that it would be very difficult for any member of this Senate to disagree with it, except, I think, in one instance. Senator MacGibbon in his motion said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the recent floods in the west of Queensland and New South Wales have been the worst in a hundred years-
I do not think anyone would have any argument with that-
many families and individuals have lost their possessions and suffered great hardship and many local businesses cannot be re-established without substantial aid . . .
I do not think there is any argument with that from either side of the chamber. The motion continues:
recognises that it is now 3 weeks since the onset of the floods and that the task of rebuilding is urgent . . .
Again, I do not think anyone would renege on what is stated in that clause. The motion continues:

calls on the Federal Government in concert with the state governments, to explain in detail, as a matter of urgency, what help financial and otherwise will come from government sources so that those people affected can plan for the future reconstruction of their lives and communities . . .

I will deal with that item in a moment. Again, I do not think that anyone disagrees with that. I think it is very clear that the information is available, but I think people need to know where to go. To continue:

further notes that, for the towns downstream of the floods, appropriate planning was greatly hindered because no accurate predictions could be made of the likely flood levels given the complex geography and the variables involved in the great western river systems as opposed to the eastern coastal rivers . . .
I do not think there is any argument there. The motion continues:
calls on the Federal Government to fund an adequate research program as a matter of urgency so that an accurate computer model can be generated and developed to aid planners in future floods.

I am not sure that we on this side of the chamber would agree with that because I think other things need to be done first, and then I think the Government should look at what has happened and look further down the track as to what action it takes in relation to further planning and research.

Let me deal with item (c), which calls on the Federal Government, along with the State governments, to explain the details of help as a matter of urgency. I think it is quite clear to everyone that that is very difficult at this early stage and that it will be some time before accurate figures are available. Loss assessments after a natural disaster are a difficult and a time-consuming exercise. I do not think anyone would argue with that. It is very difficult to assess the losses and to say who lost and who did not.

I know a lot of people can tell us stories, and I could tell some stories about the floods and what happened to various people as individuals. But I think we need to look more broadly than that, at the total overall-what has happened to the town itself, the best way that we can plan to give that town money, and the way in which we can plan to overcome the sorts of problems that the citizens in the area generally have.

I walked through the chamber earlier tonight and heard Senator Boswell talk about the losses that people have suffered in the area. I know that the honourable senator was talking about estimates-and that is all one can call them, and in this case I only have estimates-but they show very clearly that there have been some major losses in the area. I think those losses need to be established to the point where we, as a government which has a responsibility to allocate money from the taxpayer, know that those estimates are correct-we know the losses that they are suffering and the estimates they make in relation to those losses are very clear.

Let me at this moment run through some of the costs that people have estimated at this stage. I think it has been said on a number of occasions that the total estimate for the flood would be $100m. Apart from the losses on home services, stock losses are 300,000 sheep and 11,000 cattle. Some 360 properties have been affected and 9,000 kilometres of fencing have been destroyed. The total loss to primary industry is in the vicinity of $30m. Costs so far are $2m just to clean the towns up. To bring things back to some normality would cost in the vicinity of $2m. Other estimates include $3.5m for personal hardship; $25m to repair houses; $13m for furniture; $10m for repair to shops and businesses; and $30m for road works and public buildings. Without road works in western areas, where people are isolated, it is very difficult for a community to sustain itself and work in a normal fashion.

Senator MacGibbon said in his motion that one of the things that we should be able to do is to outline to people exactly where they can gain the funds from or where they can go and request some sort of aid, whether it be financial or whatever. I think it needs to be remembered-and I do not think it is anything new-that there is a Commonwealth-State natural disaster relief arrangement which stays in place for all national disasters. A summary of the particular things that would be done in relation to national disasters very clearly outlines where people would be able to gain some sort of financial or other help in relation to the problems that they face because of the floods in their area.

Let me just for an example read from the first part of the national disaster relief arrangements. In relation to needy persons it mentions grants for relief of personal hardship and distress. The purpose would be needs and emergency repairs to dwellings. The upper limits of the amount and rates of assistance would be: single persons $6,000, families $8,000. The remarks that follow those things that I have outlined mention that initial inquiries should be made to the local clerk of the court and that assistance is means tested and may be invoked immediately if the need is indicated.
