That is very clear. It is a document that is put out by this Government. In the first instance, I suggest to people that they go to the clerk of the court and make an inquiry. Some of the information that I am relating now would be made available to them. Further down the list-and I will not read all the points there-the document mentions government and semi-government authority grants for the restoration of public assets, and concessional loans for primary producers for carrying on restocking and restoration. We talk about the 300,000 sheep that have been lost; that is the sort of thing that would be needed.

It mentions small businesses. I know we have been accused from time to time, in particular by Senator Boswell, of not looking after small businesses, but there are concessional loans for the re-establishment and the carry-on of small businesses.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are already in debt over their heads now.

—I know, but Senator MacGibbon suggested in his motion that the information was not available. I think what people need to do, first of all, is to assess the loss they have had and go to the people that might be able to give some some assistance. From that point they will be able very easily to work out where they should go to gain the sort of money they may need to carry on or to re-establish their business. Thirdly, the document mentions churches, sporting organisations and non-profit organisations. There are concessional loans and grants for re-establishment. I think those are the sorts of things that are talked about in Senator MacGibbon's motion, and that is the sort of information that should be made available.

SPEECH.PARA: If those members of parliament who represent Queensland and those areas that have flood problems go to the Treasury Department and ask for information on national disaster relief, I am sure the information will be made available to them. In turn, as good representatives, they will be able to pass on that information to the people who require it.

I say finally that one of the problems faced by the people in the western areas is that the towns that have been flooded are badly planned. One of the things this Government or any other government should look at in the future is whether we should spend money on repairing what is there or whether we should look at re-establishing some of those towns. If we have to spend $6m or $7m to repair a town and there is another flood in 10 years or 12 years time and we have to spend another $8m or $10m, it seems to me reasonable to spend the money to re-establish, so that something can be done for those towns.

All honourable senators would understand that in western Queensland the problems faced by the towns relate not just to the water and the flooding. The towns have wide streets and the councils cannot afford to put down all bitumen. They put a narrow strip of bitumen down the middle of the street and there is an area on either side that is not covered. The streets are so wide and the blocks are so big that there is a cost problem in putting in services. All those things should be looked at now. In the long term if things were done now it would be cheaper for this Government, for other governments and for the people of western Queensland.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are only a couple of minutes left but I would like to refer to a couple of matters that have been spoken of that have particular relevance to areas that are currently within my area of responsibility in assisting the Treasurer. Those are the tax matters raised by Senator Brownhill, which I thought were positive. I cannot give an immediate reaction to them, of course, because it is the first time those particular matters have been raised with me, but I do want to take this opportunity to say that I will make sure those matters, in so far as they relate to the Taxation Office, are looked at. I have already made a note to ensure that the matters he raised in his speech are taken up tomorrow by my office and reviewed. Like Senator Jones, I have a little difficulty with the last paragraph of Senator MacGibbon's motions, but the speeches that he and other senators made provided a substantial contribution. The Senate has discussed a very important national matter that deserves proper attention here. We do need to distinguish sometimes between talking about important things and saying something important. I think tonight sometimes people did one and sometimes they did the other, but it is worthwhile that the Senate should provide the opportunity for people to make contributions about great matters of national importance. These may not be contributions using the Senate as a legislative chamber, but contributions using the Senate as a forum wherein representatives of the people from the various parties can say to the Government: `These are important issues. They cross the normal party boundaries. They are not partisan issues. They are not matters at this stage requiring legislation but they are matters that concern us, as representatives of the people in the three States concerned'' Senator McGauran is right about that, if not about much else. There are three States affected and it is important that we do acknowledge that in those three States people suffered considerable-
—Order! The time allotted for the consideration of general business having expired, the Senate will proceed to the further consideration of Government Business.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity, in speaking to the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1990, to highlight two points in relation to this Bill and the matters surrounding its inception. I do not want to take up the time of the Senate tonight in arguing about the merits and demerits of the existing export market development grants scheme or, for that matter, alternatives that have been proposed. What I do want to do is canvass two particular points that arise from this Bill being introduced and the matters surrounding its inception. The first relates to the insight that those matters give us into John Button and his capacity; and secondly, the insight that the matters leading up to this Bill being before us give us in relation to the media.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I can deal first with the second aspect, the insight into the media. I noticed an article in the Age of 1 March by Michelle Grattan headed `How an export insider unmade Button's day'. Apart from the fact that the subeditor should really have `undone Button's day'-it would have been slightly more witty-the article contains some quite telling points. What Ms Grattan is saying is that had a Mr Pointer from the Australian Export Action Committee not had other engagements here at the time and had he not happened to wander into the press conference, the course of this whole matter would be quite different. As she said:

Just before 10, he wandered into the room where the news conference was to be held. He was just a face in the crowd. He told a couple of journalists that the Government's proposed changes in the existing scheme to promote exports would mean that many exporters would lose.
As we all know now, this is something that the journalists were not told in the media coverage put out by the Government. She goes on to point out:

A glance at the wad of documentation handed out to announce a new scheme and alteration of the old one showed that some key figures were missing. The Government had told only half the story. It put figures on the extra money but not on the cuts being made in the present scheme.

Of course, that is why the article is headed, `How an export insider unmade Button's day'. What Ms Grattan is saying is that but for Mr Pointer's presence at the press conference, that point would not have been picked up at that time. It follows from that that, had he not been there, maybe the media would have allowed the deceitful packaging of the plan to get through, to get by.

Now, quite frankly, that allows some very worrying inferences to be made about the capacity of the media to scrutinise Government announcements. I do not know that that is the conclusion Ms Grattan wanted us to draw but it is certainly the one that jumps out from the article under her byline. She goes on to underline the point I am making that but for an outside who knew the back and front of this scheme, the Government may have got away with this deceitful packaging. She says:
If the figures had only been exposed as questionable, the news conference might not have turned into such a disaster.

In other words, if it was only the figures that were wrong that the Government was producing, perhaps the media may have let it get away with it, and that underlines the worrying inferences that we ought to draw about the capacity of the media. She goes on to point out:
. . . it was quickly clear that Senator Button did not know the figures for his own scheme . . .

That, of course, is the real benefit of Mr Pointer having wandered into this room at 10 o'clock. First, there is the obvious benefit that the deceit of the Government was pointed out, but the real windfall is that the deceit occasioned the media to sit up and ask some genuine questions and find out that when Senator Button was not aware of the detail of the questions that were coming he was not able to give decent answers and the whole nation was laughing.

There we were. We should not be laughing because it is pretty embarrassing to find out that the Minister in charge of industry is doing calculations on the back of an envelope to try to get it right for the national media. That is very embarrassing, but that was Mr Pointer's real contribution. He allowed us to see exactly what Senator Button's real capacity is in that area. The inference, of course, is that unless Senator Button knows exactly what he is going to be asked he has not had someone give him the exact answer and he will be caught on the hop.

However, the matter got significantly worse. The Government then went on to what I believe is a damage control exercise. A number of quotes by Senator Button mention that it was irretrievable and perhaps they would have done better to take his advice that it was an irretrievable stuff-up. I think that is what Michelle Grattan referred to it as, and I would endorse her remarks in that respect. One of the Minister's later clarifying statements, as they are called-which means, `I made a big mistake and I will try to work my way out of it'-stated:

Because of uncertainties of the level of the Australian dollar and the open access nature of the scheme, it is impossible to predict with any accuracy what payments would have to be made in 1991-92 and 1992-93 had the scheme not been adjusted.

What that says is, `Look, it is all a bit difficult and we cannot really cost our scheme.' The reason he said that is that he gave four or five different costings of the scheme in the space of a couple of hours, so it is no surprise to me at all that he issued a statement saying how hard it was to cost it.

But where does that put our Minister and the Government in relation to industry policy as it relates to exports? It puts them down at that end of the Chamber with what Senator Walsh calls the fairies at the bottom of the garden. One of the most stinging complaints attacks on the Democrats attacks in the recent election campaign was made by Senator Walsh, who made such a joke of their attempt to say, `These are our policies but we cannot cost them because it is too hard.' Senator Walsh expected the Democrats to be able to cost their policies with the aid of backs of envelopes and calculators, yet he himself, with a calculator, the backs of envelopes and a whole department behind him could not do it. Where does that put the Government? As I say, it puts them exactly with the fairies at the bottom of the garden and the Australian Democrats.

The Government is unable to cost its own policies. It is no wonder that our international reputation in terms of management of industry, for which in some regard the private sector is responsible but for which others believe the Government is responsible, and that investor confidence in Australia in that regard are dwindling rapidly. This fiasco, or stuff-up as Michelle Grattan refers to it, gives us a very clear insight into just how bad this situation is.

So, we have bypassed the big glamour announcement that was brought undone by the presence of someone who knew better, and we know that we now have a Bill before us to extend the existing export market development grants scheme by six months. Yet it was not much more than eight weeks ago that the Minister was prepared to organise for himself national television coverage to launch a scheme-I do not have the name in front of me at the moment, but it was some fancy new name for a reject version of the old scheme-and he was quite confident that he had all the details: `This is the way we are going and vote for us because we know what we are doing with export market development grants'-despite the fact we all knew later in the day that perhaps the Government did not. Only eight weeks later we know that the Government does not know and never did know what it was going to do.

The Minister may try to get away with saying that that is an unreasonable complaint because all he is seeking now is an extra six months, but most people know that a week ago he was seeking considerably longer than that-another five years I think it was. So we have a situation where an Australian who wants to think about it can see that eight weeks ago a Minister announced a scheme but, when he was put on the spot as to the details of it, he could not answer and could not work out on the back of an envelope or with a calculator what it added up to, but nonetheless said, `Despite the fact that I cannot add it up, we have it all together and we know what we are doing.' Eight weeks later he says, `I think I need five years to work out what I want to do.' One week after that he said, `No, I can figure it out in six months.' We on this side of the chamber wait with anticipation to see what the Minister will come up with in six months, and I am sure we will look at it fairly and properly, but in light of what has happened in the past it could not be expected that it will be approached with an air of confidence.

In conclusion, I reiterate the two insights that I think are given by the scenario leading up to this Bill being before us. First, it tells us that the media are just as likely to swallow any well packaged fish that this Government dishes out to them. We could ask ourselves why that is the case, because we know that, had Mr Pointer not been there, the discrepancies may well not have come to light, Senator Button would not have been put under pressure and the whole nation would not have seen how incompetent he was. So, we can be very grateful for a strange face in the crowd at 10 o'clock on that morning. We can be grateful to him, but we should not let our gratitude to him or the luck of his presence in any way colour the concern we should have for what that tells us about media coverage in this nation and especially media coverage at an election time when we expect very strict scrutiny of both Government and Opposition proposals. We do not expect a situation where, unless someone taps on the shoulder of people in the press gallery and says, `You have been missed out of the picture', we will miss the fact they have been left out of the picture.

Secondly, despite all these colourful election announcements, we all know that last week Senator Button was saying he needed five years. Thankfully, he has now cut that down to only six months. As a rider to that, it is instructive to remember-I am not sure whether it was before or after this fiasco of a press conference-that the Prime Minister was describing Senator Button as one of his most innovative and assiduous Ministers. He was so assiduous that he could not add up the scheme at the time; so assiduous that a week ago he wanted five weeks to figure it out; and so assiduous that he has now suddenly changed his mind from five years to six months. The fiasco, or stuff-up as Michelle Grattan calls it, has given us a useful insight into the media and into John Button that ought not to be lightly forgotten.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is dealing with the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1990. The purpose of that Bill is simply to extend the operation of the export market development grants scheme from 30 June until 31 December of this year. That extension, however, will have certain ramifications. In fact, it will enable those hard core porn merchants who have indicated that they will apply for grants in fact to do so and, therefore, to use taxpayers' money to prostitute the image of Australian womanhood overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that it is pretty rough for these hard core porn merchants to so denigrate Australian womanhood by exporting Australian made hard core porn videos, and not only that but to use taxpayers' dollars for that purpose. I would like to mention to the Senate that in fact one such merchant, the Mature Media Group, John Lark, has indicated that he wants a hefty slice of taxpayers' money for that purpose. He has reiterated again today that he wants a hefty slice of taxpayers' dollars for that purpose.

I see Senator Coulter looking at me. He indicated this morning that it was not the appropriate time to take action. I beg to differ. It is the appropriate time to take action if we as the Senate chamber believe that taxpayers' dollars should not be used for that purpose. The very important question at stake is the status of Australian women as well as Australia's international image. A substantial part of the income of the Mature Media Group is derived from the distribution of video material which, in the words of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, treats women as `sexual commodities to arouse the sexual desires of its target audience' and `reduce persons to objects or occasions of sexual pleasure'.

The material that will be exported and promoted by taxpayers' dollars is exploitative and degrading. It is my intention in the committee stage of the Bill to move an amendment which will prevent any export market development grant going to anyone for the purpose of promoting the export of video material which has an X classification. Why? If the Senate approves of this amendment, then it will prevent the export of the degradation of Australian women and the export of material which exploits Australian women. It will prevent the export of material which, as the Joint Select Committee on Video Material said, engenders a `sexually callous and manipulative orientation towards women'.

If any honourable senator has any doubt about that and wishes to see an example of the type of material that is produced for export, I am quite prepared to show that honourable senator. I am willing to bet that, having seen the material, honourable senators would support my move to prevent taxpayers' dollars from going to promote this material overseas, because the material sullies the image of Australian women and degrades them in the eyes of the world. It depicts them in a manner that indicates that they are generally highly promiscuous and available. The material also promotes AIDS high risk behaviour. It is an interesting thing that here we are in the health budget spending millions of dollars trying to stop the spread of AIDS and this material depicts activities which are in the high risk area. The export of this material could, if the applications are made, be by courtesy of the Australian taxpayer.

I remind the Senate that as far back as October of last year I raised this matter in the chamber. I asked a question of the then Minister representing the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I referred to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 13 October 1989 which stated that Canberra's porn king, Mr Lark, would be applying to the Federal Government for taxpayer subsidisation of the marketing costs of his exports of X-rated videos.

I might say here that I know that 13 such videos have been produced in Australia, and it is very interesting to note that when the Joint Select Committee was in session Mr Lark was very coy about plans to produce this material in Australia. He is no longer coy about that. He is quite open and blatant in his statements that this is his multimillion dollar plan.

I get back to the question I asked on 17 October 1989 of the then Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I asked her whether she had noted that the Joint Select Committee on Video Material in its majority report found that such videos treated women in the manner that I have just described. I will not repeat it. I asked her whether she agreed that an application for taxpayers' funds to market Australian-made hard-core pornographic videos was a contentious issue and that the status of Australian women as well as Australia's international image was at stake. I asked also what action the Minister intended to take on it.

To her credit, she did say that she had made a note to discuss the issue with Senator Button even before I had raised that question. She said so because she believed that this was a matter of `extreme sensitivity' within the community.

I then followed that up with a question to Senator Button. Again, in the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) on 29 November I followed it up again with Senator Button. The effective response of Senator Button to my question and to the matters that I raised during the debate on the Appropriation Bill was that if the Lark media group applied for an export development grant there was no way that he could interfere in the provision of that grant. In other words, he indicated that if such an application was made it would be approved if it fell within the guidelines. The guidelines do not exclude hard-core pornographic videos.

Honourable senators might ask me why I am using the word `hard-core'. I am using it because it is a word that was used and I have a statutory basis for using it. As honourable senators will realise, when the Classification of Publications Ordinance was tabled in this place in 1984, I think it was, the explanatory memorandum indicated that there would be a new classification, namely X, and that would apply to hard-core pornographic videos.

We are now talking about that type of video. The videos which have been produced by the Mature Media Group for export, the ones to which I referred previously, have received an X classification. How many have been produced and have not received any classifications or perhaps not even been submitted for classification, I do not know. That matter was raised with me by Senator Walters. I acknowledge here that that is a problem. To cover the whole of the situation my proposal, which honourable senators have, will need to be amended to include videos which have not received a classification, because it is quite possible for videos to be produced in Australia for export and not be submitted to the Film Censorship Board for classification. So I acknowledge the point that was raised by Senator Walters with me during today and I would support her in any amendment to cover that situation, because it is an important one.

This is a very serious question, a very serious question indeed. As I indicated earlier, Australia's image is at stake. Canberra has become the hard-core porn centre for Australia and the group that I mentioned intends Australia to become the hard-core porn centre for South East Asia and a major world porn centre.

Some honourable senators may not consider it appropriate for these types of videos to be banned for sale and hire in the Australian Capital Territory. Indeed, that question was considered in this chamber and it was narrowly lost. It was considered in another place and it was narrowly lost-by one vote. We are not dealing here with the issue of whether the material should be banned or not at this juncture. We are dealing with the issue as to whether Australian taxpayers' dollars should be used by hard-core porn merchants to promote these degrading and exploitative videos overseas. That is what we are dealing with. Unless we act now, if the producers of these videos for export do make an application to Austrade under the export market development grants scheme, Austrade will have to shell out taxpayers' dollars for that purpose. That is the issue we are discussing at this point of time.

I do not want that to be confused in the minds of honourable senators because if honourable senators vote against my proposition, what they are saying to the taxpayers is not only are they going to impose their view on them relating to these videos, but they are going to use their money and give that to the hard-core porn merchants to promote these X-rated videos overseas. I ask any honourable senator to go out on the street and seek to justify that position.

Senator Coulter, as I understand it, was not speaking for the Democrats as a whole, but he made an individual point that it was not appropriate now. I hope that I have indicated to Senator Coulter that it is appropriate to deal with this matter now because we have a statement by the major producer-the porn king, as he is described-that he intends to make an application under the export market development grants scheme. We are not dealing with an if and when situation; it is not a straw man; it is an immediate threat.

I ask Senator Collins, who is in the Minister's seat, to try to justify that amongst his constituents-to tell them, `Your hard-earned money and your hard-earned taxes are going to be given to the hard-core porn merchants so that they can prostitute the image of Australian womanhood overseas and make their fast buck in so doing'. It is not only an individual fast buck; it is millions of dollars. I ask him or any of his colleagues to try to sell that to the public if they intend to vote against it.

I make this appeal, particularly to colleagues on this side of the chamber who may be listening to the debate. This is a serious matter of conscience. It is a serious matter because we are dealing with taxpayers' money-people who do not want a bar of the export of the material. We can have our differences on whether the material can be banned or not but, when it comes to the crunch of whether we are going to require taxpayers to pay for the promotion of it overseas, that is another issue. That is the issue that we are dealing with today and that is the issue which is included in my amendment. I am quite certain, of course, that my amendment, if carried, will prevent the producers of hard-core porn, that exploitative and degrading material, from cashing in on taxpayers' dollars for the purpose of exporting this material.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: I apologise for not raising this earlier when Senator Vanstone sat down, but there was a certain disturbance in the chamber. It relates to an expression used by Senator Vanstone. In the course of her speech she used the term `stuff-up', a term which I have never used. I find it personally extremely offensive, and I think anybody who looks at the origin of this term will find that it has very strong sexual connotations. I would ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to rule on the use of that term because I find it quite unparliamentary and quite inappropriate, especially in this debate in view of the matter which has been raised by Senator Harradine.
—I have noted your comments, Senator Coulter, but that matter should have been raised at that particular time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is little point in debating once again my private members Bill that attempted to prohibit the importation, sale and hire of the more extreme violence in R-rated and X-rated videos. Suffice it to say that women's organisations throughout Australia have told the Government in no uncertain terms that they believe that X-rated videos degrade the status of women, as does some of the extremely violent sexual violence in R-rated videos. Madam Acting Deputy President, for the benefit of new senators I will read just a few quotes from a cross-section of the women's organisations because some senators were not here during the debate. It will put in context how the women of Australia feel about these degrading videos.

SPEECH.PARA: Joy Taylor from the Women's Electoral Lobby writes:
WEL is totally opposed to any portrayal of women that exploits or degrades them in any way or portrayal of women that reinforces the unequal power relationship that exists in society.

WEL ACT endorses the intent of your Bill to ban X-rated videos in the ACT. We believe that it is inappropriate for the ACT to continue to distribute X-rated videos in the face of the contrary decisions of the Attorneys-General in all States.
The Catholic Women's League says, `We are against the proposed non-violent erotica category and feel that the existing R and M classifications should be tightened'. (Quorum formed)

I was just going through the various women's organisations that had supported my private members' Bill, the aim of which was to get rid of the more extreme violence, particularly sexual violence, in R-rated and X-rated videos. I said that the Women's Electoral Lobby had endorsed the intent of my Bill and that the Catholic Women's League also did, as did the Country Women Action Alliance. The Mothers Union of Australia said that it believed it illogical for the Government to support such projects as `Fair Go for Women' and affirmative action, which seek to improve the status of women in the community, and allow the free availability of material which depicts women as mere objects of male gratification.

There were a number of other organisations, including the women's organisations of Australia, and not only church leaders but Australia's largest trade union, the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Union, the Australian Parent's Council, the Australian Council for Children's Films and Television, to name just a few. That women's taxes should be used to support the export of these videos is, I think, quite against the intention of all those groups that wrote giving the Government their views.

I intend, as Senator Harradine has already indicated, to move an amendment to his amendment by adding after his amendment the words `or has not been classified'. Senator Tate, who is in the chamber, might be interested in my amendment because it goes that just bit further than Senator Harradine's amendment, which would prohibit grant money being paid for Mr Lark to produce these X-rated videos. It would also deny Mr Lark money to produce child pornography and all those other videos that in this country we say are illegal. If he produces these videos and does not put them up for classification, according to the Australian Customs Service he is quite at liberty to export them. It is for this reason that I seek to add to Senator Harradine's amendment the words `or has not been classified'. I intend to move that amendment at the correct time in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. In respect of the amendment to be moved at the committee stage, in order at least to attempt to dispose of this matter tonight, considering the legislative program we have, I shall be very brief in my remarks. I would like to thank honourable senators who contributed matters other than the contributions to Senator Harradine's amendment. I think probably the most pertinent contribution during that part of the debate was made by Senator Coulter, who pointed out that this is a one-clause Bill which provides simply for an interim period to be allowed, so that the 50-plus recommendations of the Hughes Committee can be properly considered by the Government. We know, of course, that there will be a very substantial debate on the same piece of legislation in the Budget sittings.

SPEECH.PARA: Could I just say, in touching on Senator Harradine's amendment, which will be moved at the committee stage, that the Government at this point will not support it and state the reasons why. The current situation under the scheme is that there is discretion already in the way in which these grants are allocated for prohibiting the application of funds for matters which are unlawful. Rightly or wrongly, at this point in time this is not an unlawful activity, although many people, including myself, may well find it distasteful. Indeed, if honourable senators want to be just a little philosophical about this, and I think it is probably a good idea at times to be a little philosophical, they could logically extend a precedent such as this, if it were created, to prohibit the application of public moneys for the export of other Australian commodities which many of us find even more abhorrent-things such as tobacco, alcohol, and so on exported to the Third World.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would go along with that.

—I am sure there are a lot of people who would go along with a lot of these things but, rightly or wrongly, this Parliament at this point in time has declined to make this activity unlawful, though it may well decide to do so in future. Indeed, another parliament has recently decided, by a narrow vote or no, and that is the way democracy works, that at this time the activity is not unlawful. I believe it would be far more appropriate for this Parliament to proceed at this time not to accept Senator Harradine's amendment-I will canvass this if I need to, as I may need to, in the committee stage, which may well not be taken tonight-but for the Government to give careful consideration to what Senator Harradine is proposing. I can give him and the Parliament that assurance. It may well be, if Mr Lark's business activities are as profitable as he claims they are going to be, that he will not be eligible for grants under this scheme in any case.

SPEECH.PARA: In the six months that the Parliament has to consider the Hughes Committee recommendations, it might decide bringing down a full package of amendments to this legislation later this year, to create for the first time since this Act has been operating a precedent in establishing one special class of goods for which it is not appropriate to provide export grants. The Government may well have a view on that issue. Indeed, I have a view of my own, which inside the forums of my Party I will press, in respect of the application of public moneys for this purpose. Ultimately, of course, as Senator Harradine would be the first to acknowledge, it is the Parliament that determines the shape of the legislation that leaves this place and the House of Representatives.

It may well be that Parliament decides, upon mature reflection, that it is necessary. I simply put a cautionary note on it: at this point there is a discretion within the organisation to preclude the application of public moneys for unlawful purposes, rightly or wrongly.

Senator Harradine would be the first to concede that we have had this debate ad nauseam. The one debate that nobody could claim has not been canvassed to death in this Parliament is the question of X-rated videos. As someone who has participated in every debate on the matter while I have been in the Parliament, I can say that, rightly or wrongly, we have taken the position we have.

I would prefer to see the Parliament consider this very serious and pertinent issue that Senator Harradine had raised along with all the other recommendations for the amendment of this Act that have been raised by the Hughes Committee, which will be canvassed in a full and comprehensive debate in this Parliament later this year. From my own point of view I must say, taking Mr Lark at his word, that if it should be that he does make as much money as he suggests he is going to make, he will not be eligible for the grant anyway. Should it appear that he might be, it may well be at the end of this year the Parliament may well determine that it should have a particular view on this case. With the greatest respect, I think it is appropriate to leave these matters, along with the 50 recommendations of the Hughes Committee, to the substantive debate that will occur on this legislation in the Budget sittings.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
